151211492.review:
Pretty good single-player game to sink some time into.

You just kinda make your character, send them into the world and off you go.
A bit unforgiving the first few times when you have no clue what is going on.
Trailer does a good job of showing you the base game loop, but to get better you have to die a few times first - or many in my case :P

The Plus Edition brings a lot more content into the game, including:
- 3 new classes and quests
- More items
- More endings
- More NPCs
- Better meta-progression (Addition of Castle and Dimensional Coins)
- Quite a few Quality of life improvements

The base game is fine as is and I think I put about 60-ish hours into it before going into Plus Edition.
When transferring your save file from the base game to the Plus version, it will attempt to wipe some parts of your save file (records of prior runs, prior gear enhancements in the vault, and a few other things). I believe I bypassed this by straight up copying one of the files in one folder and pasting it into the other.

The Plus Edition the definitive way to play the game, but I feel that the base game is easier since scaling is more busted and you can traverse mountains and water in 1 turn with certain builds/classes.
If you have to pick one, just go with the Plus Edition, but 

I just wish that I could get access to all the music tracks that they have as another DLC or music list somewhere, since I often find myself whistling them when walking on my own.
The music is all royalty free, but the quality and range of music is great in my opinion.

Great game, sufficient story to get invested in with a great soundtrack to suit every emotion.
Strongly recommend.

147787898.review:
I played this game with my Steam offline, so I've sunk much more time into this game despite what my gameplay stats suggest.

I found the game surprisingly addictive. Each class has their pros and cons; at first glance, the minor differences in each class seem to mean little, until you actually try the class out and realize that it actually makes a surprising difference in how the game is played. Compounded with the randomness of your circumstances with each run and the game continues to provide a (reasonably) fresh experience over an extended period of time. 

There is a surprising amount of customisability afforded to the player; you can retrieve items from your vault (that you have accumulated over past runs) and allocate perks to your character to improve them in small but impactful ways.

The (important / hireable) characters you encounter don't get more than a handful of scenes to flesh out their characters, but they do inject life into the game. 

I think the best part of the game is its music. Each region / big boss comes with its own piece, and even after hours of gameplay and listening to the same songs over and over, I still find them pleasant to listen to.

The story is not particularly deep (and upon further inspection is actually kind of stupid) but I still enjoyed how the plot subverted expectations in ways I did not think possible. You are lead to believe that the big boss of the game is the demon lord (who, to be fair, literally chases you to the ends of the earth to kill you). However, this is not the case; as you play the game (or browse the internet), you would find out that the demon lord is not actually the hardest / final boss you can fight. 

Personally I found the game quite enjoyable, and more than worth its price.

140739479.review:
One Way Heroics is a unique and engaging roguelike game developed by Smoking WOLF. The game offers a compelling mix of RPG and strategy elements that will keep players entertained for hours on end.

The game's plot centers around a world that is being consumed by darkness, and the player must journey through various environments to reach the "Last Demon King" and stop the spread of darkness. The gameplay mechanics are relatively straightforward, with players needing to gather resources, upgrade their equipment, and manage their health and stamina as they progress.

One of the most interesting features of One Way Heroics is the way the game world is randomly generated each time players begin a new game. This means that every playthrough will be different, and players will need to adapt their strategies accordingly.

The game's graphics are simplistic, but they work well in the context of the game. The game also features a fantastic soundtrack that really helps to set the mood and create a sense of urgency and danger.

Overall, One Way Heroics is an excellent example of a roguelike game done right. The combination of RPG and strategy elements, random level generation, and compelling gameplay make it an engaging and entertaining experience for any fan of the genre. If you're looking for a game that will keep you hooked for hours, One Way Heroics is definitely worth checking out.

133421592.review:
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]First Impressions[/h1] 
I've played several RPGs, so when I saw the unique premise behind One Way Heroics (OW), I was intrigued by how this would work out. Having to run away from a constantly encroaching screen edge, while still taking on typical heroic tasks such as slaying monsters, obtaining treasure, and in theory talking to NPCs sounded bizarre and challenging. The question is whether OW is heading the right direction, or if it's going against the flow of traffic and gets run over. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1] 
As already mentioned, the objective of OW is to avoid the instant death effect caused by the black edge of the screen. This isn't a real-time hazard, so you aren't actively weaving through obstacles like a shoot-em-up. Instead it's turn-based, so you have to plan ahead, choosing a route and moving square by square, dealing with different barriers such as enemies, mountains, etc. The game is a rogue like though, so death is expected. 

Each time you die, you'll lose all of the items you acquired, though you can place a few into the dimensional vault for the next run. You'll also earn heroic points for how you performed during the run, which can be used to unlock new perks, classes, and expand the size of your dimensional vault. Unfortunately, you'll always start off as a level 1 noob, no matter which perks or classes you select for them. Additionally, unless you put it into the vault, your funds and starting gear is going to be weak sauce. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2937194404
[h1]Controls[/h1] 
Part of the reason for my large gap in first trying OW and reviewing it stems from not having a compatible controller at the time. Therefore, I was making do with a keyboard, which isn't my first choice for most games. One downside to the game's design, no matter how you control it, is how often you'll want to move diagonally for optimal travel. It works alright at least some of the time, but when it really matters, I have to be very careful and selective with each movement. 


[h1]Story[/h1] 
Like many RPGs, the once peaceful land must deal with a great evil. However, this one is more meta than normal, but no less harrowing. The very edge of the screen is eradicating everything as it sweeps from left to right, and only by persevering through several deaths and attempts to build up strength will you be able to fend it off. If you clear the game multiple times, with several classes and allies, you'll uncover more of the game's lore. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2937194796
[h1]Visuals[/h1] 
The game makes use of basic pixel graphics, and they do the job. Unfortunately, with everything so small on the screen, you spend more time looking for upcoming things of interest than characters or enemies. To make the tactics of this turn-based system work everything is built on a grid system, making environments have a flat, bland look to them. Something that really drains my interest in playing further is the lack of enemy variety; skeletons, birds, goblins, lizards, etc. How can you tell which ones are powerful? They've got a triangle over their head, “Oh no, we're doomed! That bat has one of the Triforce pieces!” 


[h1]Sound Design[/h1] 
Checking on YouTube, I was pretty surprised by how many tracks there are for OW. I suppose the idea was that with no set place for any area type, such as desert, grasslands, or whatever else, multiple themes should be made that can be interchanged freely, “Play the second theme for grasslands this time.” With the rate you'll progress to the right, you often won't stay in any place for too long, unless you're managing your inventory or bashing through a mob of enemies. However, each song is on the short side, which doesn't help with becoming too repetitive from looping. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2937194654
[h1]Pros[/h1] 
🌟 You can achieve specific goals if someone has a helpful world seed to share. 
🌟 It's a unique idea for a game.


[h1]Cons[/h1] 
❌ The mini-map helps you avoid mountains or bodies of water (and lava), but unless you've used an item, doesn't tell you about upcoming forts or NPCs. It's hard to make progress or prepare well when you're ill-informed. 
❌ Activities such as wandering towns, conversing with locals, etc. are absent from OW. These often aren't the highlights of an RPG, but they help build the world and set the tone. 
❌ I already have enough factors to keep in mind without an energy system to mess with. Missing my attacks so many times also ticks me off. 


[h1] Tips [/h1]
🔍 The game will announce when you're approaching certain thresholds and nearing the demon lord. Fighting enemies and increasing your level is one of the main ways to prepare for the fight. 
🔍 As long as you're not completely trapped against a wall or mountain range, you can push the limits of being near the darkness a good amount. Just escape when you absolutely have to. 
🔍 Money didn't seem that useful, as I didn't find anywhere to spend it. If you find a place that sells healing items, bulk up, as they're helpful for fighting the demon lord. 


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1] 
To this day, I don't think I've seen another game quite like OW, but there's a reason it's not generating copy-cats. Though it's unique and works well enough to compliment the developers' premise, it takes out much of what makes the two types of games it's based off work well. As an RPG, the combat is stripped down to a bare minimum, with a scant amount of options available. You lose the scope and freedom to explore a fleshed-out world and to learn more about it, its inhabitants, and even the monsters you fight. There's no way to develop lore about specific towns and locations with a game based on randomly generated worlds. It's possible to gain allies, but they're basically just extra attacks, not characters. Buried deep under several playthroughs may be a story, yet with no developed world or characters to care about, what's the point or value? 

Looking at the rogue like side, it has the general cycle down, as you get stronger and make more progress over time. However, much of the challenge is learning good routes to take and what random equipment you could find is worth a darn. The lack of more clear landmarks to reference doesn't help with navigating either. Plus, rogue likes often end after you beat the big bad or clear the final dungeon. In OW, you'd be expected to keep replaying with various classes, earning specific epilogues by meeting nitpicky requirements during the run. There's really no incentive to keep playing after beating the demon lord once except for the sake of playing the game more or unlocking achievements. It's pretty cheap, but I don't think it's really worth it.

Done with the base game. Pretty neat RPG experience, some classes are MUCH better at getting the ball rolling than others, the dimensional vault make it easy to start understanding the game more and exploring other classes. Getting companions other than Freya seems quite hard unless the game throws you a special world to easily get one.

[spoiler] Also, shrines are sometimes abundant and others... just there isn't any on the run. Defeating the true boss is such a chore because finding the correct weapon to use against him depends on RNG (or on reaching the ends of the earth) [/spoiler] 

The highest difficulty seems pretty impossible without the vault or a REALLY strong class to start. 
The epilogues are a nice touch and I really enjoyed the tragic/happy tidbits of story from some of the characters.

I plan on buying the PLUS DLC once its on offer and check the improvements to the base game. But even if you only get the base game, I say its an imaginative different RPG with good enough gameplay although at times unfairly hard.

UPDATE: I did end up buying the DLC and playing through it, there is many nice updates that balance some of the hardest classes to start with (Force user, hunter) and a lot of new items to make things interesting.

The dimensional update manages to increase on the game's story quite nicely, I loved the additions of the new epilogue text and the new companions, the force knight class feels great while the ninja feels like a glass cannon with a lot of interesting skills with a considerable price of use.

The only frustrating part for me was using the tourist and trying to complete the journal mission, the epilogue makes it worth it a bit, but it is needlessly complex.

Overall this game was a great, if at times a raging experience due to misfortune.

115379455.review:
[b] tl;dr One Way Heroics is an absolute gem of a Mystery Dungeon-like game that is a STEAL when on sale and IMO worth full price, but get it with the One Way Heroics Plus DLC. Addicting gameplay loop, amazing music, surprisingly deep amount of freedom / flexibility to play how you want. [/b]

You know when you can tell a game you're playing is a passion project? One Way Heroics is a clear example of that. It's also one of my favorite games of all time for many, many reasons.

This is a game presented in a simple package - move right, don't die, don't get swallowed by the screen scroll. In reality, One Way Heroics is much deeper than that. Even though you want to go in "One Way," you're really free to play however you want. The classes give you freedom to play how you want - you can go for a pure strength build with the Knight, play with magic as a Force User, hoard items as an Adventurer, or rely on your party with a Bard (and this isn't even half of the classes in the game). There's no class-locked weapons, so you can also wield whatever you want. Want to kill NPCs? You can even do that too (with consequences, of course)! There's even different ways to win the game... but I'll leave that for you to explore!

Every run, win or lose, also feeds into future runs - it's a roguelite, after all! This game's implementation of the roguelite formula is really cool. Aside from your standard class / perk unlocks, there's also a "Dimensional Vault" that lets you store items in-between runs. The obvious use for this is to carry powerful items over to your next run, but you don't have to use it (and you get bonus score if you don't use the vault)! I personally use it as a "trophy case" for storing the many unique items you find in the game. I'm also currently carrying a set of armor across multiple runs and stacking enchantments on it to make the best piece of armor ever. There's a lot of cool stuff you can do here!

One Way Heroics is also a pretty funny game and it doesn't really take itself too seriously, which fits well with the overall simple style of the game. The music is also stellar, and I'd argue the soundtrack itself is worth the full asking price of the game. 

I've played 50 hours of this game so far and I think I can see myself playing at least 50 more hours - I still need to unlock some hidden classes, master the harder difficulties, and try winning in different ways. There's also some online components to the game - every run is a seed and ANYONE else playing online can see progress from other players asynchronously! There's daily and weekly runs in the game as well (as well as daily runs with unique gameplay modifiers)!

Of course, I have some criticisms. I wish there was more item variety across the board - after playing a while I tend to see the same stuff over and over. There's also been some moments where I felt the game was a little unfair - strong enemies spawning too early, for example. I think I just need to shift my strategy on consumable items I keep around for emergencies, though. Additionally, the game's QoL is apparently really bad if you don't have the Plus DLC, but I've never played it without Plus.

All in all, there's just so much in this game to play around with and it feels like the developers really cared about the fun factor when making it. Please get this game, ESPECIALLY if it's on sale - if you like roguelites, the Mystery Dungeon series, or fast paced RPGs, you will not regret it!

[i] As a personal note - I really want to see this game's community revived in some form. I've been buying the game for whoever I can and I hope I can contribute to the community in some significant way. Maybe I'll do weekly streams of it where everyone can play together? [/i]

106721094.review:
This game is awesome. It seems simple at first, but the player constantly makes choices that dictates the character's future - including and especially from the beginning. The game is kept fresh with regular challenges, a story that evolves with each run you complete, and constant decision-making on the part of the player.
Somehow, the game can get you connected with the characters, despite the fact that, by nature of constantly restarting the game, you are constantly back at "step one" in learning who the characters are. Perhaps my investment in the characters is derived from how rare they can be to encounter - running into a recruitable character with enough charisma to recruit them is amazing, and running into them without the means to recruit them (either in charisma or in [spoiler]the ability to break them out of what amounts to a stone death trap[/spoiler]) is somehow both disheartening (because you can't recruit the character) and encouraging (because restarting will eventually give you another shot).
Seed-based world generation means that you (and your friends!) can play and replay the same map as many times as you want. For what is basically a mystery dungeon game, this is neat, as you can use your accumulated knowledge to make movement decisions that you otherwise wouldn't without the foresight. Alternatively, if you want a whole new seed to play on, it's as simple as generating a new random world to save. The game can be played how you want - if you want to try a single seed for 4 hours in a single day, go for it! If you want to make 10 minutes of progress a day, you can do that too. Want to beat easy mode in under 20 minutes? Unlock [spoiler]hero[/spoiler], stack [spoiler]the unarmed damage upgrade[/spoiler] at the start of the game, and you have a quick and easy run.

Overall, One Way Heroics is a fun experience. Expect to die, [i]a lot[/i], but with so much replay value, you can find yourself playing again and again.

106566064.review:
So there I was, in the tundra, starving to death. Having just dealt with a horde of bears and skeletons, my health was in the single digits. My energy was 0%. I was surely to die in my next encounter. A few hours and kilometres pass, and there were no villages or monsters in sight.

But as luck would have it, a rabbit appeared. I smacked it dead with my sword, and consumed its flesh in the cold winter night. Its meat was rancid and I was poisoned, but it filled the stomach and restored some health. Two steps later, a member of the One Way Heroics PETA organization stood before me. She knows what I have done. That horrifying midi piano music played, and she began shooting arrows at my general direction. Still low on health, I had no choice but to stop time and bash her head in, killing her instantly.

After the encounter, I found a tavern. I was already on a bounty list, but they didn't recognize me yet. I walked over to the chef for some food, and I managed to restore some of my life and fill my hunger. I decided to buy take out. My inventory was full, so I had to throw away something. But instead of politely dropping an item, I accidentally threw a dagger. Directly at the chef that just fed me. The entire tavern--the guard, the merchants, the fortune teller, and even the save receptionist--became hostile to my presence. I had no choice but to kill them all to preserve my own hide.

As I was slaughtering the people of the tavern, a group of polar bears surrounded the building. The big one started to claw into the walls with each turn while I struggled to murder the people of the tavern. After I killed the last of the people, I now had to deal with the roided polar bears that approached me. But before I could land the first blow, the Demon Lord appears. In a panic, I stopped time yet again to equip my staff and repeatedly barraged the bears with flames. Their meat burned and became grilled, and I consumed their cooked flesh as I turned their bodies into sweet, nutritious, BBQ. The leftover meat that wasn't cooked I gathered into my inventory, which I then grilled using the portable BBQ set in my inventory, and immediately consumed.

My health restored, my energy now at max, 2 more roided bears in front of me, and the Demon Lord behind me. I can survive this encounter. I had confidence that I can even defeat the Demon Lord as well. I grilled the remaining bears and brought out my secret weapon: the Holy Dagger. It had one durability left. So I threw it at the Demon Lord to free some space for grilled meat, and break his many barriers.

... But it missed. And ended up hitting a dragon. And that dragon was, to put it lightly, pissed about having a dagger thrown at it. It took a deep breath and blasted both myself and the Demon Lord with a beam of fire. Again in a situation where I cannot possibly survive another turn, I decided to stop time and run away while I could, eating some grilled meat to shrug off the damage I've taken.

After some distance of running, the Demon Lord left, and the dragon eventually stopped being pissed. Then I walked 10000 km to the right and finished my run.

In short, 10/10 it's okay. Purchase with OWH+, otherwise it's technically just a demo.

105447122.review:
PRELIMINARY REVIEW // 4.7 hours on record
----

As one archaeologist said, cat perched on the shoulder, as they disappeared down a set of weather-worn slab stairs: "anything is edible as long as you have a tinning kit."

I have no idea what they meant.

Like the passage of time, [b]One Way Heroics[/b] is inevitable. This 'tiny-in-file-size-but-big-in-replayability' game is a rogue-lite: rogue, meaning misbehaved, lite meaning only somewhat.

Rogue-lite games are games built around two core concepts 1) that each session is a self-contained episode and 2) some progress from a session which previously ended in your death will carry over into your next session. Typically, these unlocks can be character classes, weapons, equipment, or character upgrades. Games like [i]The Binding of Isaac[/i] are considered Rogue-lites.

The core concept of [b]One Way Heroics[/b] is that you are ever-marching onwards to your inevitable death. A wave of death edges ever closer to you in real time as you move. Advance far enough to the right, the screen will scroll. But retreat too far back, and you'll find that the screen only scrolls one way: forwards.

This game does work on both controllers and keyboards. I found I enjoyed this most when played on a controller/gamepad -- the cheerful 16-bit artwork makes it feel like a long-lost classic from the days when NetHack was still ASCII and when the MegaDrive was king.

Compared to the cheesecake that is Nethack, [b]One Way Heroics[/b] is M&Ms. You always tell yourself you can control your portions, but by the time you check your watch after starting, you've eaten the entire childrens' haul from halloween and it's 4AM already.

[i]One Way Heroics[/i] is a neat little experience that's refreshing as both an action-RPG and a "cheap" (only $3.49 new!) title. There's very little story, so it's no big deal if you put it down for weeks, months, or even years; it's easy to pick up for fifteen minutes or a few hours.

Even if you suck at it (or just have a bad run), you're always progressing, which makes the whole gimmick of the game - to always be moving forward - more fun and rewarding.

This game is a pleasant JRPG-themed rogue-lite that lets you custom a few fantasy character classes and 'move to the right' for looting and adventure - because the world is being consumed from the left, and it doesn't stop for anything. This is an excellent game to pick up and spend an hour or two trying to collect items and earn Hero Points to unlock new Classes and Perks to help you in future runs... and there will be many future runs. Good news, the game itself offers a lot of helpful tips both in-game and via a gameplay summary at your untimely end. There is also a wide variety of gameplay options and settings as well, including Random generation, seed-loading via password, and even multiplayer.  There's plenty of content; folks who love doing 100% of games will find lots of goals (both obvious and hidden) to achieve.

92965394.review:
One Way Heroics, otherwise known as Oh Lawd He Comin Simulator.

One Way Heroics is an extremely straight forward game, literally, as there is only one way to go. You must go east as the darkness approaches from the west. It is a roguelike RPG where you can pick from classes and talents but ultimately at the end of the day the goal is always the same, save the world. With lots of endings and options to choose from, it makes a good attempt at rewarding hard labor, especially with unlockables and secrets that really flesh out what appears as a deceptively small box of a game. 

Quite frankly, I think it's a shame this game is so obviously limited in scope. I feel this game with a full production from a larger company, with a larger budget and resources to get there, would make for an amazing experience even in modern gaming. I ultimately rushed through finishing this as I love the charm and had a great time, but even a few hours in you have a good idea of just what you're gonna get out of this. While that's not particularly a bad thing, it does mean that I wish there was more to it, as it has many great ideas from mechanics to the very scope of the game's setting and the characters that inhabit it.

If there is anything this game surprised me with, it's just how invested I got into the endings. Normally endings are just a matter of doing X before Y, but this game, albeit it short and simple, had characters and twists that genuinely entranced me, and I would be lying if I didn't tear at least a little at some of the endings. While I could say more, I will simply leave this one up to you to discover, as I feel the narrative of this charming little game is fully worth the exploration. 

All and all that about sums up my experience with One Way Heroics. I first played this game in 2015, and just now game back to finish it in my everlasting pursuit to clean up my library. While I may be moving on to something new, I'm sure there's an adventurer or two who can set up shop and take back the world in my place. If that adventurer is you, I wish you luck in the never ending battle against the darkness, as you are in for one interesting tale of a ride.

91801626.review:
Easy to pick up, difficult to put down, and worth more than it's low asking price. Also it's nice to see a game where the boss isnt immune to everything, so you can get creative.



After spending FAR longer playing the base game, I can say that it is certainly a quality game and well worth playing despite it's age. The randomly generated biomes, loot around the world, locations of towns, and just a  merchant chilling in a field really make the runs different (for better or worse) And most importantly, the game works. Over 200hrs without a crash, making the bonus for completing a run without saving possible to do. Alt tabbing in and out of fullscreen to my heart's desire with no problem. (On dx11, I tried dx9 and crashed immediately.

The game makes you swap around weapons and armor as repairing is extremely limited, unless you jerry rig your gear which then makes it break faster. Managing your inventory, the durability of your gear, weight of a weapon vs. it's power, and the 5 times you can stop time can all make the game stressful. Each decision can make or break you. 

Unfortunately, some decisions aren't yours to make as the game does have it's flaws. The map and health bars are very much in the way of the game, and the off screen detection arrows are done quite poorly. The text of your active effects can block your map (using area map and detection always does). These are changed in the DLC but in my opinion, you shouldn't have to buy dlc for a HUD adjustment option. 
Furthermore, the generation of buildings and their doors is infuriating. Their are occasions when, by the time you see the location of the door, it's too late to go in, missing out on a merchant that could've helped you. Or, more frustrating, when the doors are facing mountains and you have to bust your way through. Even if you're an Adventurerer or Hunter class, you're not climbing those mountains quickly unless it's leveled up enough. In that case, good luck getting through with a dagger or bow.
And then, there are the NPCs in the towns. They are not safe from monsters. There are "guards" at each village and town mostly, and they will threaten you if you do anything. But any monster can go into a town and murder every NPC and these guards will do nothing unless they are within 1 tile of the enemy and only if the enemy targets them. The random spawning of NPCs that can be your companions are also unsafe from the world's monsters, as you get the "to the > you can sense a kindred spirit" just to see that they die 3 turns later with absolutely nothing you can do about it.

Just a few flaws, but far too annoying to go unspoken. It's a good idea to start with the base game before just playing the Plus DLC. It is nice to enjoy the more generous boosts that stats give, and the overall easier and less punishing gameplay.

89355145.review:
Wether you're interested in traditional roguelikes or want an rpg style dungeon crawler, wether you like short games or hour long runs, this game has something for you and is definetly worth the look.

It features a good selection of classes, 4 difficulty settings which also alter the gameplay and possibly gameplay length, daily special campaign worlds as well as "Maniac Mode" as a modifier for any of the difficulties for the true roguelike expierience. It features several ways to complete your run, from killing the Demon Lord over defeating the Darkness by other means up to circumventing the world or even the whole dimension.

Without maniac mode, the game uses a move order depending on everyones speed, like seen in many jrpgs. When you die, it also allows you to save a few items in the "Dimensional Vault" so you can retrieve them with your next character, giving you a unique sense of character progression, despite the perma-death.

With Maniac Mode on, it's strictly turn based. Something is faster than you? It will get 2 moves every turn. The Dimensional Vault also gets disabled with this, as you can't retrieve items with a Maniac character. You still can deposit items at the end of your run. However, you still get rewarded for playing Maniac Mode, as this further increases your score at the end.

So if you just want a casual quick "Afternoon Stroll" or an hours long "Inhumane Oddysee", this game got you covered. I am returning to it every now and then, since there still is so much to do and to discover for me. Highly recommended, even at full price. If you buy the game and find some enjoyment, please also buy the OHW+ DLC as it enhances the gameplay and content so much more.

88268355.review:
The gameplay is very simple, there's not much of interest in terms of character development, and the constant pressure from the encroaching darkness leaves little time for exploration, even at times when there's actually something to explore.  On top of that, the random world generation sometimes results in dead-ends from which there is no escape and the darkness will inevitably catch up to and kill you.

Despite these problems, the game does have a certain addictive quality to it, tempting you to try to build up wealth and resources over many runs (which you pretty much have to do if you want to win).  Some players may enjoy this kind of gameplay loop, but I prefer succeeding through strategy and/or skill rather than just patience.

A really fun game, potentially hundreds of hours of gameplay that offers different playstyles, alternate endings, secrets, *and* a pleasing amount of difficulty levels to choose from. 

Its also really funny sometimes, and occasionally kinda lewd~
Some of the dialogue made me bust out laughing, other times it was weird and unexpected, either side is offered by pretty much every character you speak to. The cool part is that OWH has massive amounts of replayability everywhere, including in the dialogue between followers. After multiple runs, youll end up with some repeating characters appearing. I thought they were starting to get grate-y, since they have a background story that you go through everytime you recruit them, but they began to suprise me by bringing up things they *completely* left out in the previous runs, things that explained more about themselves or helped you piece together the rest of their story, or just some neat pointless/ funny dialogue; the game's got character.

Getting this game on sale is a pretty sweet deal, what you see in the trailer is pretty much what you would expect to be getting. Also, the devs have been updating the game long after its release, with small changes and fixes here and there; the updates are more common than you would think. 

I used to be in love with this game, its a game for someone with a smaller library. It has plenty to offer for thrifty gamers or for those who have a real niche for games with good old pixel art.

78570836.review:
[h2]Now this is a GOOD game![/h2] 

[b]Very much Roguelike with great pixel art, unlocks and theme. For a sale price of $1 or $2.98 for it and it's massive expansion DLC, it's value you'll seldom find on Steam. If you like roguelikes or tactical fantasy games, BUY IT.[/b]

[i]I bought this game during the Halloween sale because it was only $1..[/i] I've had this wishlisted for years and for some reason never got around to playing it until it dropped on my Nindie Switch. Bought on that console and freaking LOVED it 

though Devs.. 

[b]if you are reading this the fonts on the Switch aren't legible. Really need to increase the text so we can enjoy this game on that system because as it stands its near unplayable. [h2]Please fix![/h2][/b]

Got a little derailed my bad. So yea, I finally bought it on PC after enjoying it on the Switch. I guess the fact that I struggle to read the text on the Switch made me want to try it on PC so I could fully enjoy the game then found it on sale. Rest is history. 

[h2]Gameplay is superb.[/h2]

At first, you might not appreciate the game right away. It feels and looks like something out of RPGMaker. In fact it could be, who knows. There's also a bit of confusion to be had when after making your toon, finding a world to play in. Your first run will mostly likely end terribly but it's at that point you'll start to see the beauty. 

[h2]Getting ranked on each run.[/h2]

Insanely fun and offers a bunch of replay value trying to beat your previous runs and get those 'S' ranks on all the categories. 

[h2]Upgrades. Lots of upgrades.[/h2]

After you die, depending on how you did gives you points to use to unlock new classes, storage space, abilities and more. Gold coins will drop (a separate currency) which you can use to upgrade things in the actual game world itself. 

[h2]Replays.[/h2]

You can save videos of your runs to re-watch later which I thought was super neat. You can also post your stats and replays instantly to Twitter via in-game for those who like to share there stats with the world. 

[h2]Worlds to explore.[/h2]

Every new run you can pick a new world to play in. Some are basic, some advanced and some can be played with other people around the world. Up to you on how you want to die to play. I mean..try to play :)

Artwork both static images and pixel art are above average and look great. The sprites are mostly adorable and pleasant to view. 

[b]However, this game isn't without faults. Let me throw those out.[/b]

1. Resolution is garbage. At default this game is something like 800x600. It's tiny. They allow you to change it up to full screen using configurations outside the game but the problem is, it just stretches the 800x600 to fit. What happens is you have 2 large black rectangles on each side of your screen (dead space) and the game itself is noticeably worse looking. Even then, text and things can be hard to read.. It's 100% worse on the Nintendo Switch though, it's nearly unplayable. 

2. Default controls are bad. Playing with a controller is much much much better than kb+m. 

3.Navigating the menu's is cumbersome, especially while playing. It can be quite confusing those first few runs trying to figure out the menu's and where everything is or re-binding hotkey's. Over time you'll figure it out and it's not terrible but definitely leaves a lot to be desired. 

4. Music while what little there is is serviceable but I do wish there was more as it becomes quite repetitive. After only a couple runs I muted it and turned on Spotify lol

Might be forgetting something but those are my main gripes with it. Overall this game is a solid roguelike and for the price it's a steal if you are into these type of games. I can tell I'll be putting many many hours into this title both on PC and on the go with my Switch. 

[h2]It's charming, hard as nails yet insanely fun and rewarding. Highly recommended![/h2]

78044106.review:
I've only played this for 3 hours and I'm not sure it will hold long term appeal; but this game is definitely worth trying if the Store Page looks interesting.
The game forcing you to constantly move away from the left-hand side of the screen is less of a gameplay factor than I thought from the game summary. You generally have lots of breathing space and just can't grind endlessly in one place. The left-hand side of the screen is more of a factor when you find a building; as you need to reach the building, and get to its door, and do everything inside, and get out before the door drops off the screen. This can be less than enjoyable when buildings aren't always highlighted on your map and the game's randomness can make the door location very inconvenient.

Why I would recommend the game is that it offers quite a bit of progression in improving your starting character; and the game's presentation and design has quite a few commendable ideas. For the price and the 40MB install size, there is a substantial amount of gameplay here!

77088722.review:
Damn-sick game. There are some issues with "learning" - kinda similar to the problems with Binding of Isaac - where there isn't enough tutorials for 'all the questions/concerns you have', but I've heard that this is "part of the package" so to speak and that you should just have faith that everything will be revealed in time as a reward for your hard work~

Music is above-average and fits the backdrop 'fantastically', the art is very intuitive and full of anime/JRPG goodness, and the difficulty scalings seem to go off into the crazy territory leaving me to presume that there's an enormous amount of room for player skill-growth. 

Best of all (probably?) is that, unlike other Roguelikes, if your round is going bad, it'll end at an intuitive point and you'll 100% feel yourself reflecting on your own choices (rather than 'having lacked the potential due to luck' or something); and if your round is going well, you'll find the session's runtime running for much longer than your immersed self will comprehend. Pacing in this game just feels spot-on, and it also leaves you a tonne of room for 'being fastidious' and exploring every nook and cranny compared to the "speed-run"-esque impression of the game. 

I really can't say if this game is a "classic" yet, but I'm giving my hopes up on it for now. At the very least, the charged price for the game is absolutely paying for itself without it being anything more than what I've already briefly experienced. 
(Err, do note: I left my game idly open for a few days, so I've realistically got about 20 hours down in it already - and still I feel I've hardly touched the surface of it~).

A simple rogue-like with a simple premise - Go Right!
The game is heavily dependent on random generation, but, the game can be forgiving at times.  the rate of bad runs vs good runs is about 50/50.  if you have a bad game, just start over and try again.  There are many different classes of characters with different advantages and disadvantages.  There is a vault system that allows you to save some rare items between adventures and a perk system to customize your character for different goals. there are tons of different endings and a rather compelling story which only truly unfolds as you unlock the different epilogues.

Each game can be completed in anywhere from 10 minutes to 4 hours depending on the goal you are trying to achieve.  100% achievements can be acquired within 40hrs or so (with the DLC which is highly recommended).

Fantastic game, liked it so much I bought it again on Steam and sunk another 35+ hours into it. Pretty much everything you could want in this style of game:

* huge variety of items, enemies, areas, and meaningful character/run customization options
* clear graphics, cohesive aesthetic
* excellent music (especially the title music)
* satisfying difficulty curve - you may die a decent amount, but you will generally understand why you died
* fun gimmick - forces you out of "must explore everywhere and collect everything" and keeps the pace moving along
* sensible meta-progression
* biggest challenges feel like you've accomplished something but are within reach
* high replayability due to well-executed roguelike nature and daily runs

Can't recommend more for players who like this style of game, especially at such a low price point.

Interesting mechanical concepts and application are what make this game stand out to me. One Way Heroics is a procedurally generated 2d rpg with roguelike elements. I love that sharing your experience is as simple as sharing a code with your friends, allowing them to play the exact same world as you. I also love the fast paced turn system and how encounters can go from single turn kills and controlled extermination to mosh pits of chaos in so little time. You'll notice I have played this game for almost two-hundred hours as of this review;  I will say that it was worth it.   

While the combat system is not incredibly complex, the different ability choices between the classes and the plethora of equipment available in a given run(more if you decide to grab your +3 sword, etc., etc. from the last adventure) give the game enough replayability to make it as far as I have, and further if you're truly up for a grind and lots of self-inflicted punishment(higher level difficulty runs and punishing character mods that multiply your ending score).

Given that the worlds are procedurally generated based on a given seed, there are basically infinite scenarios available for play.  For forced-scrolling grid-based combat, one could hardly find a better medium.

55593685.review:
One way Heroics is a 2D turn-based scroller with RPG elements where you choose your class, some starting skills and go out to save the world from being consumed by the darkness.

The screen constantly scrolls to the right as the left side being constantly consumed by the darkness and this while you 
fight random monsters, acquire companions and get better equipment from the dungeons and towns while always trying to outrun the darkness.

The different areas  you go through are randomly generated with each playthrough and elements like building placement also change as you enter a new areas during the specific run.

At the end of each playthrough you will get hero points according to your deeds which can be used to unlock additional skills or new game elements like more capacity for the dimensional vault were items collected during gameplay can be stored to be used by the next character in another playthrough.

Each class has a unique approach when being played, for example:
The knight can absorb more damage than any other class, especially if equipped with a shield, and thus can better survive high damage attacks, making him one of the best classes for beginners for figuring out the game mechanics.

Another example is the force user which  is a mage type class, he needs one turn to charge his attack and that requires some planning and careful maneuvering in to a good position before casting a spell. It's a hard class to start since he is pretty weak early in the game but gets better the more you progress.

The companions are also interesting part of the game, they each got their own unique abilities and backstory which can be uncovered by doing specific actions, giving a specific type of food or just traveling.
These will unlock dialogues which will uncover more backstory and even improve their abilities and states.
Each companion, if gained enough affection, will also unlock a special epilogue unique to them and a unique powerful item to be used in the next playthrough.

If you plan on getting this game the expansion is mandatory, I just cannot recommend One Way Heroics without the Plus expansion since its bring necessary improvements to the UI and progression aspects that the base game lacks.
The plus expansion also add castle renovation which add special quests to unlock more classes and endings unique to the expansion.

[h1]+[/h1]
Unique top-down/side-scrolling/turn-based gameplay
Tons of secrets and content
Easy to learn, hard to master

[h1]-[/h1]
Carrying items over is a necessity as opposed to a luxury
Beginner classes are kind of boring

One of the most unique games I've played in a long time. It's randomly generated, side-scrolling, world-traveling style scratches that rogue-like itch in a great way and there's tons of content for you to explore (especially with the Plus dlc). Reminiscent of Dragon Warrior or Pokemon-type adventure games in terms of aesthetic and movement. Lots of secrets to discover and stuff like characters and endings to unlock. Great game to play on the go offline. It'll take a few runs to figure out what's going on and a few more to unlock some more useful perks to make your class-building actually interesting. With lots of avenues to success in the world the game feels well designed and special in ways a lot of other titles fall short of. It's got charm, it's unique, and it's fun fast. Great price point, lots of value, must buy for offline players.

54348275.review:
Do you like the look and sound of a JRPG but not the slow pace of the story and combat? This is the game for you.

I really enjoy rogue-like and rogue-lite games and this is an underrated entry in the genre that I rarely see anyone talking about. It nails the feel of playing an action JRPG such as Ys, but in roguelike form. 

The main concept in One Way Heroics that differentiates it from other rogue-ish games is that instead going down, you always have to go right, and you have to go fast. This keeps the pace up. You are always in the action, always engaged, always being pushed to progress no matter what. There is not a dull moment in any given run, and it's genius.

Important: Buy the DLC. While the base game is good on its own, the extra content in the DLC is a significant add-on and the base game feels naked without it.

53594121.review:
It's been a while since I've played the base game, so this review might contain some bits from the DLC.

First of all, this game is a relatively simple roguelike with a twist: the world is constantly being consumed from the left, forcing the player to continue moving to the right. The base objective for winning is to defeat the Demon Lord, who will generally pop up to fight you after certain amounts of time has elapsed and retreat in a bit if neither is dead. There's a couple of other winning conditions available, but it's definitely a spoiler. The Plus DLC adds some alternate campaigns to fighting the Demon Lord, which increases the winning conditions even more.
There's a simplistic hunger system(energy, but you can't die from not eating, just severely weakened at 0 energy), weight/inventory management, and of course tile-based turn based combat.

On the topic of the DLC, One Way Heroics is like the base game, with OWH+ acting as an expansion pack. OWH on it's own is a pretty completed game, but the DLC adds some balance changes, new events and companions, and a few new playable classes. It also adds a "true" ending to the game.

There's a bit of interactivity in the game with other players, as you progress in a world seed, you can leave brief preset messages as some of your current stats are shown to the other players on a side bar. You cannot interact with any other players as each session takes place in its own instance, but when a player dies, a NPC ghost may show up in the other players' session, and talking to them will drop a copy of an item from the fallen player's inventory on death.

As I mentioned before, the game is fairly simplistic, all action can basically be boiled down to four main points, 1. Attacking, 2. Talking/Interacting with items/NPCs, 3. Movement. 4. Using items. The talking/interacting is incredibly simple, in fact, attacking is the same button as talk. You can't normally attack townspeople if you're in talking range if you aren't already a criminal. That said, your class, item usage, and equipment management can let you play in a couple different ways. Class skills and the classes in general are more diverse in the DLC, and were pretty similar in the base game last I played.
In addition, the game runs very smoothly, turn transitions can happen near instantaneously, which honestly spoiled me on my experience compared to Mystery Chronicles: OWH. The fluidity of the game in the original OWH(+) was just too good.

Another note, for a roguelike, I feel the game is pretty fair. You very, very rarely die random unpreventable deaths if you're properly prepared (like actually bothering to wear decent armor, or not walking around without paying attention). Some progress for unlocks carries over between sessions, and you can even bring along inventory items/equipment into a vault from one run into another upon completion/death, or just for collection purposes. You can even save the game on an adventure, with a second separate save system in place if you need to close the game so you can play it later. That said, I've never saved in the game before, so I'm not too sure how they work.

The game has 4 difficulty levels going from Easy, Normal, Hard, Very Hard. There's also a special modifier called "Maniac Mode", which turns the game into a strictly turnbased game. Without Maniac Mode on, you can reliably get several turns in before an opponent if you have a high enough Agility stat. Easy mode (Walk in the Park) forces you to fight the Demon Lord in a way unlike the other difficulties, as the Demon Lord will NEVER run away on Easy mode, essentially forcing a fight to the death.
There's a hidden epilogue available in the DLC if you manage to get a certain alternate win condition on Easy mode that isn't in the base game.

The music in the game is pretty good, I've had a couple hours on the game with just the main menu theme open. Probably because the OST is freeware, this has allowed the creator to include a wide variety of tracks in the game, with even more in the DLC. I believe there's over a hundred tracks in just the base game. The sound effects are pretty simplistic, nothing too special about them.

The graphics are mostly pixel graphics, with drawn portraits for certain important characters. Everything in game is easily distinguishable at a glance from the graphics. Some people may not feel the drawn portraits are especially pretty and a bit "sketchy", but I think they're quite charming, as are the characters they depict.

With how often the game goes on sale, I would definitely recommend people to pick up the game and give it a shot. Definitely get the DLC if you enjoyed the game, but I wouldn't tell you to grab it without trying the base game itself first, as the additions aren't drastic enough to turn it into an entirely different game. MC:OWH is okay, but I feel like it lacks something the original has.

48851357.review:
It surprised me how much I enjoyed this game. It seemingly looks like a JRPG but isn't one of those. You are moving from left to right beating up enemies and discovering loot for around 1-2 hours until you will meet the endboss. Tactical combat is the focus of this game. Turns take place simultaneously, meaning that whenever you perform an action so does the enemy at the same time. Executing an action will also impel the left side of the screen to move towards the right. 

The screen scrolling mechanism is not a cheap gimmick but actually significant and refreshing. Once you fall out of the screen it will be game over. There is a fair amount of risk assessment involved, do you want to go through that mountain pass and taking the risk being blocked by enemies where the screen will catch up with you? Do you really want to explore that dungeon? You might get stuck in there long enough for the screen to catch up with you. The screen scrolling also prevents you from grinding to high levels by staying in one specific spot and forces you to move forward and using your skills. 

Levels are randomly generated which contributes a lot to the replayablity and music is outstanding. My only gripe with the game is that a lot of content is hidden from plain sight, you'll need at least finish the game once before unlocking rogue-like features like item transfering, character unlocks and minor story-like quests. The DLC is highly recommended since it adds a lot of content to the game. This is one of those games where you need to go in blind with zero expectations and bias.

48082890.review:
This game was a really pleasant surprise for me. 
For only the price of a cup of coffee One Way Heroics is an impressive and full game that kept me coming back for more in a wholesome way. 
Attention to detail is what makes this game shine, its a basic concept explored thoroughly through carefully balanced mechanics that all work in tandem together. When those mechanics click this game becomes more than the sum of its parts, please don't take it at face value like I did.

The story while sparse is again more detailed than it might appear at first. Characters reveal more about who they are as you journey across the land and even those that might seem tropey at first evolve in one way or another. But what is truly brilliant is that this isn't done through heavily scripted cutscenes or lengthy text walls but through a clever mix of:
Dialog that hints at the character's backstory, while allowing the player to fill in the blanks.
Gameplay, this is nuanced and difficult to explain in full so i’ll try and keep this short. 
As you travel many kilometers across the land, constantly dogged by a world spanning darkness, fighting powerful enemies and interacting with townsfolk, companions become a consistent comfort. 
The battle system furthers this with an ingenious though small detail, facing enemies head on will never result in your companion taking damage. But if an enemy attacks at your exposed back or side, they take the hit instead. 
The damage is split 50/50 from the side but from the rear your companion will take the full brunt of any attack. This can imprint a pretty primal message into the player; 
Your companions have your back, they are willing not only to fight at your side but also to die for your sake, they will allow you to use them as a shield. 
I've never seen a feature like that in a game before.

Phew, that was a lengthy paragraph but I think it's a feature worth mentioning in full. 

Gameplay is turn based but by no means slow. 
The game's world is split into hundreds of invisible squares, your character taking up one of these spaces. With any given weapon you can attack in a 3 by 3 circle around you, unlike most rpgs one hit is usually all you need to eliminate an enemy, but depending on the class one-two hits may be all that's needed to end you. 
As you progress enemies will get tougher and friendly npcs more uncommon. This creates an engaging risk and reward dynamic, a dungeon could provide great gear and xp needed for later areas, but with such a tight health bar I found myself either avoiding encounters or tiptoeing through dungeons, making use of corridors or bottlenecks to funnel enemies avoid getting surrounded. Likewise as you go on the stakes continue to rise, with enemies getting tougher and your gear getting damaged. 

That's by no means everything but maybe it will inspire interest :) 
The classes are often different enough to create different playstyles and experiences.

I adore the music, it's reminiscent of older final fantasy titles while maintaining its own identity and substance. 

In conclusion this game is a miniature marvel and well worth your time and money. Compared to most other rpgs it doesn't waste your time and for just over 2 bucks you really can't go wrong, I'd say go for it it full price and definitely look at the dlc - it enhances the base experience in many ways.

46536845.review:
Overall:
Once a demonstation of a tool to create games and what that tool is capable of, this gem of a game has aged quite well. The turn base mechanic coupled with a simple, but creative plot twist made and still makes this game awesome and playable. You should give it a try and if you (really) like it - get the dlc, it's a really great addition to the base game.

It is a rogue like game - so don't expect a huge development over the course of your playthroughs. Though it has a developing story and unlockable elements, unlocked by helping certain npcs, defeating the evil demon king and preventing the everso swallowing darkness.

Into Detail:
Every two steps/actions/turns (except "free actions") you take the darkness moves one space. This way the game gets it's own dynamic and urgency of decision-making. Will you go into that fortress and try to loot it? You may need to crush a wall in time, because the exit will be swallowed by the darkness once you got the chest. Once the darkness reaches you it's instant game over.

There are classes and perks to unlock, some perks will give you a boost, while others can be chosen to increase the difficulty. The DLC let's you expand the starting castle (+ new stuff like 2 classes), which is a nice little twist on unlocking new content - just remember it will only be there every playthrough for a couple of turns before it gets swallowed by darkness. Nothing lasts forever...

The NPCs are quite interesting and have some interesting backstory, though due to the rogue like element those stories are thin - which doenst make them less interesting.

Personal note:
I really appreciate the graphics and I am quite intrigued by the story, the setting - overall the game! This game is one of those games I really play now and then.

Personal note 2:
Poor Dosey... I am so sorry...

44010968.review:
[h1][b]One Way Heroics [/b][/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1471025678
[b]Imagine walking from one end of the earth to the other while a wall of darkness threatens to eat you if you ever stop. So you can't ever fall asleep you just keep walking and eating things to give you energy until you get strong enough to kill some dude.[/b]

[h1][b] Gameplay [/b][/h1]
[b]Simple is sometimes better, but unlike many other streamlined games this one manages to maintain some level of depth.[/b] 

Although it's rather easy to hit things with basic attacks and moving around can be done by all but the most braindead, somehow this game manages to have more depth than many other 'hard' games. This is a kind of game with a gimmick I've never seen before and one that fits immensely well with procedural generation and rogue-lite elements. And although it can be pretty hard from time to time, it's very doable and almost never cheap shots you.

There are a lot of games out there that claim to be hard as a sort of selling point, but more often than not they're just using cheap tactics to kill you off. Darkest dungeon is one of those games where it doesn't respect your time and pushes you through a slog of mud for the sake of extending playtime. Dead cells is another game that does this, but many overlook it due to it's surface level combat and movement mechanics. And while both those games feel great, it's just skin deep. This game is much closer to Xcom levels of tactics where you aren't pigeonholed into certain builds.

One way heroics has a very wide variety of combat tactics and styles ranging from just running up and slapping everything to death to taking everything turn by turn and resorting to throwing your items at enemies just because you can. It also largely benefits players who are more thoughtful about how to approach a situation over those meatheads who rush in and spam buttons. I adore this. Though you can still occassionally just spam attack and win against enemies depening on your gear.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1471022397

And to make things even better there's a lot of stuff to do. It's super odd considering that this game is literally pushing along a path that feels narrow, yet it's also non-linear. See a dungeon? You can go inside it if you want. And you can even bash down the walls. But be careful! The ever looming threat of the wall means if you get stuck inside you might lose! And I must say that I'm very surprised with how aware the game is because every single character gets an ability that stops time for a few turns. Careful use of this ability adds another layer of thought to it all since it could mean the difference between a game over and a victory.

I'm not really sure I think ANYTHING in this game is bad. I suppose the game isn't too careful with monster scaling. I vaguely remember that my very first game I walked out of the castle into volcano lands. A bear then walked up to me and killed me. Frustrating for me, but then I just made a new world and it was grasslands. At that point the game showed me what it could be.

Things to note, there is item durability for weapons and armor so if you don't like those things it could be a non-selling point for ya. There are also shops, foreign lands, class customization, rogue-lite elements (after death progression), scoring, a system for you to build your starter castle(a bit), unlocks galore and you can even change your sprite/portrait if you like! I showed this in the opening .gif of a portrait a friend made and a sprite I made.

[h1][b] Graphics [/b][/h1]
[b]It's pixel art.[/b]

For the most part it's pixel art. There are a few full character portraits, but I honestly rate those kinda meh quality. The art style is nice though for sure. The clouds passing overhead is a nice touch and adds a constrast of something moving to the otherwise motionless land. There could definitely be more too like wavey grass, snow, rain (NEEDS RAIN AND MAYBE THUNDERSTORMS), breezy trees, different types of trees and really a lot more.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1471028358

With that said, even in it's 'basicness' it's still good. Not amazing, but good. I do very much enjoy most of the character portraits especially the C knight. And as I said I like having the ability to do customer sprites/portraits. I almost always play with them changed.

[h1][b] Sound [/b][/h1]
[b]It's rather average.[/b]

The music is a least a tiny bit memorable, but really nothing I'd write home about. The sounds are all very fitting. Slashing for slashing. Thrust for spears and like crashing smash for slamming with axes. Mostly fits. Just not really the big focus of the game though. I do enjoy it enough and listen to it when I play.

[h1][b] Story [/b][/h1]
[b]Strangley enjoyable.[/b] 

I would've liked it if I could have done more with [spoiler] the demon lord[/spoiler] but really there's a lot here that may take you by surprise. Following in line with it's unique approach, the story is unique as well. Unfortunately a lot of it is spoiler heavy so I can't say too much. It's a non-standard story and that's really all I can say. Though I am not going to hype you up about it because it's not extensive. I'm actually very much NOT A FAN of most anime oriented stories and prefer western stories, but I like the art style of anime. With one way heroics the story is more tolerable, albeit still presented in a way that I'm not enthused about. 

There are many endings to the game including one where you don't technically win or lose. They're based on who you pick up for your limited space party. Weirdly enough I didn't experience any of the other character's stories until I beat the game like 3 or 4 times. I didn't even know they existed for a while nor did I know of any of the hidden endings. So here I'll tell you that there are a lot of different endings and there are some characters you can find along the way who also have stories to go with them. Now ya know.

[h1][b] The Company [/b][/h1]
[b]Not much to say.[/b] 

I don't know much about them except that they tried to release I guess a sequel to this game, but it didn't do too well. I'd like to play it A LOT, but I seen the reviews for it and they're disappointing to say the least. Seems odd to try and release a sequel that's so much like the original, but what do I know? Anyway I'm neutral towards them.

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1] 
This is a game for thinkers and explorers. If you like a game with slower turned based pacing and you can tolerate durability, some RNG and a slightly harder than normal difficulty then there's a good chance you'll like this game.

43728916.review:
I highly recommend this game. Its got charm, depth and for its price its an absolute steal.
Best played with the expansion (One Way Heroics Plus).
You can pick both up stupidly cheap on a sale.

This is the sort of game where its just fun to be playing it and you don't really have to achieve anything.
That being said there are still plenty of things to aim for, new classes to unlock, secrets to find and challenges to complete.
Most fun in short bursts, do a run or two then leave it and come back later.

Dying can be frustrating but you are never left feeling that there was no other options or that you exhausted all possibilities. It doesn't really suffer the from the "run doomed because bad RNG" problems that some similar games have, but at harder difficulties it doesn't go easy on you either and you will be running from some fights just to survive.
Some runs will have you near death constantly making use of everything you find on the spot yet getting you further than you have before, where as others may have you overburdened with good stuff trying to decide what to hold onto then blowing it all on a desperate fight with a miniboss and regretting it later.
It's best played at harder difficulties though, the moments where you are trying to minmax every turn just to survive are where the game shines the most.

Even though it is pretty basic looking, it has quality where it counts. 
Attacks, items and spells are well animated, sound impactful and are always satisfying to use. 
Equipment and skills are also well balanced and offer interesting choices and trade offs, for example swords combo more but do less damage than axes which are heavier and have less accuracy but can also chop through walls and chests, spears hit at range and pierce through walls/enemies and while they are not as durable they tend to be lighter.
Heavy armor can be better defensively but may also slow you down and the weight reduces precious inventory space compared with light armor which may also offer evasion, better spell defense or extra bow range etc.
Classes have variation within themselves and can be played differently depending on what perks you choose, equipment you find, skills you pick up, companions you meet etc.
Take the Hunter for example, primarily a ranged character who uses bows. You can go for the classic glass cannon who uses the range attacks to kill stuff before it reaches you but will die quickly in a melee, you can make a more durable and agile spear/shield user who uses combo hits with hit and run tactics or you can mix it up wielding a heavy axe in one hand and throwing arrows and items with the other, weakening enemies before they reach you then finishing them off with a big axe hit while using your speed to make sure you don't get flanked. You can even try some more experimental stuff like focusing on Vitality so that you regenerate more life while you are kiting which lets you save precious healing items for when you really need them. You may choose to focus on one thing and end up doing something else just because thats what this run gave you and discover a better build as a result.

Its one of the better "rogue" style games and if that's what your looking for you can't really go wrong with this.

43279030.review:
A simple turn-based roguelike game on the surface but underneath these cute SNES-era graphics lies a somewhat vicious little beast with a splendid gimmick. See the world is ending and the end comes literally from the west. The screen moves towards right and you should too, since if the darkness consumes you... well you will die of course. This feature makes you prioritise where to move, which buildings to enter (since you can get caught in them if you're not careful), when to fight enemies or if it's better to just run away. 

And it works. Even though the game is turn-based and you can take all the time in the world to decide how to approach the different situations you just can't do everything and this actually makes the gaming experience lighter than your typical old-school roguelike games. One Way Heroics is closer to rogue-like than rogue-lite but it truly bends the boundaries here and I hope it gives fresh ideas to other devs aswell.

During you first couple of hours the plot might feel vague and the gameplay a bit shallow but this is a game which rewards many tries and many playthroughs, and opens up bit by bit to keep some surprises in its sleeves. One Way Heroics is a also a great game for shorter bursts since one playthrough doesn't take too long and as mentioned earlier the game kinda pushes you forward.

Pros.
- Pretty if you like pixel art and old FF's 
- "Short" playthroughs (at least compared to other roguelikes)
- The world ending gimmick
- Quite easy to learn even though it uses many buttons (I suggest using keyboard even though pads are working too)
- "Casual" introduction to roguelike genre

Cons.
- Doesn't really take a hold on you in the beginning (but it keeps growing in you)
- Could use more "everything" meaning items, enemies, events and whatnot. 
- UI - User interface is a bit all over the place (you'll get used to it)
- There isn't a whole lot of story here.

Great game, short and simple. 

You go one turn at a time through the world being chased by the end of the screen (the darkness). Each attack or action moves the end of the screen closer so you have to make good use of your turns, especially if you want to talk to NPCs in buildings and still get out of the building before the darkness gets you. 

In 'rogue-like' fashion you will have good runs and you will have bad runs, even on easy mode. Each run nets you coins and points that you can spend to make things easier. You unlock new classes, new skills, wings on the castle to give you things and storage space for items you want to take on the next attempt. 

The DLC is definitely worth it. 


Since I play it in a small window I like to load up a youtube video and listen to it while I play, great time waster.

42046998.review:
This is most certaintly my 3rd favorite indie game, and one of my favorite games period.

Pros:
> Great SpriteArt
> Large amount of content (i've done some much, but still havent gotten certain endings and beat the campain with a few classes)
> Every class Feels different, and has disticnt Strength's and weaknesses
> Huge rewards for doing challenge runs (weaker charecter's, harder difficulties, ect)
> Its combat system is well suited for both Slow and methodical or Quick and furious gameplay styles
> A simple but effective inventory system
> Hero points which are earned at the end of a run (death or victory) can be used a a multitude of things, most of which are very useful,
> And a simple but deep equipment/enchantment (for lack of a better word) system
> Charming cast of loveable recuitable companions
> the DLC OWH+ is more Akin to a expansion if anything. It adds three new classes, a ton new items and gear, a ton of new thing involving world generation, and a massive amount of story content.

Cons:
> While it has many rouglike systems and built in a rougelike manner. Its much more like a SRPG, especially since you can save your run in numerous ways
> Riding on that if you choose you can sacrifice said save to throw some of your current items into "the dimensional vault" to take for a future run (at the cost of hero points in the end) making the game infintely easier (Mine is currently full of a ton of late game/unique items and gear)
> Hero points become completely useless once you buy all that you can buy
> Some classes are desprately weaker then others (im looking at you pirate)
> There really isnt a plot, granted the are many endings but they're all basically after the storm for you and your companions (though their is a true ending, and a "truer ending?" which are both really nice)
> Due to being randomly generated enemy encounters can sometime come out of nowhere and can feel unfair
> the Blessing and Curse system is unbalenced and Curses are MUCH more dangerous then Blessings are useful.

Overally, while it can sometimes be annoying and even unfair it still an amazing game that you can easily get many hours out of. I would Strongly reccomend this to anyone who enjoy's JRPGs and SRPGs.

41985869.review:
One Way Heroics does a lot of things right and it becomes a wonderful fantasy/rogue-like experience. 

You have no fancy story, complicated plot, etc. It's fairly simple; the land is being consumed by darkness, and you must run away from it until you find the evil Demon Lord and slay him. Now there is more beyond that but let's not get into spoilers. That's all you need to know to start off. Music is fantastic and sets the tone, while the sound effects give everything weight. The graphics meanwhile evoke a 16-bit feel to them, while at the same time not feeling completely retro.

But like a lot of games, what you mainly come here for is the gameplay. Staring off with the base two classes, you can unlock five more. Each class plays differently, from the defensive oriented Knight, to the powerful Pirate, the magic of the Force User, etc. Each time you can name the hero, choose a gender, and choose multiple starting perks that you can unlock as you play, most of which are stat bonuses and others give bonuses to kills or even add an animal companiion.

In addition to all of this, you never truly wind up playing the same map twice unless you want to. Essentially any comination of letters and numbers, even pure gibberish, can result in maps. There are ones set up for daily challenges, specific ones people have found for achievements, or you can just make up your own. I've explored areas named after my wife Susan, and one named after the classic film "Aliens". Note that nothing thematically changes, but its just cool that you can put in whatever and get a unique area. 

When you complete a map, either by dying or winning, you get a ranking based on how well you did, and get "Hero Points" for your efforts. These can be used to unlock classes, additional perks, expand your storage to hold more items over between runs, and more. Those of us obsessed with unlocking everything will have a field day.

Oh yes, and there are multiple difficuly settings. So if you find its getting too easy then crank it up. Oh and once you "beat" the game, you're not really done since there are multiple endings, and you find there are multiple ways to succeed. I won't say anymore; go find out yourself, trust me. And get the expansion while you are at it because its more of teh same and that is always good.

Well, from here, only way to go. The "add to cart" button. Have fun!
