36981478.review:
OWH (and the accompanying content in +) is a bit of a sexed up turn based RPG that features randomized gameplay in a variety of fashions.

Games can be quick, moderately long, or take quite a bit of time - regardless of whether or not you die in the process.  If you do though, starting back up in the same world or a new one is pretty easy and rewarding.  I'm reluctant to call it a rogue-like since it really isn't like rogue, and beyond that, these days who's actually played rogue?

Music is pretty solid, and the art style is fine/cute.  Never had a problem with any of the translation in game.

Anyway, the usual stuff.  A smattering of different classes, equipment, enemies, terrain/environments.  The big thing that sets OWH apart is that the game features a crawling 'darkness' that is sweeping across the land - from the left side of the screen to the right.  Since the game is turn based it only moves when you move, and depending on some settings, the speed can be mixed up.  Think of it as playing 'The Neverending Story' with The Nothing creeping up on your heels... if you know the movie anyway.  Darkness catches you - you die.  Makes for some interesting gameplay because you have to prioritize your actions, fight monsters to level up, go digging for loot, all while trying to keep pace and stay ahead of the darkness.  One major positive for me is that the game tends to 'play fair' with a lot of items and status effects.  It doesn't fall into the "but that character is a boss/powerful!  X is useless!" kind of stuff.

Really easy game to sink quite a bit of time into, and it's rewarding as well.  While each individual character will either succeed at their quest or die trying, there are elements in the game that allow you to carry items forward to new characters, or to progress in different ways; unlocking other classes, starting options, etc.

Best of all?  It's a really cheap title, so it oozes value for money.  If it doesn't wind up being your jam, I suppose you could always refund it, but you won't need to get that much playtime out of it to justify the purchase anyway.


For the negatives:
- It is a highly repetitious game, so if you're not into that, this game is definitely not for you.
- Even after playing the game a lot to figure/find out all the story elements, it's nothing to write home about.
- The random nature begets replayability, but the way this is fashion can result in you getting totally and completely unfairly screwed.  Doesn't happen that often, but something to be wary of.
- No full screen/widescreen if that bothers you.

All in all, this one is a keeper for me.  I still come back and play games of it from time to time because it's really easy to just crack one off, and it still manages to be fun.

36686085.review:
It's a beautiful, simple game. Greatly recommend it. Here's a bit of a breakdown:

*Graphics: It's your standard basic NES/SNES overworld view with some portraits that arent great but are good enough. Portraits seem to be the extent of the artwork. It's not meant to be beautiful, but it doesnt really take much away from the game itself. 
*Music: It's fantastic and it's worth the time looking for it and downloading it (don't worry, it's free, hence it couldnt be packaged into a DLC, which I would've gladly spent money on). No, really. The music is beautiful and outstanding, reminescing of SNES era. Especially the game recap/clear data tune and the loading screen. 
*Battle system: Simple hack and keep moving. Simple item usage. Simple magic using if you can get to it. A bit bothersome to get to the menus to cast magic or skills, but hack slash is a click away. 
*Gameplay: Controls are very easy, mechanics are simple, objective is clear from the get-go. Menus are a bit cumbersome as mentioned previously. Other than that, it has some neat mechanics like the dimension vault where you can store some valuables to use at your next rebirth. Perks are nice to have, and all classes have a plus and minus, they feel fairly balanced. I can axe walls with my mage, or cast fire with my pirate. It's a joy to play. 
Difficulty: Up to you. It has several modes you can play, and though I've only been playing on the Easy mode, I haven't found it too bad. I still die if I'm not careful, but not like I am struggling to survive... except when all of my weapons break at the 375km mark and the evil lord is about to show up. Without the dimensional vault, it can be slightly challenging, but MUCH easier if you do use it to store valuable weapons and equipment. 
*Story(?): Well, it's very simple really. Run from the darkness before it gets you. I've read the more you play the more you get to know what's going on (what's the darkness? Why are you the hero? Who's the evil lord? Why at 402km?). I'm not there yet, but it doesnt bother me not having 200 tomes of history shoved down my throat as I am just trying to get by. And get by you must, or darkness will get you. 
*Replayability: I havent beat every single aspect, but I aint even mad when I do die because I wanted that treasure and my weapon breaks in the middle of a dungeon and darkness gets me. Each class is a pleasure to play with (last being hunters... not sure why, I just cant get along with them). Each try is different, maps, treasures, weapons.

All in all, best cheapest game I've ever bought. Would purchase at full price for sure.

PS: I haven't played the Plus version, so this is based on the basic version.

36448952.review:
Back in the heady NES era, auto-scrolling levels always seemed to cause people the most stress. In a game like Mario or Castlevania where you normally get to explore or measure your movements, scrolling forces you to think on your feet and act under duress. As tends to happen in this eclectic genre, someone took that concept and applied it to the traditional roguelike formula. But rather than simply turn a stressful game design into a pressure-cooker, One Way Heroics expands on every aspect to produce something unique, engaging, and addictive.

The Land of Generic Fantasy is in peril, and the evil Demon Lord is to blame. For any other game this would get an eyeroll from me but here the drama plays out over dimensions, not continents. Each world is threatened by an inexorable wall of darkness that moves ever rightward, consuming all in its path. Only by defeating the Demon Lord  can the darkness be stopped, at least in that particular dimension. With little time to prepare, you must scour the land for equipment and allies before running afoul of your nemesis in a climactic final encounter.

Don’t let the ceaseless march of oblivion put you off, because this is a traditional roguelike at heart and that means everything is turn-based. You can sit there as long as you want, staring at the unmoving void or frozen enemies, all waiting for you to take your damn turn so they can get back to terrorizing the land. That time will be invaluable for planning your moves, especially if you get cornered in a dungeon being consumed by the darkness or end up stuck behind a mountain range. It’ll also give you time to use your special abilities or consumables you’re inevitably going to hoard your first few runs.

Once you get a feel for the game, staying several steps ahead of the murderwall will be of little concern to you. Instead, you’re going to have to come to grips with the off-beat progression system this game has. If you’re coming off other traditional roguelikes you may be expecting a fair spread of weapons, armors, and consumables spread across the land for you. On good days that’ll be the case but One Way Heroics has no qualms with denying you any of those, even simple foodstuffs necessary to keep your heroic avatar chugging along. New gear is extremely sparse, food items need to be bought if you hope to keep a reserve of them, and enemies rarely drop anything besides some modest coin. Even treasure chests hidden away in dungeons or lakes must be bashed or lockpicked open, and so are worthless without a special skill or plenty of time to get through their unexpected defenses.

The game’s uneven power curve will keep this from appearing much of a problem for awhile, but soon enough you’ll run across a minotaur or a golem or just a really beefy bandit who explodes you in a hit or two. I’m sure your first few deaths will be quite sudden, and the game is nice enough to advise you post-mortem about how to improve your chances. You’ve got some powerful innate abilities to overcome tough monsters and tight spots with the darkness, and you’ll need to use them freely to get through the sudden difficulty spikes. The bright side of the difficulty curve is that it’s still easy to learn and overcome, and once you start sticking it to the Demon Lord the real fun can begin.

One Way Heroics does more than stick a pursuer onto the roguelike formula. The dimensions your adventures play out in aren’t just called that for kicks, they can have wildly different topography, unique landmarks and treasures, or powerful house rules like no leveling up or no item drops. Every time you start a game you can pick a new random dimension, a specified dimension, a dimension you failed to conquer before, or one of three daily challenge dimensions featuring those wild house rules. And this is on top of the numerous character classes and unlockable perks which can start you off with handy stat boosts, extra skills, or even a pet. Plus there’s the dimensional vault which lets you carry over helpful items from one world to the next.

It’s the simple fun of running riot over a fantasy world in short sessions, mixed with an expansive backend full of unlocks and game modes, that makes One Way Heroics special. That key one-more-round appeal is here in full force, taunting you to try again every time you get crushed by a skeleton or devoured by the darkness. There’s something to be said for the unique presentation as well, a veritable circus design of windows, text panels, indicators, and progress bars. It can be daunting and downright ugly at first, but after awhile even that starts to feel comfortable and familiar.

The graphics are certainly not a strong point of the game, featuring basic RPG tiles, tiny sprites, and a disappointingly bland palette. Nor is the sound design of much note, though it succeeds in capturing that JRPG upbeat heroism as you travel from fields to deserts to tundra. But it fortunately lives in a genre dominated by ASCII art and silent combat, and besides none of this stops the game from just being flat-out fun. One Way Heroics starts out with a bold gimmick and builds it into a vast and entertaining experience, one that gets deep hooks into you once you learn how it all works.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish]curation page[/url]!

36332681.review:
This game is one of those under-stated little gems on Steam. The premise is simple: move to the right else you will fall prey to an encroaching "Darkness", find loot, wreck face. It is turn-based, where each move and action -- such as equipping a different weapon, using an item, activating a skill, or attacking -- takes one turn, during which the Darkness also moves to the right and monsters are free to move and take action too. Explore the land and vanguish enemies there, but watch out for cute animals! Explore dungeons and vanguish the tougher enemies there, then break the treasure chests for loot, but make sure there is a way out or else you will be trapped against a wall by the Darkness (or perhaps you can break the wall...?)!

Like all rogue-likes, each run is different and death is permanent. Whether you win or lose, you earn hero points which can be spent unlocking new classes and perks, or expanding your "Dimensional Vault" -- in which you can store one item from each run to use in future. There are several difficulties, and you can further challenge yourself by assigning a whacky loadout of perks (or none!) at the beginning of a run. You can even play with others in the same "dimension" (i.e., seed-generated world).

Not gonna lie: the UI takes some getting used to, and it can be really frustrating losing in such a (remedially!) simple-seeming game, at first. But then you become comfortable with the UI, and realize that although the game itself is simple to learn, there is a lot of room for polish and finesse in your gameplay. Accumulating these small advantages and converting them into a win is very satisfying. In addition, the game itself, though challenging, is [i]relaxing[/i] to play, probably due to its turn-based nature and excellent sound track.

Watch some let's play videos. If you're on the fence, wait for a sale (it typically goes on for a couple bucks). There is a lot to discover and appreciate in this game, which unfolds over time. You will surely get your money's worth if you give it a chance!

34750561.review:
It's kind of hard to describe exactly what this game is, but I freaking love it! Essentially a rouge-like, but very unique, It's an action RPG with very lite turn-based elements. The whole goal is to keep moving right as the entire world is engulfed by this black wall of death. Fighting monsters along the way, leveling up, finding new gear, and eventually battling the demon lord.

You start each run by picking a character class and up to 3 starting skills. You then get to choose from a list of worlds to join. Some are harder or offer different challanges, you can join up with other players or even use the random seed generator. Playing the game at first might seem weird, but it is fun. The game and enemies don't move until you move, attack, or use an item. Although, I still consider this an action RPG because of how fluent you can move, it almost does have a real-time feel to it. It seems like the whole turn-based element is only there because it has an in-depth system with skills and inventory management. It actually makes the game more interesting because you can play it at your own pace. 

Like mentioned, every time you move so does the black fog destroying everything in it's path, forcing you to always move right. This adds a lot of strategy. Knowing when to fight monsters or maneuvering around obstacles and terrain to pick up items, all while managing a hunger meter and conserving energy. Along the way you'll encounter several NPC's. Being able to buy, recruit, identify items, or save your game among other things, but even they are not safe from the death mist. Leveling up is simple and automatic to specific character class, but you are given opportunites to trade stats at certain points. You can also upgrade weapons and armor, and use various scrolls, abilties, and a wide array of items. After a certain distance traveled you will face the demon lord. Prioratizing a well built character is key to survival, and when playing on harder difficulties there is no telling when the boss will show up.

When you win or die you will be rated based on your performance with a quick recap of your entire playthrough. You get points to spend on more skills and characters. You also get a vault to store some of your best items to help better your next run. The vault is universal for every playthrough, but taking an item out is only for that specific run. This is a good way to level up weapons and armor by playing multiple times, as long as you don't allow the durability to break. Another cool thing after winning, is you can see other players stats and progress that also beat the same world, even when using a random level seed.

What I originally considered a hidden gem has turned into one of my favorite rouge-like ARPG's. The game even has a deluxe dlc which adds tons more content, similar to how much Binding of Issac Rebirth added. Even though it has a very Japanese feel to it with the story, the gameplay is superb. I highly recommend this game if you're looking for something new and unique.

It is sad to see that people cannot appreciate the beautiful and very well designed simplicity of this game.  Heck, I'd pay just for the music!  I started playing this years ago, and still enjoy playing it to this day.  The basic premise is that your character is fleeing a world consuming darkness and looking for a way to stop said darkness.  This is hard to learn at first.  As you progress, the story continues to deepen with each milestone until you uncover a complex and engrossing plot.  Eventually when the player has mastered the movement and the rhythm of the game, then the real interesting parts start.  Classes unlock, you learn how to survive with different classes and play styles.

You will die.  You will die often.  You will die stupidly, wondering why you did something that dumb.  You will learn, and then you will start to win. Many hours later you'll probably look at the clock and wonder where your day just went.

Do yourself a great favor and get the plus version of this game.  Give it some time and love, and before long, you'll have something that you can turn to for a quick round, or for a day of amusement and rewarding activity...  And don't forget to talk to Iris before the first day, or she'll totally sulk.

33261316.review:
Saw some summer sale dorks posting lousy, unfair reviews on this and had to write a counter. 

It's a roguelike with a very solid premise in that you have to run away from a constantly moving darkness on the left side of the screen. If you are consumed by the darkness your run immediately ends, resulting in a forced sidescroller type game. It's actually quite intuitive, and the game teaches you to adapt very quickly. Expect to fail a lot in the beginning.

The system is subtlely brilliant in that it requires you to play in a number of different ways. Even if you make mistakes or a bad situation RNGs itself upon you, you can use your resources to play your way out. And if you do make a mistake that is actually fatal, it will definitely feel deserved. "Bad luck" is more often the result of ill preparation and poor management.

To make the game more interesting, there are various objectives and classes to choose from that vary the play experience. Additionally, you can choose from different 'perks' in order to build your character how you choose, or to even make the game more difficult for yourself. 

Each of the ally NPCs in the game are charming to look at and have their own unique personalities and dialogue. I won't spoil any of it, but the bonding process and backstory of the game that slowly comes to light through them is a delightful experience that adds a lot of color to the game. The art is handdrawn from the looks of it, and is pretty refreshing to be honest. Sprites are mostly what you'd see in RPG maker games, seeing as how the original engine is based off of Wolf.

I won't say it's impossible to get random'd (darn teleport pills), but the decision making in the long run is what makes the experience. If you want a challenge, try tougher win conditions on harder difficulties! There are many ways to customize your run, so you can adjust the edge as much as you like.


The least satisfying thing about the game is probably the content. This is remedied quite a bit with the Plus Edition DLC, which I STRONGLY recommend for the sake of balance and expansion. If you are playing vanilla and you don't think it's enough, I definitely think Plus is the way the game is meant to be played. Of course, this means shilling out more $$$ for a more complete game. However, purchasing Plus not only supports the localization, but the original developer of the game as well.


This is a really quick RPG roguelike experience with an easy to understand system, but it comes with a surprising amount of depth that's fun to explore. Daily worlds make completionist goals much easier, and adds a bit of fun to the game by comparing your runs with other participants in Online mode. 

At the very least, I would recommend giving this indie classic a fair try. If you can get your hands on Plus, the game is priceless.

Combining old school rpg visuals and feel with a rouge like creates One Way Heroics, a very fun and distinct game in the Rogue like genre.   

You pick a character, level up, and traverse the map one turn at a time (most of the time very very fast turns) as you try to reach the end and beat the dark lord.  With several classess, weapons, and ways to play, the game manages to have a lot of variety.  In addition, the out of game level up system lets you become stronger with every game you play and is a great addition.

The only warning here is Rogue like.  This game is first and foremost a rogue like.  If you like rogue likes you are golden.  If you like old timey RPGs but hate rogue likes it wont matter; you won't like this game.

With all that said, its a very fun game that can be played in long goes or short bursts.  There really isnt anything here not to like if you are a fan of the genre.

7/10

31408226.review:
The game costs $3.50 cents and there is enough replayability for several hundred hours. You do the math. 

Think about it like this, a movie ticket costs roughly 8-10 dollars, we'll say 8. Movies range anywhere from 1.5 hrs to 3.5 hrs. So 8 dollars gets you (for the sake of argument I'll use the higher number) 3.5hrs of entertainment. This game is less than a large coffee at Starbucks, only with this you will get at least 20 hrs of fun out of it. 

What makes this game so good is the way it is set up. You are constantly walking to the right to avoid a black cloud of smoke that kills on contact. The story is randomly generated each time, as are the zones. Also, this is a roguelike, so once you die, you die forever, however there are things you can save such as new classes, etc. 

The music is excellent, and the entertainment value is incredibly high. If you've ever played Tome of Maj'Eyal, and enjoyed it, this is basically the same game, only better in absolutely every way.

Highly reccommend. Worst case scenario, if you don't like it, you can always return it as long as there are less than 2 hrs played and it's been less than 2 weeks. With that said, even if you only played for 2 hours, you'd still be getting a lot more than your moneys worth.

30111893.review: One Way Heroics is a rougelike RPG with a twist.  All the normal conventions of an RPG are present--stats, classes, gold, weapons, random monsters, chests full of loot, towns, a sprawling overworld--as well as the start-from-scratch different-every-time staples of a rougelike.  The catch is no backtracking, and no dilly-dallying: the left edge of the screen is a mass of darkness consuming the world, and is constantly moving right, so the player must move even faster while still spending enough time to level up and find better supplies for whatever dangers lie ahead.  The game is pretty entertaining in its own right WITHOUT the one-way gimmick, as it boils down an entire RPG fantasy adventure into a bite-sized 30 minutes, with victory unlocking more options to use for the next run.  It does nothing particularly new, but takes a ton of old ideas and simplifies them for a fun little game that's easy to play and replay.

29736418.review:
8/10: The encroaching Darkness is the perfect justification for creating this combination of side-scrolling runner and fantasy role playing game. Fight monsters, defeat the Demon Lord, and seek out a way to avert the destruction of the entire dimension!

The dimensions are randomly generated, but the pieces get pretty familiar after a few playthroughs. Even so, there are things that only show up during later playthroughs, and while the story is simple, unraveling the connections between characters and the reason there's a terrible Darkness swallowing up the land behind you is still pretty satisfying. 

There's several characters you can only ally with using Buddy Tablets, and there's a good variety of classes to try out from Hero to Pirate, though the Adventurer's ability to easily traverse mountains and water and identify items is really helpful when the terrain gets especially bad. The Dimensional Vault lets you transfer your favorite items so you can retrieve a few at the start of future playthroughs, which is a good way to maintain a sense of advancement when you have to regain levels every time.

Overall, a fun take on the randomized dungeon RPG.

Walk in a straight line, attack what-ever you want, die. Wash, rinse repeat. That is how the general gist of this game progresses. There isn't a whole lot of depth to the game, there aren't many weapons, aren't many variations of enemies, no characters you really connect with, the map areas are general generic type fanatasy locales, and no real story line (other than to stop The Darkness) which is stated in the opening 3 seconds of the game. However this game has something going for it... charm.

If that sounds silly just run with it for a moment. There is very little to do, or really unlock that can't be done easily. Unlike the game that drew me to this (Faster Than Light) you can unlock everything in nearly 5 hours, the remainder of the time will be playing with these unlocks. However the goofy commentary from the few NPC's you do find are enough to distract momentarily from the humdrum of walking to your right. That is where this game gets its charm from. The constant breaks in the basic mechanics of the game for a fun, light hearted gab between pixelated characters.

Finding all the secret endings and characters endings will be what make you come back to this. The small morsels of charm that you get are what will make you enjoy coming back to it. However, don't expect to be able to play this for long periods of time. I found that the game is best when played a few run throughs at a time. Any longer than that and the charm kinda wears off and the simplistic nature of the game robs from its potential.

Additional peripheries were pretty decent as well. The music is fun to listen to but after prolonged time periods begins to grate at your ears. The graphics are simple enough and give it a classic RPG feel that allows me to relive the days of early Final Fantasy's. Mechanics are simple and will be picked up with one minute of playing.

Feeling in a good mood today so let's give this game an eeked out 7/10

28060698.review:
One Way Heroics is a surprisingly good roguelike.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward: whenever you move, every monster on the map moves as well. You attack monster by running into them, and your stats determine how much damage you do, and how much damage they do to you.

This is pretty standard for a roguelike, but One Way adds in a twist: every time you move, the screen moves a little to the right. If you get caught on the left edge of the screen, you die, so you always need to keep moving forward. Not only this add to the difficulty, it also ensures that every run moves at a good pace: there's no time to loot or backtrack when everything in the world is disappearing on the left side of the screen.

One Way Heroics uses permadeath, so if you die, it’s game over. Fortunately, a successful run in the default mode only takes about 20 minutes to complete, so even if you die right at the end, you (usually) don't feel like you've lost a lot of time. You also have the option to keep a few pieces of equipment from previous runs, so if you die right after finding a great piece of equipment, you can carry it over to the next game. The difficulty is also balanced very well. I was able to beat the game after only two or three attempts at the easiest difficulty, but there are several difficulty levels above that, with each one being significantly harder than the last.

Overall, One Way Heroics is a solid game. The different difficulty levels offer challenges to players of all skill levels, and the randomly generated worlds keep every run feeling fresh. I’d recommend this game to fans of roguelikes and roguelites at any price, but especially if you can grab it on sale.

28042188.review: If you want an awesome RPG and have broken your ability to go left... the is the game for you.

28029126.review:
[b]Quick note: Be sure to get the One Way Heroics Plus expansion. It's the only way the original creator gets money. More details near the end of the review.[/b]

For something that seems like it'd be a small, simple little game, One Way Heroics has a [u]lot[/u] of staying power, especially for its low price. After 100 hours of playtime, I'm still undertaking new challenges, discovering new things, and polishing my survival skills. There's also quite a bit more story than you'd expect from the game's description; each recruitable party member has their own backstory they'll slowly share as you progress through a run with them, and each has their own unique ending (and a few have more than one). As you do more things and undertake harder runs, you'll also learn more about the world, such as the true nature of the Darkness enveloping everything, and even how it affects the land after it has done so. Resultingly, there's even more endings based on how you go about stopping the Darkness, and generally, the more difficult of a run you complete, the better the endings you get tend to be, ranging from "We stopped the Darkness... but at what cost, and what's really going on?" up to [spoiler]effectively becoming a demigod with the power to truely change the fate of the world and its inhabitants[/spoiler].

It can be fairly hard to "win" a run early on, though it won't be long before you've polished your skills and learned enough tricks that the Demon Lord isn't terribly hard to defeat. If you're having trouble, I've found that the easiest difficulty isn't always the easiest place to get your first victory, as unlike other difficulties, you can't just run from the Demon Lord if things aren't going well. Unlocking more perks and classes also helps a lot, and one of the easiest builds is available early on. (If you feel you need the help, it's: [spoiler]Grab a ton of Pro-Wrestler on the Swordsmaster, and punch everything to death.[/spoiler])

The One Way Heroics Plus DLC is along the lines of an expansion pack; adding more classes, perks, party memebers, items, more challenging runs, and essentially just more of everything, like any good expansion pack should. As stated earlier, it's also the only time the game's creator earns money from the game, as the Japanese version of the base game is actually free, and the price for it on Steam only exists to pay the translators (who have done a very fine job, by the way. I've yet to find any issues in the game's translation). Eventually, when the game became really popular, the creator added the paid One Way Heroics expanion, both to update the game and to have a way to earn money off his creation. So I strongly recommend buying the OWH+ DLC, even if you haven't played before. Even with the added cost, the game's still an incredible value; almost criminally so when it's on sale.

All in all, the game is a hidden gem that's far better than the price point would suggest. As cheap as it is, there's no go reason not to grab it, and makes a great choice for using that last bit of cash in your Steam Wallet, or funds you've gotten from selling trading cards from other games.

There are several win-state goals in the game, each of which with varying difficulty. In other words, just because you've defeated the Dark Lord doesn't mean you've finished the game. There is more to the game than simply defeating the Dark Lord. 

With the different classes with different play styles, the potential allies that you can recruit, the different worlds and encounters, there are many unique adventures to be had in your quest to save the world. The amount of content and hours of gameplay you will get out of this is well worth the very cheap price of this game. 27319166.review:
[b]TL;DR:[/b]
[list]
[*]Fluid turn-based rogue-like/lite gameplay with an advancing wall of doom (the darkness) - maniac mode removes a lot of the rogue-lite factors like the vault for those that dislike how easy they can make the game.
[*]Fairly easy to get into and enjoy but deep enough to take a while to master.
[*]Lots of unique classes and numerous settings that impact difficulty to suit almost anyone.
[*]Single-player with optional (can be disabled) indirect online interaction with other players.
[*]Good variety of music, almost all available online for free
[*]Immense value for money with it's frequent significant sales and very high replay-ability with seed-based procedural generation and numerous other options that impact a run as well - worth it even when not on sale.
[*]The DLC also adds a significant amount of additional content including classes, items, special campaigns and several helpful UI improvements.
[/list]

Disclaimer: some parts described below may only be available with the DLC, but most of this is available in the base game as well.

[b]Content overview:[/b]
OWH/OWH+ is a Rogue-like/lite (depending on whether you enable maniac mode or not - which disables access to a lot of the rogue-lite elements in a run such as the vault, as well as other beneficial features like the goddess statues) with RPG elements made in the Wolf RPG editor, which is also made by the developer of the game.

There's numerous difficulty settings with a combination of base difficulty level, maniac mode on/off, numerous perk slot options and classes of varying difficulties - some intentionally easy to succeed with and others intentionally hard to succeed with and a varied mix of playstyles. Force users generally have to prepare a few turns in advance to avoid taking unnecessary but have unmatched power and can annihilate most targets in a single hit, heroes have little difficulty charging straight in head 1st as long as they don't get surrounded and pirates tear through most walls with ease and can swim through lakes effortlessly, making their own paths. You'll have to play a bit to unlock them all, but sooner or later you'll probably settle on a favourite - for me it'd be the force user. But I've played them all a fair bit.

There's also numerous endings and rewards depending on how you complete each run and who as. Maps are procedurally generated based on a seed and there is a variety of unique classes to play and companions to find to keep each run feeling different for quite a long time.

Controls are re-mappable and parts of the UI can be re-positioned too, among other gameplay control behaviour settings under options on the main menu. Partial mod support allowing replacement of class-specific images to whatever you want.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]

Gameplay is turn-based but fluid (e.g. if you hold right you'll just keep running with the turns merging together) with an advancing wall of doom (the darkness) from the left side of the screen. The goal per run is simple - defeat a boss such as the demon lord when it turns up or reach the end of the dimension.

This fluid turn based nature means you can rush along avoiding enemies and then suddenly take it slow when they get close enough to be a threat to minimise the damage you take by ensuring you get the 1st hit...or if you're playing the hero class, probably just continue charging straight into them in most cases!
If it's too slow for you, there's even an acceleration key to speed up animations and make turns move even faster.

The advancing darkness will speed up to keep a maximum distance if you push against the right side of the screen and will just as happily kill your enemies (and friendly NPCs/following allies) as it will you - even the demon lord will retreat from it!

Friendly NPCs will turn on you if you commit crimes (primarily murder, but some will hunt you down for killing endangered animals too) in front of them and if you aren't charismatic enough to offset your bounty then future NPCs that are normally friendly will attack on sight too.

Each individual run can be short or long depending on what you aim for but there are save options so that you can quit and come back later when necessary as well so it can played whenever without needing to set aside a minimum amount of time.

The game is primarily single-player, but there is optional (can be disabled in the menu) online community interaction in the form of ghosts (when other players die in that dimension one of their items will be available via their ghost) and an event log for the current dimension showing where everyone is, including some manual interaction options if desired - this works with all seeds but there's a set of campaign seeds that change on a regular basis as part of the online features as well.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
Well, see the screenshots/video on the store page - there's not much to say other than that. There's nothing impressive here, but they're certainly not bad either.

[b]Music:[/b]
Plenty of good tracks with quite a variety too, changing with the different areas mostly - they're all available for free online, but they're spread out quite a bit. One of the optional castle characters in the DLC allows you to pick a track for the 1st area of each game.

[b]OWH+ DLC:[/b]
The OWH+ DLC adds:[list]
[*]3 new classes - Force Knight, Ninja and Tourist.
[list][*]The tourist is a very weak class that comes with their own special run completion method.[/list]
[*]A castle upgrade feature to improve the starting area with numerous benefits.
[list][*]The castle also includes access to some new unique campaign options and to a new special terrain with new bosses and endings/rewards for all classes.[/list]
[*]Numerous UI improvements including hotkey assignments for using items
[*]Lots of new items, NPCs, skills/force powers, etc
[/list]
The base game is still available with the DLC installed and the saves are separate, OWH saves can be imported into OWH+ with a few caveats that the game informs you of.

Finally, there are some balance changes - both buffs and nerfs (in some cases to the same feature but in different scenarios just to make it harder to abuse said feature)

[b]Value for money:[/b]
Well, the base game is a steal even at full price for the amount of content included, and with regular 75-80% deals you don't get much better value for money without being completely free.
The DLC is lower value for money than the base game but is still more than worth it.

Years later, I've had more fun with a $3($1 if it goes on sale!) game with its ~$6 expansion than some $30+ games I've owned.

Despite being a more traditional roguelike, OWH is a lot more accessible than ascii roguelikes. Featuring some simple but readable graphics, it's also not too difficult. With a lot of replayability through multiple endings, multiple difficulties, classes, and challenges, it's a simple game that'll provide a lot of hours of gameplay.

The art is a bit anime but it's pretty toned down. I don't think anybody will really strongly hate it. 

For gameplay, it's a pretty well balanced game. Obviously as a roguelike theres a degree of inventory management and there aren't many instances where I felt like the game deprived me of a resource leading to me losing only because of RNG. All the classes are unique enough to give each a different playstyle, a pirate has different strategies than a swordmaster, a hero can take on enemies differently than a bard will. 

There's also a surprisingly deeper story to the demon lord and the darkness, it really never is the highlight of the game over saving the world, but there are some more hidden endings.

I'd strongly recommend anybody who enjoys roguelikes or even wants to get started to try OWH. It provides a perfect mix of difficulty for people who want something to ease into playing roguelikes, and people who are masochistic enough to seriously enjoy the hardest difficulty. And with how low the price is, it's really not a tough choice to just pick it up.

The expansion OWH+ is also recommended as it effectively triples content through new npcs to meet, more endings, new items, rebalancing, a new postgame mechanic(Which is more just more QoL stuff), and improving QoL/UI.

27034657.review:
This is an easy-to-learn roguelike based on the idea that the left edge of the screen is some sort of Darkness that is always creeping to the right.  You have to stay ahead of it by crossing a mostly randomized landscape -- you start in the grasslands, but can move on to places like deserts or volcanic regions, each with their own twist on exploring and fighting.

You have a limited number of turns until the Demon Lord comes after you, so while you're running away from the darkness you encounter tiny forts with treasure, enemies to fight, townspeople to talk to or trade with, etc.

The farther you get and better you do, the more you can pass on to your next playthrough, get permanent upgrades, or unlock new character classes.

One Way Heroics is tough but not absurdly punishing, and the limitation on where you can go (not too far up or down, but always being pressured to go right) helps keep you on track instead of wandering aimlessly.  I felt that this encouraged repeated playthroughs without being frustrating -- I usually got a decent sense of advancement/accomplishment from a session.

The standard price is, what, under $5?  I'd say it's worth that, but it's often a lot cheaper during sales (as I write this, it's $1.74, and I've seen it for under $1.00).  If the idea sounds at all decent, add it to your wishlist and grab it next time it's under a buck.  Or just grab it now.

With the Mystery Chronicle version of OWH adding some divisive choices into the game, it made me appreciate the relative simplicity of OWH a lot. It's just you, the monsters, your companions, a Demon Lord, 1000km+ of neverending, randomly generated road ahead of you, and a wall of black death behind you.

This game is great on all fronts. 

Gameplay mechanics are great, keeping things moving quickly while requiring serious tactical decisions. The creators clearly recognized their key gameplay factors and designed all the game features around them.

The story is surprisingly deep and well-written (with party member plotlines and NPC dialog helping reinforce the overall theme).

Replay value is almost infinite, with many classes and party members, lots of endings (with different victory conditions), daily worlds with special rules, and varied environments. Oh, and difficulty settings of course.

Only potential drawback is runs can get quite long for some endings, with permadeath, and death can come quickly even late in the game (for some classes/difficulty settings at least). But you'll get your money's worth even if you don't do the longest quests.

I highly recommend this for anyone who's ever enjoyed a roguelike.

The game is amazing. I'll elabore below.

I'll start with the bad things i saw on my first minutes.

[h1] Negative [/h1]

[h1] - [/h1]   [b] UI [/b]: At first you will be overwhelmed by the UI, lots of stuff you don't know of, and weird position (I'm still not used to having a map in middle of the screen).
[h1] - [/h1] [b] Everything looks so small [/b]: The graphics are distant, but you'll accustom to it pretty easily. F4 (window size) will be your friend here.
[h1] - [/h1] [b] "Chatbox* [/b]: System info can be hard to see (the thing that looks like a chatbox) and you can't (or i haven't seen/found such feature) really scroll it up in case you missed something.

After my first few minutes, i was able to withstand the things i was concerned from. All thanks to these pros.

[h1] Positive [/h1]

[h1] + [/h1] [b] Soundtrack [/b]: The music is amazing. Each area has its own music and you'll be used to hear them pretty often, but the thing that i enjoyed the most, was event music.
Each event has a different soundtrack, and that adds a nice variety to your ears.

I'm just talking about design here, but the quality of the soundtrack is also amazing.
Area music matches pretty well with the environment.
Event music matches with the element of surprice and the feelings you may have while thinking your next move.
Lore (game over / special characters / victory / etc) music is nice, you won't feel that it's out of place or that it affects negatively to what's going on.

[h1] + [/h1] [b] Story [/b]: This one can be subjective. I love with all my heart the genre of medieval fantasy. You'll find a few clichés, but there is also room for nice plot in between. I won't say which kind of plot, but it was worth it, even tho i kinda like all medieval fantasy plots.

[h1] + [/h1] [b] Replayability [/b]: I'm pretty serious with this one. I make sure to not buy any game that can't offer a good replayability.

[h1] Please understand that after this point, i'll tell some stuff that even tho it's not a spoiler, it counts as stuff that is nice to see for yourself. You don't have to see all the game features in order to see if you'll enjoy it.
After this point i suggest you to try a demo or buy it and play it for as long as you can refund it in case you don't like it. [/h1]

Following the replayability...
You have different classes, each with unique skills, strenghts and weaknesses. At easy difficulties it isn't that big of a deal, but if you want to beat the game on the harder difficulties, you'll have to make good use of each class' strenghts.

After beating the game, next time you pick a class, you'll see a medal based on the difficulty on the class that you beated the game with.
A nice replayability factor is to complete the game on every difficulty with each class. And...

[h1] + [/h1] [b] Randomness [/b]:
As long as you keep playing on different realms, you won't have the same experience.

In case you are not that hardcore of a player, you can still repeat the last realm you played, and thus, having another try on the same encounter/environment.
Still, some stuff will be randomized, like items, monsters, treasure and such, so it won't be that boring, you almost won't feel like doing exactly the same.

This is getting too long, and i can't leave my games waiting for too long. So i'll jump to something i found average.

[h1] Bipolar [/h1]

[h1] +/- [/h1] [b] Save system [/b]:
You'll either love it or hate it. But you'll have options either way, remember that.

There are three ways to save your adventure (which can turn out to be some pretty long and hardcore expeditions).

1. Find a save attendant.
A young elf will offer a save feature when you find her. I won't say much more, that's up to you. But you'll be able to find her pretty often.

2. Save stone.
A crystal used to save the game. Save attendants sell it, but you can find one in your adventures if you are lucky.

3. Goddess gift.
Once in a while, a goddess will offer a save option at the cost of 5 levels.

Did you see what's so different here?
All saving methods include finding something. This is not a game you can start and leave every 8 minutes. So no gaming at work i guess.

Personally, i love this feature. I like to have to save some money for save crystals and use them wisely. As i said, you'll either love or hate this.

[h1] +/- [/h1] [b] Load system [/b]:
The game allows you to save > try > fail > load > try again. It's kinda expensive to do it often, but you can.

I don't like this, and i'm not the kind of person that can avoid to use an advantage when i see it. That's why i like unfair traps and the lack of Easy/Normal difficulties.
Even tho i never play on Easy... If i struggle a lot on normal, i'll consider it.

However, this system is also good in case you are not a hardcore player and you get too frustrated by dying because of a single mistake. (Like unequipping a shield and forgetting to equip it for the tough encounter.)

That's all, i need to go back and play more games. Have fun!

Have you ever played a game so good that you always wanted to come back to it and play it again, even after years, and it's just as good as you remembered?

25289241.review:
A modern side-scroller roguelike with anime-style graphics. It has most of the hallmark features of the roguelike genre -- procedurally generated world, tactical turn-based gameplay, interesting items (although much simpler than in big roguelikes such as ADOM or DCSS), multiple classes to choose from. The main thing which set its apart than other roguelikes is the side-scroller aspect -- the world is constantly moving to the right, and you lose if you don't move along. 

There are also some important aspects which are a bit anti-roguelike. One is that there are "save crystals" which can be used to save your game, but they felt more like an option for casual players -- the game seems balanced for permadeath play. Another aspect is that, after your game ends, you can store some of your items in the "dimensional vault", and use them in your next games -- this goes a bit against the traditional roguelike style, where your every game starts exactly the same as your first -- and when you win, you know that you won because you have learned the skills, not because the game became easier. However, I don't see it as a problem in the case of this game.

One problem I have with this game is that it does not run in Linux -- I run it via Wine, but this is inconvenient, and I lose music, which is apparently good.

In my opinion, it is far from the best games in the roguelike genre, but I still recommend playing it.

25207645.review: Not a game that you could play everyday (for me atleast) but when i do feel like playing it makes time run by quiclky. Recomended game for those who like repeating the same process over and over again but in a different way.

25123541.review: This game is such a nice refreshing take on the roguelike formula. The extra dimensions added to the game of having to avoid being gobbled up by the sweeping darkness that is constantly moving closer and closer makes for an exciting and (at times) extremely tense run. Add onto that the "dark lord" timer that's perpetually ticking away, which will launch you into a boss battle well before you're prepared, forcing some incredibly tense moments which make the escape and later victory that much more satisfying. Besides those unique twists, the rest of the game is pretty standard and is what you'd expect from a graphical roguelike such as this one. There's a really nifty multiplayer-like integration into the game, wherein the progress, accomplishments and eventual downfalls of the people playing on the same seed as you are periodically popping up as you play, and you can even run into the ghosts of dead players, receiving some minor benefit. The soundtrack for the game is great, really good old school rpg nostalgia quality to it. I have some small gripes about the interface and the way the menus are done, but it doesn't detract from the game in any major way. Overall, I think this is a fun game that's well worth picking up, especially on sale as it's already pretty cheap.

24174449.review:
A great value that gives you plenty of bang for your buck. 

I don't normally play rogue-like games, but this one was a total blast that kept me coming back for more until I finally conquered it, and I still plan to go back and play it again. I also plan to check out more rogue-like games due to how much I enjoyed this one. The music is solid, the gameplay is an exciting challenge, and the pacing is excellent, with the incoming shrouding darkness that stalks you throughout your journey (or several) putting a great deal of pressure on you to keep moving forward, but still giving you plenty of time to explore to your heart's content, powering up your character to prepare for your epic battle with the demon lord, the game's big boss. And the game gives you many ways to do so. 

You can go all around the map killing everything you see to level up as much as possible in the limited time you're given before the demon lord strikes. The second difficulty ensures that the demon lord can show up any time, which really amps up the intensity.

You can explore dungeons to loot rare items while taking out whatever lurks within.

You can stop at various buildings in the areas you visit to save your game, sell items, buy better items, and talk to NPC's. 

And much more.

Depending on quality of your build, you will die often when you first start playing, especially if you aren't used to playing these types of games. However, you'll notice yourself becoming increasingly better every time, and when you finally accomplish that perfect run you've been planning after several failed attempts, it's extremely satisfying. And really, just experimenting with different builds is fun even when you die, because frustration is infrequent. You learn from each and every death and the game is rarely every cheap. You can see all of the enemies coming towards you at all times, giving you plenty of time to prepare your next move. Plus, with a reasonable agility level, avoiding enemies altogether is a relative breeze.

One of the best things about dying in One Way Heroics is that it doesn't feel like the end. There are brief descriptive endings for every death you experience, plus every time you die, you're given the option to read advice, transfer items to a new run if you want to start fresh, unlock new classes to play with, and plenty more. Exploration rewards you with more items, many of which you don't know the details of until after your run ends, whether by victory or death, but there's an item you can pick up that allows you to see all your inventory details on the spot, which really comes in handy. 

Overall, One Way Heroics is one of those rare indie JRPG's where everything just clicks. It has very little in the way of flaws, it has tons of replay value, and there's almost always ways to freshen up your experience, with multiple updates and campaign variations keeping things interesting even after multiple hours of play. It's a great game with plenty to offer even to the most seasoned Japanese role playing game vets, and a shining example of indie development at its very best. Don't miss out on crafting your own incredible journey.

24099803.review:
Moving to the right is what heroes do.  Only villains go left.  In this peculiarly Japanese take on roguelikes, you'll explore dungeons, talk to townsfolk, do your between-battle shopping, rescue queens etc. in a kind of frantic fast forward, because you can't stop for long or the darkness will swallow you.

There are plenty of roguelite-style unlockables here to keep you busy, with a variety of classes, perks, and difficulty levels you can use to change things up, particularly in the Plus expansion (which I highly recommend).  The game uses a Shiren the Wanderer style vault to twink items between characters, but its usage is extremely limited.  It also features some interesting online features in that you can display a comment to other players which will show up along with some basic stats as to how you're doing, in the upper left corner (if you're playing a dimension shared with others).  You'll also run across the ghosts of dead players in these dimensions.

The game's aesthetic strongly reminds me of Elona, for some reason, even though the two games are alike only in that they're Japanese turn-based games that are roguelikes in a very loose sense of the word.  This isn't a bad thing; the way dialogue is written, the cheesy midi music, it's all got that uniquely Japanese indie feel to it that's ever so slightly jank, but adorable at the same time.  You'll be generating dimensions with names like ARAEYRILHG and trying again and again to kill that pesky Demon Lord for a long time to come, if you pick this one up.

I didnt expect much when I bought this game. I only wanted to get something fun for the leftovers on my psc. I dont regret giving this game a chance, it was better than I ever hoped for.

Now the combat and the gameplay is unique as such. You can only go straight to the right, therefor the name, but you have surprisingly much to take care of while walking that one way. You need to level your character, find equipment and food and prepare yourself for the final battle which starts at 400 distance for easy difficulty and at 100 for harder difficulty. It took me a while to even make it to the final battle at first, having to keep track of my own stamina, equipment and levels. I often rushed into dungeons filled with monsters I couldnt beat yet, or made dumb descisions which killed me. Its rather punishing since you can only save for either a 5 level cost or by dropping a save crystal. But that doesnt mean it's less fun, just more challanging.

+ You have different classes to pick from, each have their own playstyle with strengths and weaknesses. Some might not even be able to fight at all.
+ You gain points after each run, which you can invest to build a vault to store items for your next character or to unlock new traits.
+ You have different difficulties, even different gamemodes, changing the enemy / items or the way you start.
+ A playthrough doesnt take very long, so you can play it whenever you are up for it, without getting as invested as in big games like Fallout or Witcher.
+ Has some really good soundtrack and Artstyle

- Once you beat all the difficulties with all classes I guess there's not much to do.
- Can't think of anything else to list here.

You start out in a castle. The darkness is to the left of the castle. Every time you move, the darkness engulfs more of the screen, forcing you to move right. The people in the castle do not move right. Their screams will spur you onward as you look for a way to end the destruction of the world, and will remind you of the price of failure. (They respawn when you do, of course, so don't mourn them too long. The darkness waits for no one!)

As you move further and further right, you collect items, kill enemies, gain levels, and fight evil wizards by pelting them with rocks. You die a lot--sometimes from enemies, and sometimes because you landed on the wrong side of a wall or a mountain range while out of time stops. You have to start over each time, but you get to carry over some of your best items to your next life, so it's not that annoying. 

It's not earth-shattering, but it's a fun little roguelike for only $3.50. If you like the genre, you won't feel like you wasted your money.

23269847.review:
One Way Heroics is a 2D overhead rogue-like game where you're constantly escaping from an ever encroaching black mist coming from the left. If the mist catches up to you, or you die then it's completely game over and you start again while given the option to retain some of the items from this run, unlocking various new features classes and goodies along the way.

The game, at first, gives you a constant drive to play. The classes seem interesting and relatively varied and unlocking new skills, classes, and goodies in general is a fun. The interface and visuals are basic but well fleshed out and feel great, giving a bit of nostalgia to the 8-bit era of games like Dragon [strike]Quest[/strike] [i]Warrior[/i]. However, the issues with the game become apparent after the honeymoon period wears off.

The first of two major issues is the most unique aspect of the game - the darkness. The darkness was undoubtedly designed to create a sort of pacing and pressure, and at first it does. But once you become accustomed to the pacing of the game all it really does is discourage exploration. So long as you don't explore you'll never run into any problems with the darkness. But I happen to enjoy exploring!

The second is in the balance of the game. I think the best way to illustrate this is with one particularly absurd example. The main villain in the game is the demon lord. He'll occasionally fly in and you're supposed to wack at him a bit, constantly denting his hp a bit, until he flies away only to come back again. Rince, wash, repeat, until he's dead and the credits roll. One major strength of his is in shields - each time he appears, he has up to 45 layers of shields that need to be removed before you can even start damaging him. With a mellee class that might do just a few hits per turn at most while he's pounding on you with all he has - this is a big problem. For a mage class? Well for some reason their attacks go right through the shields. On the hardest difficultly level in the game, I defeated him the first time he appeared by just zapping him a few time with the weakest attack the mage has boosted by a pretty generic staff and beat him the first time he appeared - achieving consistent victory on the max difficulty in about 15 minutes. Pretty anticlimatic for a roguelike. 

This isn't a game you'll be spending hundreds and probably not even tens of hours on, but for a fun 10 or 20 hour romp it's an enjoyable experience.

I bought this because it was labeled as an RPG. I realize this is a rogue like also. In my personal opinion this game feels like it fails both genres.

When playing an RPG there needs to be a sense of exploration/story. However, this game really punishes you for exploring. You will come across tons of little enemy houses with treasure in them, but most of the time it is impossible to kill the swarm of enemies inside and unlock a box before the area gets swallowed by the black edge of the screen. Furthermore, the character progression just isn't there. I get that one of the man features of rogue likes is permadeath, but the perks you can buy and upgrade a new character with don't make you feel stronger. You can unlock different classes of hero but they don't feel any different.  

The controls suck for the combat style. It's both live action and turn based. You pretty much walk around the map, but when you come across enemies you must take it slow and be very deliberate about facing the right direction before initiating any action, otherwise you swing at air and waste a turn. The controls just felt very clunky and took away from the immersion. I feel like pure turn based combat would have been better.

My final verdict is 5/10. This game probably is more enjoyable as a rogue like than an RPG. Only worth purchasing when on sale for 50% off or more.

23109518.review:
"One Way Heroics" is a great roguelike where you play as a hero who tries to stop the darkness from swallowing the world - literally. You are forced to travel to the right in your quest as the darkness destroys everything from the left. Each world you save unlocks more classes, perks and other bonuses that bring you closer to solving the mystery behind the threat that engulfs endless worlds.

The gameplay is quite well balanced, allowing for different playstyles. The variety of difficulties, campaign types and options encourage players of all skill levels to continue moving forward. While the art could use some improvement, the music is decent and the story is quite interesting and well-written.

"One Way Heroics" brings the excitement of permanent death while giving players many reasons to keep trying again. I highly recommend the game to both roguelike veterans and those new to the genre. Do consider buying the DLC - "One Way Heroic Plus", as it adds even more content, features and replay value

23085786.review:
Getting brutally beaten to death while climbing some mountains is my jam! No, seriously, I'm all for permadeath but I lost many promising runs in a fashion similar to that.
Woes of stupidity aside, this game is great, and much more deep than the interface and graphics might suggest. The mechanics take a while to get right and it's harsh to new players, but it's a far cry from the most complex of roguelikes. And, once you have the basics down, you have a high chance of beating the Big Bad with something like the Swordmaster. Personally, I still can't get a hang on the more fragile classes, and just cheese it with a shield-wielding Hero.
Anyways. If you are a fan of roguelikes, unorthodox design choices, deep, lighthearted but at times sad plots, and, of course, the buffload of content RPGs usually come with, then One Way Heroics is for you.

23017156.review:
This game is simply amazing.

You start by choosing a class and up to 5 perks, but you will have to unlock most of these first.
It's fun trying different combinations and seeing how they play out.

The map is determined by the seed you choose, you can pick a random one, enter one yourself or choose one of a few daily dimensions that are altered in a special way.
The game is rogue-like and turn-based, dying means perma-death.
During your run you will explore the map, find loot, kill monsters and other enemies, level up, talk to several NPCs who offer various services, recruit NPCs to help you fight and finish your main quest (which is usually killing a boss).

Every turn the darkness behind you consumes a little bit more of the map, so you have to keep progressing forward and think carefully about if you'll have enough time to explore a dungeon or visit a town. Normally this isn't really a problem, you can easily outrun the slowly-progressing darkness.
In case of emergency you can use your Awakening ability up to 5 times, which stops the time for 3 turns so you can get yourself out of trouble.

Usually whenever you die, it is because you weren't careful, you will learn from most deaths.
Most of the time there are ways to save yourself, but you just didn't try or think of everything or were too cocky, though of course there are also times when the game really seems to hate you.

There are multiple endings depending on how you beat the game and which NPC you have with you.
Moreover when you beat the game you can store some items in your vault, which you can choose to use at the beginning of each run.

Lastly, it's a single-player game, but while playing the game online it will show you details about other players who are in the same dimension and occasionally you will meet ghosts of other fallen players who will drop one of their items and give you experience.
Furthermore after clearing a dimension it will show you the characters of everyone who completed it as well.

For the price, especially when it's on sale, it's a steal.
I definitely also recommend buying [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/352840/]OWH+[/url] if you already enjoyed the base game, it adds a lot of new content.

Put simply, One Way Heroics is the Heroes of Might and Magic III of turn-based rogue-likes. You should expect to lose several hours at a time with each session. Unlike classic Rogue-Likes (Dungeon Crawl/Elona) I've found that every time I play this, I feel like I discover new ways to play the game. 22542582.review:
I'm no expert on roguelikes. But this game at base price costs about as much as a cup of coffee from a mid-market coffee chain. I've played it for twenty hours, and it still feels like I'm scratching the surface; after each run, I feel like I learned something about how the game works, about what it wants from me and how to succeed. It's a good feeling. The game is fair but challenging, and for those of us for whom that isn't enough, offers a highly modular difficulty system (base difficulty plus class plus perks, all of different usefulness) to challenge yourself with. There's incremental progress and upgrades to unlock if you'd rather have a barometer of progress other than your own growing skill at the game, which is difficult to quantify, but grinding for these things isn't really an issue -- classes and perks are pretty cheap, at least for the useful ones, and everything else is bonus stuff.

If you buy the expansion, you're basically getting a game that has double or triple the content of the base game, and also includes a whole bunch of quality of life UI upgrades and balance changes. A lot of the things added are very simple and unobtrusive but satisfying -- things like turning to face the enemies automatically, a little screen to track all of the things you've achieved as each class, more dimensions to facilitate the psuedo-multiplayer. Other additions are bigger -- new classes, new allies, new npcs, new bosses and objectives and missions. While the price of the dlc is triple that of the base game, it's absolutely worth it -- even more so if you can get it on sale. The hours of gameplay/$ ratio is excellent.

It's also in the class of games that are easy to play while doing something else, like holding a skype conversation or queuing for a match in some other game. It takes very little processor power, deals with tab switching quite agreeably, and time stops while you aren't moving.

All in all, I think it's a great way to spend an hour or two between doing other things, and ends up being quite moreish once you've wrapped your head around the basic steps to survival. Then, it's all about the rng and your own wits. Recommended.

22265224.review:
One Way Heroics is a tile-based, rouge-like, J-RPG. There is a constant threat, the darkness, consuming the world. There's only... a 'few' ways to resolve and save what is left of this world.

One Way Heroics has a constant threat; the swallowing darkness from the west, and thus one can travel only eastwards or risk being consumed themselves. There will be many opportunity costs because of this. One can only explore only so much north-side and south-side in such a time-frame that you may miss a dungeon, or a town, or even rare holy loot; or unfortunately encounter a powerful foe that will devour your lifepoints in a single blow. Unable to fully loot everything because of a weight limit, you will have to take a limited amount of supplies and equipment and give up what is necessary for survival or end up blowing your own self up because someone lit up explosives in your inventory. 

It comes along with many classes starting with the sharp Swordsmaster and agile Hunter, to the charming Bard and sexy Hero... to a traveling Tourist [i](DLC)[/i]? Each a journey without rest and different abilities for each class.

In terms of difficulty, you choose the difficulty before you start your adventure; from [i]A Simple Walk In The Park (Easy)[/i] and [i]An Afternoon Stroll (Normal)[/i], to a [i]Grueling Campaign (Insane)[/i]. As time goes on and as the darkness consumes more of the world; foes will be buffed and be stronger in level. It can be tough understanding every little mechanic there is, but after a few Walk in The Parks, you'll get a solid grasp on what and what not to do.

In terms of the game-play time, you can probably expect each normal journey to take thirty minutes to an hour (or an unfortunate eight minutes if you get caught off-guard), depending on how much you're willing to balance exploring and fighting. There are save points for each journey if you're slightly lucky to encounter them in towns, so don't worry if you end up having to sleep for yourself in the real world. Don't worry, that darkness won't eat you.

The DLC (OWH+) is not strictly necessary, but it does change and add more content to the game as it should. Get it if you enjoy the base game for how it is, and you'll definitely enjoy what the DLC will deliver (classes, choices, and stories!).

There are many win and lose conditions, multitudes of endings, and things to learn about the origins and the characters you meet along the way; certainly a lot to adventure and explore outside from the adventure itself.

Taking One Way Heroics to a new level, Plus adds almost double the content with new classes, enemies, features and more. Defeat the Demon Lord in a whole different dimension with this unmissable addition. 

Literlly the DLC and the Whole entire game in a nutshell

If you are a fan of Rouge like Dungeons / Openworlds like Minecraft - Binding Of Issac series, and Cyrpt of the Necrodancer. Then this game is also a must in your inventory of wonderous games.

I personally would like to say I spent countless hours offline and online on this game. Trust me, it may look low now. But I spent 100+ of hours playing this... Why? I had worlds to explore. I maybe explored over 1000+ worlds and yet have to save not even 40% of them yet. 

You get to choose your class and you are already set to go on a journey of a everlasting battle of darkness. Not only that, [spoiler] the darkness is actually a dragon! [/spoiler] is also a very impending doom of your very world you travel and  saving!

Fear not, you have time on your hand. No joke, time is of the essance and so is key placement, fighting, item usage and your weapon durability. May I also say you have a day/night cycle? Vision ? More over that you have Bonuses and debuffs? Even more so you can find allies! Even if you're willing to sacrifice some of your levels, [spoiler] A bard and hero is more sufficient in creating a co-op NPC! [/spoiler] you can obtain some Cooperating Enemies or other misc!. 

The content of the first game is already a great stand alone game. But the expansion far over gives it more power and bang for your buck. Even at a sale price, the game is fantastic. The classes are easy to understand, the game mechanics simply easy to use, and if delt well , very useful to master. As time, placements, and generally the whole landscape. You too can already learn the many ways of becoming heroic.

There is also a _Afterdeath_ Screen where you can save, trade, expend, repair, and increase your items you collected in your traveling of the worlds. Hell you can even gain items you can't get in certain campaings. But if you complete it , you gain special other perks, even endings you can get if you finally get them! 

Game has perks in it... PERKS! Even Debuffs that make your heroic level skyrocket, but not for the faint of heart. As the Debuffs increase levels, yes, but make your game FAR more Harder and more time pinching then the other easy pickings. The Pros

21995621.review: The game plays very similarly to the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series of games, except instead of the "dungeon" being comprised of a lot of hallways and rooms, it's an expansive, randomly generated world, with dungeons to explore and towns to stop at. The only stipulation is that you have to keep moving right or you'll be consumed by the "darkness" or something to that effect. It's an interesting combination of mechanics that force you to prioritize targets and plan your actions ahead of time. Often you won't be able to fully explore a dungeon or town because every action advances the screen a little bit farther. There's also a lot of managing of inventory space, you have to choose what items to keep and what to leave. The game is very rewarding, and all of the unlockable content (in addition to the randomly generated worlds) gives the game immense replay value. It's definitely worth the price they're asking for it. One of the most fun games I've played in awhile, especially for under five bucks.

21679181.review:
TLDR:  Only buy this game if you get it WITH the expansion, and preferably on sale.  The reason I don't recommend it is because One Way Heroics is still an incomplete game, with the expansion and all.

The review:

After 70 hours playtime, I can't recommend One Way Heroics.  Without the expansion (One Way Heroics Plus, $6.49), this game is borderline unplayable.  The expansion brings in much needed UI updates, gameplay tweaks, more items and more characters.  And a ton of bug fixes.

Problem is, most of that stuff should have been patched in to the base game.  Or, more realistically, put in to the game before it ever released.  Especially since, even with all that, it still feels like a beta version.  Very late in the beta process, but still not quite ready for release.  Somewhere in the polishing phase.  Bugs are still being squashed to this day, and I experienced plenty in my time with the game. 

Once you take all the things from OWH+, and subtract them out since they should have been included in the main game prior to release, you're left with just the new classes and the castle expansions.  And they aren't worth $6.49 by themselves.  The classes are easy to gloss over, and none of the castle expansions have a huge impact on your game.  You can easily do without both.

With a bit of a shallow story, one that was also poorly translated, the gameplay is what keeps you coming back.  And it's (almost) all there... so long as you make sure to pick up OWH+ as well.

21633863.review:
I've never posted a review of this game until now only because it's hard to find words to sum up how great it is without dragging the review on and on.

Here's what you need to know.
One Way Heroics is a relatively simple take on a lot of RPG elements woven into a roguelike fantasy. The system for gear statistics is pretty straightforward, as is the story-telling, as is leveling up. There are no skill trees or any choice of what stat you level up, but I promise you it won't matter.
That being said, the simplicity is nice. It allows you to play the game casually without taking away that constant strive some players have for better gear or "the perfect run".

The combat is also quite simple. You have a basic attack you will use most of the time, as well as a few abilities learned from leveling or NPC's. It's quick, with you likely not spending more than 5 seconds on most enemies besides bosses. It keeps the game moving, which is nice because in a roguelike its important not to drag things out. This also allows you to keep the game short if that's what you want. Personally my average session is maybe 2 hours long, but if you insist on going as far as 2000km (which isn't neccessary to win), it's a bit closer to 4 or 5 hours. Optional saves make those long games far less daunting.

As I said, this game can work for casual players, but it does not leave the more dedicated players with nothing to do. 170 hours as I'm writing this review and there is still more to do. The game has a few interesting objectives woven into it to DRASTICALLY increase replay value, such as daily campaigns that change up the rules of the procedurally generated worlds you play in, multiple bosses to defeat, 4-5 different difficulties and 4 different ways to "win" a playthrough. Also it has one particular aspect I love to see in roguelikes; you can transfer a limited amount of gear from one playthrough to another. This helps you to continue your quest for the absolute best gear by allowing you to keep enchanting gear instead of losing everything at the end of a playthrough. But it's not at all essential for beating the game if that's too easy for you ;)

As for the "One Way Heroics Plus" expansion (without going into detail), it's not neccessary for enjoying the game. It's the icing on top of the cake, and the odds are you will want it at some point or another, so I suggest buying it right off the bat to really enhance the game.

Whether you are looking for a game to waste a few hours on, or one to get really sucked into, you just can't go wrong with One Way Heroics.
