21558401.review:
One Way Heroics is a simple rogue-like with a lot of character. The worlds are randomly generated and randomly populated, so each play through is different. The difficulty is moderate, and each run through a campaign yields points that can be used for upgrades, making subsequent runs easier. OWH keeps a large record of all sorts of statistics and completionists will find plenty of stuff to do in order to fill out the statistics screen.

OWH includes all sorts of endings and random events within the worlds. Every supporting character has their own interesting stories, and discovering the whole story behind the game across multiple playthroughs an interesting approach to narrative. It also has a fantastic soundtrack.

The DLC is a great addition and adds a fair bit of content and replayabilitiy, though the base game still feels complete enough to have provided me dozens of hours of play. The game is flexible enough where you can do a short 15 minute run or a several hour long journey, if you wish. At the asking price, One Way Heroics is more than worth it, and is my favorite rogue-like on Steam. I cannot recommend this game enough.

20816877.review:
This game....it is addictive.

I got it for $0.89 and almost immediately bought the DLC. I've had way more enjoyment from this game than 89 cents has any right to give! The fast-paced gameplay gives all of the satisfaction of a Final Fantasy game without all of the lengthy cutscenes. As such, it is great fun in 20 minute chunks or 2 hour marathons.

One Way Heroics is a Roguelike adventure game that takes place in a fantasy world that is being consumed by darkness. Our brave hero must quickly travel ---> and defeat the Demon Lord in order to stop the darkness from consuming the entire world!  The constant pressure of the dark wall of doom closing in behind you forces you to plan ahead and takes a bit of getting used to. Labyrinthine dungeons are there for the plundering, but if you spend too much time looting you may find yourself without an escape route! 

Don't let the word "roguelike" scare you off! The game has a save system, so if you really want to continue your adventure after getting eaten by that dragon, you can restart from the last time you saved. Keep an eye out for villages to save at! Also, there is an "emergency save" feature that allows you to save anywhere provided it has been at least 5 (in-game) days since your last save. Of course, you get a higher end-game score if you clear the game without dying, and with minimal saving.

In the beginning, you can choose between two classes, and more can be unlocked as you earn hero points (awarded at the end of each run). Each class has a trait unique to them that offers its own style, from the straightforward Swordmaster: master of slashy stuff, to the Force User: a squishy mage-type character.

Without spoiling anything, the game has a surprising amount of depth to it. I'm still discovering new stuff and I have been playing for quite a while already. There is a dark brotherhood, NPCs to befriend, an adorable fairy guide, witty dialogue, and some interesting sidequests you can find. The DLC is well-worth the cost, almost doubling the amount of content in the game.

Give this game a go, at a price like this you'd be hard pressed to find a better value.

One Way Heroics seems like a simple game, but it has alot of depth and alot of heart. It has gameplay that forces you to make all or nothing decisions and amazing soundtrack. 

The trailer really does summarize it best. Do you risk going into the dungeon to check those chests when the dimensional void is approaching? Your skills, items, and abilities all factor into that being a good decision. However,  you also need to get stronger as the game gets harder the further you go so going in unprepared may be the best call. The game has saving (unless a certain mode is activated), but  it is limited based on an item you purchase or rare totems that cost exp. The risk is real and gives this little game alot of depth. Its also not too intense as nothing happens unless your character is moving. 

This game has an amazing soundtrack and alot of the best tracks are not even on Youtube. This  is almost like a Touhou or Cave Story where the music is as much as a selling point as the gameplay. 

There is no reason to at least try this game as it is often just a dollar. It could take up hundreds of hours of your time with its generated worlds, weekly events, multiple endings, and long list of distinct classes.

19987313.review: Highly recommended. Besides being a unique procedurally-generated RPG with an appealing soundtrack, this game has another worthwhile distinction that isn't frequently mentioned in positive reviews: One Way Heroics is conducive to playing in short bursts, or for hours at a time. 19926240.review:
One Way Heroics (OWH), is a Quick paced Rogue-like RPG made from the RPG maker Series. Sounds simple, and is easily hidden amongst the other "Maker Games" on Steam. But this is one RPG that you should not miss. It's Challenging, Fast-Paced, and Addicting. As the name implies you will be going one way with your "heroics" as you battle the Darkness that is plaguing the world you inhabit (as the different world are classified as alternate dimensions in-game)

Pros
- A Decent array of Classes, 2 to begin 8 overall (3 more if you get the expansion).
- No two world are the same allowing for a new exciting experience each time, and if you liked a world you played before you have access to that in your logs.
- Simple yet thrilling combat: with the unique "one way" mechanic, the combat does not allow you to dawdle and grind. You will have to defeat enemies Quickly.
Con (As the only one i can really think of as of writing this review)
- Slow Start: the Game is tough, While it's nice that the first two classes you start with are easy to play, the Classes you unlock will take a bit of practice to get used to making it a tad difficult to unlock early achievements.

Otherwise One Way Heroics is a fast paced RPG that looks generic but should Not be Overlooekd just becasue of that. IF you like Simple yet thrilling RPGs then One Way Heroics is a Game for you!

19860578.review:
So, I bought this game a long time ago thinking it was going to be a game where I ran in one direction trying to stay alive.

I was not disappointed in the slightest.

One-way Heroics offers some of the dumbest, funniest, and rediculous gameplay I have ever seen from a rouge-like game. 

*Slight spoilers below, you have been warned*

-Hey, I know you're new, but you're supposed to save the world from the left side of the screen since this is sidescrolling and all, and for some reason the left side of the screen is eating everything. GOOD LUCK!

So begins your slow and painful descent into hell. 

At the 1st gate of hell you pick your class, name, and perks (assuming you even have any). At first you'll wonder why you only get two classes, and thats because without any foundation the others will either be piss easy to play (IM LOOKING AT YOU PIRATE <3) or even harder to get going than your beginner classes (coughForceUsercough).

At the 2nd circle of hell you wander around on "Walk in the Park" mode (easy mode) and you get the gist of the game....while simultaneously wondering why the fabled final boss meets you at a predetermined point or why they even want to kill you (I still dont remember signing up for this ***....Was I Voluntold?). You also realize multiplayer is a lie, as ghosts of people who may have died in that world you signed up to plop into dont seriously help when you're being swarmed by Zubats when night falls on the open plains.

At the 3rd circle of hell you die because an imp threw a rock too hard at your skull....or a skeleton was spawned in and one shot you with its nifty sword....or you got trapped in the damn DESERT and harpies ended up swarming your soon-to-be carcass. You die, get a crappy score, get some really lame advice and useless critiques from Navi the Fairy, maybe even some halfway tips, and you start over because you refuse to take your beating lying down.

At the 4th circle of hell you beat the game once and get an ending that leaves too many things open. So you start again, probably on a higher difficulty because you havent learned your lesson from being nearly incinerated and eaten by wild dingos. This was a mistake, as now you have to deal with your old AND new anus being torn asunder because enemies are hitting like speeding bullet trains and you just left the Shire. 

At the 5th circle of hell you start getting more endings because you keep beating the game, but now with some of those elusive bonus companions at your side. You meet Elodie after you beat Long Live the Queen (she clearly took nothing but combat classes this time), Azir-Finally here-Emperor Pigeon, Alphonse Elric, an edgy Male Gunner from DFO, a defenseless Loli, a nurse that's crying because you chewed her out for being a dog girl instead of a cat girl, and money grubbing panty mercenary who doesnt actually care about panties. Their endings flesh out their characters, but you still dont know what the hell is going on (or why the left side of the screen continues to devour the game like its stocking up for hibernation every time you start the game again).

At the 6th circle of hell you decide to just ignore the final boss and journey until the game makes you stop. This results in many a death and many late nights wondering why the fuck you bought this game. Eventually you reach the end of the world (cause the world really is flat guys, school lied to you) and you finally understand that this game is just dicking with you over and over until you get it right.

At the 7th circle of hell you attempt to fix the left side of the screen, only to be eaten and or incinerated by it......now everything becomes clear to you and you know what you need to do.

At the 8th circle of hell you get some Cheesy Puffs, some Dew, and prepare your quad-anuses (btw you should have a minimum of 4 now) for tons of save scumming because of all of the save crystals you hoarded in your Dimensional Vault between worlds; clears or deaths. You finally beat the game and you throw yourself into the next circle of hell because nothing matters anymore.

At the 9th circle of hell you melt your computer because now you have to buy the DLC and experiance being Anakin Skywalker, Naruto, and some random tourist to Disney World to get all the achievements in the game.
Time and time again you are going to want to chuck your keyboard/laptop wondering what new ways the game can come up with to cheapshot you and why you just took 600 damage because a bear decided to fuck your shit up. This game (on higher difficulties) will tear you a new one and laugh as you try to tape your anus back together. On lower difficulties.....itll only happen 1 or 2 times because you'll pick up enough situational awareness to not get your eyes torn out of their sockets while you were exploring or trying to reach that one item tucked inbetween 30 tiles of mountain when all you know how to do is dash around like Sanic the fucking Hedgehog, trying to figure out how many items you can get before the left side of the screen eats you again.. Eventually you realize that you spent over 60 hours on a game where all you do is go right and try to survive when you suddenly dont get any food for 700 kms, or you get 4 consecutive corrupted lands and the fucking wolfmen and dragonkin swarm your position after all your weapons snap in half from all the fighting, or you blow up because you got set on fire and forgot to chuck that Elzite bomb you got 2 minutes into a run.

As you enter the Nth Circle of hell you realize that this was all only worth it if you can somehow make and achieve some sort of goal. You didnt, and you laugh as you realize this game has seared your soul and you will never be the same again.

10/10 would auto-pilot into a lava tile again.

19837164.review:
Welcome to the world of One Way Heroics.
You can play as multiple characters while you travel to the right side of the map at all times for a great darkness follows and swallows the world behind you. Do you have what it takes to manage the up coming challenges and escape the creeping death while facing the dangers ahead?

Starting off the king sends you upon a journey to escape the darkness and find the truth of what is happening to the world, you take the challenge before you and must move and leave behind the castle. Once on the move you must use cunning and skill in a semi turned based, rogue-like, RPG full of challenges. Bosses await your arrival at certain intervals, the randomly generated map will keep you on your toes. Decisions will have you staring at your screen for minutes at a time. Should you use that ability to save your life or keep pushing yourself to the limit for the slim chance of victory.

I expect to be placing alot more time into this gem. It has an excellent amount of difficulty and a very unique type of gameplay with the grid system, in-depth attributes, weapon enchanting, and item management. 

I highly recommend this game, thanks for reading.

Before purchasing this game, I was sceptical of the darkness mechanic mostly because I don't like feeling rushed in a game. What caught my attention to the game was the mult-world system, where there are infinite world seeds to add infinite possibility to the game, which also meant a lot of replay value. Secondly, the graphics and classes reminded me of my old favorites, the Final Fantasy games. After buying the game and DLC on a good whim, and trying it out for the first time, I immediately loved it. The encroaching darness actually made it a lot of fun because it added a sense of hurry and a feeling of loss when you couldn't reach that item or town in time, but it also wasn't too fast as to ruin the focus of the gameplay so I don't mind the rush because it still gives ample opportunity to do what you want while constaly reminding you to keep moving. Lastly, the dimentional storage system made it so that playing it again and again wasn't such a drag for unlocking new things because you can store and take items from the storage throughout multiple playthroughs making it a bit easier than doing it from scratch (although its a fun challenge playing hard difficulties without using the stoage).

          So as for final thoughts on the game; I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes old school RPG's with a twist. Also if you're looking for a game with great replay value, I'd say this game is up there with 'Binding of Isaac: Rebrith/Afterbirth' for a fraction of the price. It has plenty to unlock, along with a fair amount of items to use to your advantage. 9.5/10 Definately would support this game if more DLC's came out for it.

19416124.review:
Amazing blend of classic jRPG and rogue-lite. Original, amazingly deep content, interesting and simple mechanics, fair, really all that's needed for a top notch rogue-lite. It does have some limited saves, but I still think it qualifies. The humor is also very good, and the story surprisingly interesting despite how the entire game can be finished in an hour or so. Which is good because that's a type of game you're meant to finish many times to get the many different endings and face the many different daily challenges.

The graphics and soundtrack are also good in a 8-bit kind of way, but the real draw is really the gameplay.

It's a very solid recommendation for anyone who likes roguelikes and don't mind jRPGs. If you're a fan of jRPGs and can stomach roguelike mechanics, you should also definitely give it a try, it's an experience you have to make. Easily one of my favorite games.

19405345.review:
Easily one of the best roguelikes out there. I'd put it at number 2 in my book.
The companions are terrific; each have their own stories and quests. I don't think I've ever seen a roguelike with a story that was actually compelling. 
The spell casting is phenomenal, something I could never enjoy in Nethack, Slash'em, and other turnbased roguelikes.
Terrific soundtracks, another thing that many roguelikes lack. I'd say on-par, maybe better, than FTL soundtracks.
IMO, this game has an excellent balance of luck vs tactical sense (Its not a total crapshoot but there is enough randomness to make repeat playthroughs rewarding and fun.
Incredible sense of adventure as you flee the oncoming doom from the west; different biomes offer unique challenges and enemies.
Most people don't realize there are actually THREE ways to win. If you think you da man just because you stomped the demon lord, think again. You ain't done yet, lil nigga.

And... its 87 cents during sales. You could buy a soda... or you could save half that money and buy a game with at least 20 hours of content. What a time to be alive.

19386816.review:
Do not be fooled by the cheap price, this game is worth way more than what it's up for. At first i thought it was going to be another cheesy sidescroller game, and boy was I wrong. This game is absolutely fantastic, a real gem, and I'm suprised it's not exploding. The game is fun. Anyways, enough ranting about how fun it is, here's my pros and cons.


PROS: Massive replay value. There is a lot of hidden content, and a lot more to the game than what you see on your first clear.

Multiple classes for your own style of adventuring. While this may not seem huge, the differences in classes are a lot more diverse than what you think. Join up with a party of a few people, or go completely ham solo with a knight. Choice is yours

Great soundtrack. Honestly, i really enjoy the music in this game. It's something i can sit down to, and not mute the game for my own music.

Difficulty. This game can throw some suprising difficulty at the most unexpected places. I've died at some very unexpected places. There is a lot of strategy into this game. Very good for those who enjoy a challenge.

CONS: Well, I haven't run into anything that would deter me or anyone i know away from the game yet, but I'll update this if I do.

19384218.review:
A distinctly (but not stereotypically) Japanese take on the (real) roguelike. Kill things. Collect utility items. Find good gear, hopefully. Carefully contemplate your options as a cabal of imps breathe down your neck. Probably get killed, or more likely kill yourself in a nearsighted blunder. Every once in a blue moon, reach the the Big Bad only to lose your head to a casually-flung fireball. Every once in a hundred blue moons or so, actually kill the guy. It's simpler than, say, Nethack, but bears more depth than grandaddy Rogue.

In true roguelike spirit, there is a leveling system, but progression is heavily biased towards gear, and by extension very random.

The advancing wall of doom is a unique spin on the roguelike formula, forcing you to budget your actual turns. Can you make it back to the entrance of the dungeon? You can easily kill the enemy harassing you, but do you have time? It creates a real sense of urgency without imposing actual time limits. You have plenty of time to think... about the 8 turns you have remaining before the darkness consumes you.

Another unique mechanic is the final boss periodically shows up and harasses you before running away. It's a double-edged sword; this gives you an opportunity to slay him early, if you got lucky enough or twinked over powerful items from your vault. At the same time, you have to know not just when, but HOW to run. The game does warn you when he'll be showing up soon, so you always get a chance to put your pants back on.

And unlike your average roguelike, it's controller-friendly, being largely driven by graphical menus as opposed to keystroke commands.

If you like very unusual games, buy it. If you enjoy a proper roguelike, buy it. Hell, it's dirt cheap even without a sale. And quite good.

19327769.review:
[h1][quote]One way to get the most out of life is to look upon it as an adventure. -William Feather[/quote]
***I would like to give a special thanks to Earl[33rd] for proof-reading this review and for initially presenting this title to me.

Developed by Indie studio Smoking WOLF and released on February 28, 2014, [i]One Way Heroics (OWH)[/i] is a two-dimensional procedurally-generated roguelike in which an increasing threat of dark essence jeopardizes every individual in the expanse. You play as a custom character on a trek to defeat the Demon Lord, a powerful entity that imperils the world with the motivation toward total destruction. Before meeting the tendrils of corruption, the player must endure a certain distance-decided when choosing the various game settings-while destroying hostile creatures.[/h1]

Here are a few items of interest within [i]OWH[/i]:

Gameplay - Aside from other roguelikes, this title’s complexity is derived from its tactical display rather than gameplay, as [i]One Way Heroics[/i] utilizes a turn-based approach to combat and item usage. Each in-game action made by the hero utilizes said turns, which advances the daunting foe. The term ‘turn-based strategy’ does not entirely cover this game’s spectrum, however, as [i]every[/i] action, whether it be equipping a new weapon or item, or consuming a potion to gain back energy, summons evil one turn closer to the player’s character. Adding to the ominous theme, the darkness swallows the lands you have passed through, and the notification of non-player character deaths can be heard as they disappear into mist. Controls are rather simple on both keyboard and controller, but can be adjusted in the case that they feel awkward. Equipment can be modified within the menus to alter the method of play by adding boons to weapons and armor, but, as stated, this increases danger; these items are gained either as loot from defeated enemies or may be distributed throughout the map. With a high enough Charisma score, the player may also gain discounts from various shops and recruit non-player individuals to the party that will assist in combatting foes and leveling up. 

Character Creation & Upgrades - Characters comprise of several customizable components, such as name, class, avatar, and perk and statistical preferences chosen by the player; perks may also grant players companions or other game modifications such as quicker swimming or improved unarmed damage. These adjustments allow the player to modify how they would like to play according to the class. Additional equipment may alter damage totals to enemies or reduce them toward the player’s character. Levelling up in [i]OWH[/i] operates in a similar way to other titles, as it improves the character’s base statistics depending on which class was chosen.

Unlockables - Depending on how far the player’s character progresses in the campaign, a number of Hero Points are rewarded to the player to purchase game augments. These modifications increase the amount of content usable by the player, such as said hero classes, perks-with selections for both combat and other skills-, and expanding what’s known as the Dimensional Vault: an item-storage system in which adventurers may donate a number of items from preceding generations to the next living hero. This expands play so that the entire game is not just an uphill battle with no reward when so close to the resolve, but rather contains encouragement toward progression.

TL:DR - [i]One Way Heroics[/i] is a fun, simple, and rewarding title with incentive to advance toward the Demon Lord time and time again. There is a great amount of challenge involved in this title, but does not evoke frustration due to its Hero Point system. Though the accolade of defeating the ultimate evil may not be reached every time, the journey is a fantastic ride filled with choice, vicious battle, and sacrifice. I highly recommend this title to anyone who enjoys roguelikes and simple roleplaying mechanics. This game has a great deal of replayability, and I hope you enjoy upon purchase. Thanks for reading.

Do you feel this review helped in any way? Feel free to visit my Curator Page at [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9793734/]Spearpoint Reviews[/url].

19297993.review:
There is a TL:DR

If you grab this game for less than $1 then it is very much worth it. I actually REALLY like the game and the simplicity of combat but boy oh howdy is it a very shallow experience. Aside from tiny modifiers and higher difficulties this is a very easy game to beat once you figure out how not to die to the moving wall of darkness.

There are 2 types of rogue like games. The first type you actually progress your character accross playthroughs (Dead Rising, Rogue Legacy) where you get your sense of accomplishment despite not beating the game.

The other type consists of losing literally everything stat and possession and see if you roll the dice better this time around. Thats much harder to remain satisfying since from a stat angle you can't tell who has 80 hours of play time and who has 5 hours. So why invest the additional 75 hours?

This game is the latter, sure certain games can pull it off like Faster then Light because you unlock ways that alter the game in a dramatic way that getting those unlocks feels worth it even if you lose. This game has a few different classes but they control and play almost identically and their bonuses would only be noticed if this game was in the former catagory. It wouldn't be hard either, you remove weapon degredation (since you can save items between playthroughs) and allow perminent base stat increases using the levels you gain in playthrough as currency. Make this playthrough harder so that future ones will be easier sort of deal, they already have something like that but it only applies to the current playthrough

TL:DR this game is very much worth if you're buying it for literal cents on the dollar. It goes on sale frequently

19258962.review:
There are two philosophies in making Roguelikes: The classic Roguelikes like NetHack had dungeons that weren't terribly long with permadeath, but were excessively lethal because the point was that you, [i]the player[/i] were the one "leveling up" by learning new techniques for beating the game that you never thought about before you had YASD or hit the oracle; The other usually eschews permadeath to have a more classic RPG sense of character progression through nigh-infinite procedural dungeons.  

One Way Heroics goes the ultra-short game route with none of the character progression, but it also manages to be so rules-light that it fails to really give the player any sense that they learned anything.  I "beat" the game on my second try, and it just said, "Yay, now try again!"... WHY? What goal do I have in playing through a 10-minute game I've already beaten to get more loot I don't need to beat it again?

It just feels like it gutted the biggest reason I enjoy RPGs - the sense of customization and development of your characters - in favor of nameless forgettable nobodies, and there's nothing in the game that replaces that or gives me any sense of reason why I'd want to play any more than that 10 minutes it takes to see the whole story play out once.

19114612.review:
One Way Heroics is adorable, but it's not super deep.

There's enough customization to keep you absorbed for a while. Once you've unlocked all the classes, defeated the demon lord, seen the end of the world, fought the darkness, and seen a few endings... It's not as interesting. The gameplay gets a little repetative, especially considering that an unlucky run might run 5-20 minutes. There's a surprising amount of hidden story in here, but I'm not sure if I'm patient enough to see it all.

But it's so cheap. So cheap. I got it for less than a dollar. For that amount, it's worth it. I've gotten about 8 hours of fun out of it so far, and that's *definitely* worth a buck.

The DLC is... meh. It makes the game harder. In the original game, a "friendly settlement" will usually include a save girl and someone selling food. In the DLC, it might be a merchant, a trainer, a mercenary, or lots of other things that won't feed you. Also, your food rots and raw meat poisons you. All this  means that running out of food is a *way* bigger issue in the DLC than in the original.

The DLC's okay--you get some classes, more achievements, and probably more plot--but I don't find it as enjoyable as the original game.

It's a fun game with plenty of options for replayability and hours of fun.

19041953.review:
I seriously enjoy this game. One of my favorite aspects of a randomly generated world is the fact that you're not going to see everything the first play through... Or the second play through... Or even the twenty-second! I still have not figured out how to recruit other party members during the journey, but I'm fine with that because I've been so preoccupied with discovering all the other things you can do with different classes.

Speaking of classes, I normally hate class systems in an RPG. When you have to devote to one for the entire game and you're not even sure if it's your favorite because you haven't got to try the others yet. But in One Way Heroics, many runs are fairly short, so you can try every class that you like. Get a feel for all of them. Then play the one you feel like playing based on your mood. It's kind of like a fighter game in that aspect; you pick a character based on the kind of match you expect to have.

Another great thing about the classes in One Way Heroics is the fact that they all have something unique and interesting to bring to the table. Each has a special skills, and each has regular skills that they perform better or with a bonus. It's balanced pretty well and it makes picking a favorite for your style of play easy.

The variety of items is the last good point I'd like to touch on. One thing I almost always start out with is increased inventory ability, because I love picking up as many items as I can and using them effectively. One Way Heroics exhibits great balance between character stats and the necessity for equipment. You can make your character strong, sure, but if you don't find a rare and powerful weapon or some really good armor, you're going to be running from the demon lord many times before you can hope to fight him.

The one down side to this game I'll mention is the character design. The artwork is a little sloppy looking, though charming in it's own way, and the character dialog, while funny at first, is a little lacking in terms of variety. Well. during gameplay anyway--Dialog is actually pretty good during cut scenes, as I am hit with something new almost every new game and end game. Finally characters feel a little flat. Even though the after story of you and the fairy continuing your journey after the world is saved is rather touching, it feels awkward because I don't really feel connected to the characters. They're too generic, but then, maybe that was intended.

All in all, great game. 9/10

(This is my first review, so I haven't developed any kind of coherent style.)

18664496.review:
[h1] A Great Time killing game, hold on Solitare, Chip's Challenge, or whatever you play to kill time, here's [b]ONE WAY HEROICS[/b][/h1]

So after playing this game for a good little bit, I have found that this game could easily be one of those games that you could play to kill time, ALOT of time. 

One of my friends sent me the game and expansion as a gift through Steam, and I tell you what, It's quite an amazing game especially for use old heads that like our RPGs and video games in general with a more retro feel to them. The graphics, by today's standards, aren't the super realistic HD sculptures that a lot of people have come to expect from video games. Instead, the graphics are more of a 16-bit sprites with beautiful choices of color palettes throughout the game. It is very easy to tell when you traverse through different environments, desolate deserts, cold artic tundra, lush beautiful forests and plains. The guards, townsfolk, and inhabitants of the world are just as carefully designed and all look unique. 

Probably one of the biggest things that makes this game so great is the gameplay. Imagine a Japanese Style Action RPG with a lot of Rogue like aspects that do nothing, but add to replay value of the game. Everything can be randomized, and like most Rogue Likes perma death is a real thing. About the only thing that you can save, aside from the game, is your character's inventory, or rather a select few items to continue playing with. You get a super awesome sword that when roots your enemies and burns them to death, and you don't really want to let it go? Well there's something called a deminisonal vault that you can use to keep that sword through multiple playthroughs. 

Speaking of that deminisonal vault, the way you get it, and use it is through things called Hero Points. You acquire Hero Points by either completing a full run of the game, or dying. If you die, by some random Dragon Knight in a structure you were checking for loot, drowning in water, or trying to climb to the point of exhaustion and just collapsing. There's also one other very unique way of dying. In this game, you visit a town and you can't revist it, you can't go back the way you came at all. This is because the Dark Lord (boss of the game) is spreading darkness throughout the realm, you touch the darkness and you die. Well the screen scrolls to the right, just like an old school platformer, but instead of being able to go back you can't because of the darkness, if you try, you die. This adds for a significant amount of challenge, you can easily get stuck in areas of the game because of mountains, walls, or whatever other obstacle that impedes your travel, and the darkness catches up and you die. Actually, every action you take, wether it's attacking an enemy, moving, using an item, casting a spell, or whatever moves the darkness closer towards you. 

The Plot is a throw a way plot you are X hero out to slay the Dark Lord and stop the spread of the darkness throughout the world. There's other campaigns that you can do that are fixed maps that have their own story as well, but it follows the same formula. 

Probably one of the coolest things about the game is Character Creation. At the beginning of the game you start with two classes, a Swordmaster Class and a Knight Class. You can chose what your sprite looks like, and also give your character perks to help with his stats, or whatever skills you have for the class. You start with three perk slots, but as you play you can unlock up to five perks. This alone gives the game that massive replay value, just to see how every other class works, in a completely different world every single time.

As you play through the game, and earn Hero Points,  you also gain new classes to run through the game with, each class, plays very differently from the other. You unlock these classes by either spending those Hero Points you've been hoarding, or by completing specific tasks in game. Aside from the Deminsional Vault, and new Classes, the Hero Points also unlock new perks for character creation.

For us retro gaming fans, especially those who are fans of RPGs that came out before everything looked "pretty" and realistic, this game is a must own. This will probably end up replacing solitare for those people.

18636482.review: Probably one of my favorite games on Steam. It is loads of fun, quite challenging, and has tons of different ends.  Since every world is different, no two games will play the same. 18590720.review:
[b]Oh my oh my, why I have I passed this up so many times before in the weekly bargain bin - there is a darn good reason this has [i]overwhelmingly[/i] positive reviews.[/b] This is such a wonderful mix of rogueLIKE (turn-based combat), and [i]Final Fantasy[/i], without the menu-based combat. Metric tons of meta-game unlockables, which I totally love. So much game here, its a shame how underpriced it is.

[i]Don't let the JRPG/RPG-Maker graphics turn you off, this is not some weekend project - it is very well crafted and totally original.[/i]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Totally addicting roguelike game
+Tons of gameplay to be had - and I haven't even touched the multiplayer/online map portion, which looks super fun
+I love the meta-game unlockables; they remind me alot of [i]Rogue Legacy[/i]
+There is also an item vault similar to in [i]ToME[/i]
+Price is stupid low
+Definately alot to learn a la [i]BoI[/i] style - knowledge is definately rewarded here
+I really appreciate games that only use the keyboard - allows for easy laptop play, but I must add that controller support is great here too
+Music is totally good classic RPG style ballads

[b]Cons:[/b]
-The graphics and JRPG structure will certainly turn alot of people off at first glance - it did for me - but it shouldn't!
-Some wonky resolution options on the bigscreen, but I did find a fix that I still need to try
-With complexity, there always comes a medium- to fairly steep learning curve

[b]Totally worth the money, hands down.[/b]

18582104.review:
For a game that regularly goes on sale for less than a dollar, it's absolutely amazing, the dlc for the game, while making the game harder, adds so much convenience to the interface. Now for the breakdown

Music
 The music is never really downbeat, though there are times when it's calmed down.
 It tends to pick up to a rousing adventure theme when combat really begins to happen
 The music in towns is really calming, to the point that I've just sat in towns listening to the music playing

 I tend to reccomend listening to the music of any game prior to purchase though, and there's an awesome playlist on youtube containing all of the music from the game.

Interface
 The interface in the base game is kind of unintuitive, with the keys being used as follows: R T W A S D Ctrl Shift

 There might have been more, but either never needed them, or they just didn't come up.

 The intro menu here is really simple, but the opportunity to rerun a map you like just because you remember its seed is awesome, but there's not much that's all that interesting in the intro menu.

 The in-game menus are interesting, but I do have just one issue in that you can "use" a bomb, by which I mean it will just explode on you. I don't know why this is an option but I accidently use the bomb instead of throwing it more often than I'd like to admit. But beyond the occasional issue with that, the menus are easy to understand, just getting into it the first time is a bit interesting.


 The interface in the expansion is much more compact with the numbers on the keyboard being used for quick acess inventory slots. The rest of the keys are: Z X C V Shift Ctrl W A S D or the arrows

The expansion makes the menus even easier to use, as well as picking up dropped items.


Gameplay
 It's a Turn based roguelike with the opportunity to overcome every map that I've come across, though it may take several attempts to do so.

The combat is really intuitive, where the combination of shift and direction makes aiming easy, and there's only one attack button, which allows you to really take advantage of the turn-based global interaction.

It is possible to get all pooped on by the spawning of the enemies, or even by travelling to the wrong bit of the map and getting stuck behind a wall of mountains, but so far, I've had only a couple of instances where this happened. 

My complaints here are really just twofold, with the first one being the bomb issue. There's a number of games I lost because of that, but it's my fault. The other is how slow the game can be on the longer runs, but the expansion allows the speeding up of movement so I no longer have this issue.

Story
Nope. not telling you. If you want to find out, do so yourself.
It is a compelling story found out through gameplay if done correctly though.


Really, as a quick sum up of all that: the game is really well put together and the expansion just tightens some controls and adds to the game as a whole. I spent $7 on this and as you can see I've put in 40-ish hours into it. I love it, and it's something that, if you like the gameplay, you'll love the game. If you don't like the aesthetics and or the gameplay, you won't really feel bad about it because you've probably spent more money on worse games.

Enjoy! I did.

This is an amazing roguelike game. Just like any other, YOU WILL DIE the first few times you try. However, you will eventually get the hang of it, and be able to survive just about any situation. For example: I recently got the plus version, and in it they added a couple new biomes and new items. One new biome is an ocean area, where there is a very large area of water. Water takes 5 times as long to navigate as dry land, and this is a major issue with the darkness chasing you. What made the area worse is that the Demon Lord (powerful boss) spawned for me right after I found the ocean. I fought for a while, before I realized I was screwed if I kept fighting. I was trapped between a very powerful enemy and an ocean that would cause my death. Luckily, I found an item that proved highly useful. Its called Magic Bridge. It forms a bridge that extends to 15 tiles in front of you. I used it over the ocean, and managed to run away for a little while, and heal. However, the bridge wasnt long enough to make it all the way over. So I was trapped once again. However, through strategic item, skill, and using my followers as bodyguards, I was able to get him down to about 10% hp. However, I couldnt survive another hit. I thought to myself "How can I possibly survive?" I was skimming my skills, and I noticed I had one more awakening left. Awakening is a skill that freezes time for 3 turns. However, you can only use it 5 times a playthrough. I used it. And on the last turn of the awakening, I managed to finish him off. It was the single most intense moment of my One Way Heroics life.

I highly advise that you get this game, and the Plus version. Easily worth the money. And with time, Im sure you too will overcome impossible odds!

18225895.review:
tl;dr- Seriously. You like JRPGs? Buy this game. You like persistant unlockables? Buy this game. You like random levels? Buy this game. This is one of my favorite games out there. Its fun to sit and play for 15 mins - or 4 hours straight.

Also - be happy knowing you're supporting 16-bit style WITHOUT USING RPGMaker. This game runs its own engine.
That in and of itself its worth it.

___________________________________________

At first glance, One Way Heroics looks like it was made on RPGMaker. It wasn't. Its a completely custom engine, from someone in Japan.

And, boy is it unique. Seriously. Yes, its an RPG. Yes, it is done in 16 bit style. But that is about the only thing that makes it anything like the RPGs back then.

The description on the store page really doesn't do it justice. It explains the base game. But it doesn't explain how incredibly addicting it is to go just "one more run". 

See, there's a bunch of dimensions - and they are slowly being swallowed up by the darkness. Meaning you can't go left for too long, as the darkness slowly advances from left to right across the screen every step you take. You are slightly faster than it, though. 

The game is turn based, so like Rogue, everything only moves when you do. Its like Rogue too, in that all you have to do is hit the attack key near an enemy  You are trying to defeat the Demon Lord who's causing the darkness, but its going to be quite a few playthroughs even on the easiest mode to beat him for the first time.

You will die. A lot. No biggie though as it has permanent unlockables. A "vault" which you can upgrade to store items in. Perks to make your char stronger. And you can either choose to adventure in a completely randomly generated realm, or you can choose one of the "online" realms, 1 of which is random, and the others of which have "specials" (a certain character is there, darkness, better items, more XP etc). The online realms change every 24 hours. There isnt multiplayer as such, however in the online realms, theres a constant scroll of a pic and brief info about each other person playing. You can also set 1 of about 20 "online messages". One of the nicest features of online is you can also encounter the "ghost" of another player in your game at the spot where they died. They help you by giving you an item they were carrying and some of their XP.

Theres also 5 game modes, eacxh slightly harder than the last, but with better items and more story. 

Oh did I mention that? Theres a story too. Each companion which you can find (and theres quite a few) has a story associated with them you can learn by talking to them. Oh, and both enemies and companions can have "prefixes". Some make them stronger, both enemies and companions. Some change dialogue with companions. (Really, EVERYONE needs to see Naughty Queen Frieda)...

The base game is I think around $4. Its totally worth it. There's also DLC, which is totally worth it as well, if you like the base game. It adds even more awesomeness.

11/10 would die again

18122456.review: It was hard to understand how the game worked at first, but after a little bit I figured it out. It's a simple game with an interesting concept. You can only move in one direction, hence the title. If you are caught on the far left side of the screen, you can die. So you always have to move forward. Each move causes the screen to move, so the more time you waste in one position, the less time you have to escape the left side of the screen. It sounds weird but you'll understand when you get into the game. Now, the game is simple, you buy equipment, level up, and defeat enemies. It's pretty difficult to fight the first boss at first, but at least you can transfer items from your first playthrough to the next one, making it easier. You can also receruit party members if your charisma is high enough. Just like in Magicite, another permanent death game, the point is to play multiple times to increase your stats and chances of survival. You'll get more bonuses to your character and it'll be easier to move on. The game is great when it's on sale! I think I got it for less than a dollar.

18030831.review:
Didn't like it. While it does feature proper randomization and varied starting options, I can't say I find it an enjoyable roguelike. 

First of all, interface is bad, no mouse support, and various dialogues during each run start / end repeat every time without ability to skip them. Also, it was obviously designed for Japanese language, the information is crammed in too tightly, and those dialogues I mentioned are like something out of a jRPG/visual novel but, you know, this is a roguelike with many retries necesseary to achieve something, so you'll see those pop up every now and then, forcing you to rapidly skim trough same lines every time!

Next, it's... I can't really say it has that much tactical depth. I mean, there are special abilities which are not very convinient to use due to interface, some of them cost stats, some can be used just few times, but due to the price you pay to use them they are only handy in extreme situations. Same with items, they run out of durability and break, so you have to spare better ones, but even then there's no depth beyond "know when it's right time to use this".

Also, can't say I enjoyed either visuals or audio. Guess I'm just not weaboo enough to enjoy Japanese style. Although if you are into this sort of thing, you should probably enjoy it.

Finally while it has some nice simple ideas, the balance is pretty shit. Like charisma is near-useless except for getting extremely rare companions, meanwhile other stats are essential for survival. While unfairness is a common thing in random roguelikes, having one of the essential stats useless outside of daily events and extremely rare occurences is just plain wrong.

All in all, this might be a pretty good simple timekiller for a weaboo, you might even enjoy the extra challenges the game offers, but for anyone not used to Japanese game design practices and aesthetics this might prove rather dull.

17829887.review:
Let's get the important things out of the way right here at the start:

Is One Way Heroics a good game? Yes.
Is it fun? Yes.
Should you buy it? Yes, especially when on sale.
Is the OWH+ DLC worth it? Yes, every steam penny you spend on it.

Now for the unnecessarily long analysis portion:

One Way Heroics is a Roguelike with large amounts of Turn-Based RPG elements. Your character grows stronger as they defeat enemies, you can equip a variety of different weapons, there are multiple character classes, and there are even quests in the game which require recruiting certain characters or speaking with a specific person (OWH+ has quests to unlock extra character classes and a quest to return a little girl to her father).

Some other mechanics the game runs on include:

- Everything moves on a grid
- You have a stamina bar that allows you to climb mountains, swim in water, and use special attacks
- You also have an energy meter which is refilled by eating food, it also provides energy for force attacks
- Every recruitable character has affinity that goes up as you travel with them or do specific things on the way such as eat a specific kind of food or kill enemies
- The recruitable characters can also be levelled up
- Weapons can be given extra attributes via scrolls or other such objects
- Most items have weight (arrows and gemstones don't) and if you exceed the weight limit, you can't move
- You can unlock various perks that help you along the way
- You can find goddess statues throughout the world which give you special boosts for the cost of levels
- The Awakening ability, which allows you to take five consecutive actions without anything else moving
- The Dimensional Vault which lets you store items from a run and take them out again for a different run
- Your weapons and armor will break after a certain number of hits, given or recieved

Mechanics specific to OWH+

- Food can go bad as time goes on
- You level up upon reaching a new area
- You can add extra parts to the starting castle with Dimensional Gold Coins you find in each run, you can also place special NPCs in these extra parts
- Extra perks that make the game harder but greatly improve your rank and score
- Tons of extra items that aren't in the regular version

The biggest and most important game mechanic however, is the darkness. The darkness is always on the left side of the screen, and if you get swallowed by it, you die. Every time you do something, be it moving, attacking, equipping an item, or even talking to someone, the darkness moves forward. This means that ever action has to count, and you have to really think of possible risk vs. reward of doing specific things. Because if you go into a dungeon and can't get back out in time, you will be consumed and that'll be it. You can use the Awakening ability to get away, but it only has five uses per run, and the world goes on for a long way (10,000 km if I recall correctly).

Overall, a really good experience, and one I highly recommend.

17745124.review:
So, after finally clearing the game and seeing 95% of what it has to offer, I figured I could give my two cents to people considering wether to buy this game. 
Simple version? Buy it. Longer version:

Plot

The setting itself is quite simple. You are the hero, saving the world from darkness that's devouring everything. And to do that you have to kill Demon Lord, who's somewhere over there ------>  
That's basically it, but there is so much more, if you care to search for it. Game is filled with alternative endings, hidden classes, party members... Well, you get the point. It actually makes me really sad that only 4,6% of players have invested time to complete the game in some other way, than beating the Demon Lord, as they are missing out on great plot, that's just hidden within seemingly generic RPG storyline.

Gameplay

As you embark to find the Demon Lord somewhere over that ------> way in randomly generated world, the said darkness is chasing you, destroying villages, killing the monsters and, most important of all, keeping you from stopping.  On your way you'll encounter multitude of different terrain types, villages, dungeons, enemies, merchants, friends, (friendly) ghosts of other players and so on. The further you go, the harder game becomes.
Combat is very much in retro RPG style. You act ---> your party members act ----> enemies act. Extra agility can get you (or enemies) multiple moves in a row. There are status ailments, buffs, critical hits and plenty other things involved as well.

Difficulty

The game lets you pick the difficulty setting from Walk in a park, Afternoon Stroll, Grueling Campaign or Inhumane odysseu, but even the Walk in a park isn't exactly a cakewalk for newcomer, while Inhumane Odysseu often catches even experienced players by surprise. You also choose your class, perks, and wether you'd like to start with some items from your previous misadventures, so game lets you have very much control over the level of difficulty.

Overall

I enjoyed this game immensely. When i got it for around 0,60€, I felt like I was robbing the developer, because this game is a rare gem that has great potential. So I was just happy to pay the 5-ish € for the new DLC, as I felt I had finally paid him back.
The game is addictive (albeit a bit repetitive), and easily triggers the "ONE MORE RUN" -feeling, that made me waste many evenings while trying to overcome hardest ordeals the game had to throw at me.

17703158.review:
So, you want to know if I recommend this game do you?
I do!

[h1]Heres why![/h1]
[b]Don't judge the book by its cover[/b]
Countless choices to make, which could make or break run as the longer you progress the strong the demonlord becomes. However what if you don't want to fight the demonlord? Befriend him, and take him to fight to the true boss[spoiler] The ever growing darkness you had run from the whole time![/spoiler]

[b]Gear/Items galor[/b]
Progressing through the world will net you countless weapons and armor. But the fun doesn't end there! You will occasionaly find scrolls that can enchant your weapon/armor to make them stronger,ignite enemies, confuse enemies, and root them in place. Really like your weapon? Store it in the vault to use it in your next run to get an upper hand earlier. 

[b]Allies/Quests[/b]
Through out your time playing, you will come across allies that can help you in various ways and interact with other characters that might have otherwise attacked you if you didn't have them with you. You might find allies that only fight others might have unique abilities to help you get good items and others... are a little bit unique in thier own way. Some of the allies you come across have quests that they ask you to help them with and reward you for completing it often with strong gear you cant get else where.

[b]Countless Unlocks[/b]
Achivements for death can be used to unlock perks, classes faster, or extra vaultspace which in turn makes you upcoming runs easier or allow you to do things you couldn't without them. Get extra gold at the start to make use of the random shop/fortune teller that spawns at the start. Possibly get extra Charm to get an ally ealier to help you. Bring a loyal pet to assist you in fights that levels beside you. The amount of things you can discover and unlock are insane.

Now, with that out of the way. There are infact some flaws to the game that might be a turn off to some people and here are a few i have noticed.

[h1]Turn offs for some[/h1]
[b]Grindy Gameplay[/b]
You are not going to be that strong from the very start, and it will take quite a few runs to get up to a good standing. Some runs can last up to an hour in length just to complete. Even some areas can't be accessed without the proper items(However this can be avoided by killing the npc/breaking down the door!)

[b]Repetitive Gameplay[/b]
As you might have noticed all you pretty much do is move right, and that restricts you to explores all of the map sometimes. With the only way to unlock perks/extra vaultspace is by building up enough points from winning/losing a run. the first 30~40 minutes of the game are going to be fighting only the first boss due to it being to hard/impossible to fight the other boss/achieve the other ending.

[b]Easy/Hard Difficulty[/b]
Some parts of the game are extremely easy and don't take much effort to complete where others can take hours to achieve and sometimes go wasted when you die and forget to save. With a learning curb that can make some parts of the game a cakewalk while simply not knowing can add time onto your run.

[h1]Overall Opinion 8/10[/h1]
[b] If you think you might enjoy the game, go ahead and buy it as its rather suprising how much there is in store for you![/b]

Best .87 cents of my life.

It's a nice little roguelike with a twist. Said twist works out surprisingly well. It's not very expensive and it's pretty enjoyable. 17626403.review:
Very hard to get used to the controls for some reason, but once you do the game is amazing, i suggest playing it while watching a walk-through for it so that you can better understand the world you've entered. The game itself isn't inherently hard, but you have so little to work with that it takes getting used to. Warning to new players to stay away from Golems, they have set spawn locations per world and they are nasty with or without an axe (which does more damage to them).

Characters can be unlocked with points rewarded for your progress after each death or by completeing a certain feat. You can use these points to get a vault and add space to said vault. The Vault NPC is in the set spawn for each character. I recommend always keeping a Key of Seals in the Vault if you manage to come across one. Keys of Seals are used on Temples and can give you Holy Artifacts. My first holy artifact was an Axe that crushed everything before me. By the time it had worn down i found another temple and another key of seals, and got a Holy Spear and Holy Chest Armor. Made it the last 80 km to the Demon Loard and killed him with no struggle. 

I've only gotten 2.8 hrs of playtime in the time of this review, but i could easily put 200 hours into it. It's cheap for it's value of entertainment, and if you end up in a poor spawn you can always just continue again. 

More tips
-Always buy from a Chef When/If you reach a town. They seem pricey but in actuality they are cheap and extremely valuable.
-This game is about Trade-offs, you may end up choosing things that are detrimental to the world you spawn on.
-More expensive is not always better, especially when you do not have a high enough Item-Appraisal to know what you are buying.
-Randomly Generated worlds always have their problems, the largest map wrecker in this game is large mountain walls that you have to climb. They take a great deal of turns to climb and eat your stamina, if you find yourself having to climb mountains frequently you will die, and you may want to explore a different route or a new world entirely.
-Chests in the water are also death-traps but if you can manage it, they may offer useful loot.
-Teleportation Pills will save you from Bandits, Bears, or Golems.
-Axes will destroy walls and chests with ease for better dungeon navigation.
-Bows and Lances will help you kill your enemies from a distance, very beginner friendly weapons, unless you have no arrows. 

Negatives about this game - 

The loss of your character after completeing the game is without a doubt a loss, but the ability to save his gear makes up for it, despite the fact it is battered and will probably have to be repaired despite my deep loathing of the brittle debuff.

17515805.review:
A surprisingly excellent speed-run game. I really mean it. More action-adventure than RPG (as you have to really hurry and can't chat for long) and you push on and try to survive with your single life. Very few saves and it is easy to die, but the good news: there is a dimensional vault where you can store your favourite items for use by your next character. You can also expand the vault.

If you win or bravely perish after achieving some advancing, you can then unlock perks, new classes and a larger vault. So it rewards commitment. I really enjoyed playing it, and it did take me a few deaths to really get it and get through.

Then I put my grand sword and scaled shield into the dimensional vault and unlocked the pirate and hunter classes. As I write this I am pleased with my victory and looking forward to my next speed-run of One Way Heroics.

It is great fun and a challenge. Try it.

17484357.review:
Interesting? Yes. Entertaining? Yes. Cutesy? Yes. Frustrating? Perhaps. Addictive? Most definitely.

One Way Heroics is a nice little game created in Wolf RPG Editor. When I first played it, I was excited. Games like this always caught my eye and the dialogue the characters/NPC's have only made it more fun. A tad bit silly, but nonetheless still great. So, I started it up and was ready to play. I thought it would be rather simple. It looked easy enough to do; Avoid the darkness consuming the world. In other words, avoid getting scrolled off the screen. I fought monsters along the way. It was very tedious, sure, but entertaining. Then, finally, I encountered the boss, the Demon Lord. I swear, I have never been defeated so quickly by a boss in my entire lifetime. 

Eager to defeat him, I retried. And thus started the endless cycle of trying to successfully defeat the Demon Lord.

This game is a bundle of joy, frustration, and addiction. You are provided with numerous classes to choose from and to defeat the Demon Lord with. Each world is randomly generated so there are always new surprises to look forward to. You are also given opportunities to save here and there, so if you are absolutely certain this particular world is suitable for you to achieve your goals, then save at a save point and viola! No need to worry about losing your progress. There are also a number of skills you can obtain, as well as weapons, armor, items, partners - you name it. In addition to the gameplay, the soundtrack is beautiful, enjoyable, and is certainly enough to keep you motivated. Obviously, the graphics are pixelated (with the exception of when character dialogue pops up), but the art is nice and I will admit that I find some of the monsters rather cutesy.

I somehow managed to hop off this game for a while (which was good because if I hadn't, it would've been an unhealthy addiction for me), but I have taken note that the One Way Heroics Plus DLC is coming around Steam sometime soon, so I'll definitely be playing soon again. Do I recommend this game? Of course I do! If you choose to purchase this game, I now wish you all the good luck on your journey to defeat the Demon Lord!

17451195.review:
[b]One Way Heroics[/b]

[b]"Izquierda = Muerte. Derecha = Aventura"[/b]

Este Rogue-Like RPG Japones muestra una atrayente portada de lo que podria ser un juego del cual podria llevarnos a nuestros juegos de infancia, los RPG 2D los cuales eran tan simples y tan dificiles, que sin importar que, pasabamos horas y horas de adicción e intriga jugando para seguir entendiendo el juego y su historia (habiendo una en la cual enfocarnos). Siguiendo la musica que acompaña sus simples mecanicas y combates, esos juegos nos dejaban una gran satisfacción a la hora de jugarlos.
Este JRPG promete eso y mucho mas superando expectativas... Si estas preparado a correr a tu derecha.

[b]Historia/Tematica:[/b]

"La Oscuridad" ha sido invocada por el "Demon Lord" para que con unico proposito, devore todo lo que llegue a pasar por delante. Animales y humanos que sean tragados por "La Oscuridad" han de poder sufrir la muerte o la mutación de seres malignos esparcidos por el planeta para seguir haciendo estragos a medida que La Oscuridad sigue avanzando lentamente desde la parte izquierda hasta la derecha para seguir cumpliendo su labor.
Tu siendo el heroé del reino el cual todos colocan tus esperanzas en ti, has sido asignado por el rey con la gran misión de detener a "La Oscuridad" matando al "Demon Lord" acompañado de tu fiel acompañante consejera "Fairy Iris"... Pero las cosas a veces no solo pueden ser como creemos.

[b]Arte Visual:[/b]

2D totalmente atrayente y muy nostalgico. Desde las montañas, hierbas mas pequeñas, colores y detalles infimos de la armadura de los personajes, y los retratos de los personajes en la parte inferior izquierda ya dibujado los cuales dependiendo del 

personaje pueden cambiar ciertos detalles faciales del mismo. Para nada pesado a la hora de jugar que se hace totalmente comodo y calza a la perfeccion con la sintonia de la aventura.
A primera vista te quedas un poco impresionado al ver cierta linea negra al lado izquierdo del mapa ya siendo un poco mas sobresaliente... Mas de uno caminara directamente hacia alla, asi consegui el primer logro.

[b]Arte Auditivo/Musical:[/b]

Mientras mas vas caminando, escapando de la oscuridad y luchando contra los enemigos, monstruos, bandidos, hasta llegando a pueblos y pasando por otro tipo de ambientes, la musica va a ir cambiando de una forma tan grata o hasta perfecta para el momento lo cual nunca hara que uno se aburra de ella. Mas de una vez quedaras mas y mas tiempo queriendo seguir jugando sin importar cuantas veces mueras debido a cuanto te puede absorber su musica recordando hasta los videojuegos de tu infancia.

[b]Controles e Interfaz:[/b]

Para nada dificiles para el usuario llegarse a acostumbrar a ellos, en cuestion de solo unos pocos minutos ya se puede 
familiarizar con ellos. Pero en momentos de peligro debemos de ser sumamente cuidadosos ya que un solo movimiento nos puede costar la partida a causa de los nervios o no pensar nuestros movimientos con cierta perspicacia. Su "Menú" y "Opciones" son totalmente comodos y gratas al usuario de usar sin ningun tipo de complicación para lograr mayor enfoque del mismo en su gameplay.

[b]Jugabilidad:[/b]

One Way Heroics es un "Rogue-like Rol JRPG Indie" por turnos. Por cada cantidad de movimientos que hagamos, y dependiendo del ataque que hagamos (Y habilidades), "La Oscuridad" avanzara. No solo deberemos preocuparnos por mantener nuestra distancia contra la desconocida y malvada oscuridad que mantiene un ritmo muy constante, sino que cierto tipo de obstaculos como montañas y lagos los cuales al pasar através de ellos nos pueden llegar a quitar entre 5-10 turnos mas "Stamina".
Mataremos monstruos para ganar experiencia y subir de nivel a medida que vaya pasando la travesia.
Pasaremos através de dungeons las cuales nos veremos un tanto obligados a medir nuestros movimientos ya que, si tardamos mucho tiempo entre abrir los cofres y "explorar" nos podriamos ver atrapados entre "La oscuridad y la pared". Ciertamente puedes romper la pared. Y... ¿Si no da tiempo? ¿Si el arma se rompe antes de poder romper la pared?
Las armas tienen sus limites de usos, sean dagas, espadas, hachas, varitas, escudos, petos, etc, etc. Muchas veces deberemos de tener cuidado en que armas que queremos conservar para reparar o tirar para seguir teniendo capacidad en nuestro inventario y seguir moviendonos, ya que constamos de una "Capacity" (capacidad) de cuanto "Weight" (peso) podremos cargar con nosotros. Si llevamos mas del limite, no nos podremos mover, causando que nuestros movimientos sean anulados. "La Oscuridad" tambien se detendra si tu no te mueves, modo del juego que permite darte cierto descanso mientras decides que agarrar y desechar, pero los monstruos no lo daran.

- Diferentes clases con sus diferentes habilidades cada cual las cuales iras desbloqueando con "Hero Points" al igual que los "Perks"
- "Perks" que se compraran para la mejora de tu personaje cuando se empieza una nueva partida.
- "Hero Points" los cuales se conseguiran por tu record en tu partida despues de finalizar el juego o morir.
- Vault Dimensional en el cual seremos capaces de guardar cualquier objeto para futuras partidas.
- 4 modos de juegos, uno mas dificil que otro monstrando cada uno beneficios y contras, sin contar su "Maniac Mode".
- Humor inocente y sano en ciertos momentos de juego y entre "Loading screens"
- Precio totalmente bajo para una gran experiencia de aventura y muchas horas de entretenimiento.

9.5/10

Mentor/Curator de [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/VaomGaming#]Vaom Gaming[/url]

17233960.review:
I love this game, however I *really* wish the flaws werent so blistering.

-Your weight limit is abysmal. You can literally start the game, pick up a SINGLE weapon and you're already overencumbered. 
- Your stat increases per level are completely random. You could literally get nothing but SP upgrades from Level 1 - 15 and you'd be just as weak as when you started. 
- The Identify System is unfair. Like I said earlier, your weight limit is terrible so, you end up picking up a Sword???, you have no idea what it is... and because the system is so unfair, odds are you wont Identify the weapon. You can't bring it with you because it's too heavy. It's just not fair. And considering Item Shops rarely have Apraisal Scrolls and an Apraiser is Expensive / Sometimes to Hard to Come by.... It's almost wiser to just ignore weapons.
- You have no idea how powerful your enemies are. One Bat could be the easiest bat in the game and the next one could possibly 1 shot you. Who knows? It's not consistent. I wish it was. 

Now, all of these things by themselves are not bad... but put together, it's almost unforgiving how hard the game is.

But still...

The music is *amazing*.
The gameplay is addicting
And you have a Shared Loot system between games that helps you out.

And I'd say it makes up for all that.

17215702.review: One Way Heroics is a neat little roguelike game with a fun mechanic pressing you ever forward to the right. 17194468.review:
I bought this one during the Summer Monster Sale for very little money, but it also brought me very little enjoyment.

The game feels really, really basic. 
You move towards the right on a wide plain/desert/forest (terrains have different effects), fight some monsters, explore some dungeons (really just rooms with a few monsters and an item chest in them).
The terrain is generated procedurally, so each run is a little different.

Combat is really simple. You either attack with your weapon or use abilities.
There are little tactical moves beyond moving so that you get the first attack, or running away from stronger monsters.

After a certain distance travelled, the boss appears.

In case you die, you get a little lecture (like "you should use your time travel skill in dire situations") and then get some points with which you can unlock other characters and perks.
You can also put some of your items in a dimensional stash, to have them present in your next run.

I can honestly not understand the massive praise this game receives, maybe I just did not "get" it.
So I have no hard feelings downvoting it, despite its very low price.

17182988.review:
I have to say--I'm surprised I hadn't heard of this game at least in passing before the Summer 2015 Sale. Considering the fact that it was purchasable for less than a dollar--as well as its high approval rating--I figured I'd give it a try.

The game's concept is a fun play on a classic video game trope--the left side of the screen is literally a huge wave of annihilation, and anything that is consumed by it is obliterated. It's up to a multiverse-travelling hero (the player) to face this apocalyptic force and save the world!

For the price, I've found the game to be thoroughly enjoyable and surprisingly diverse. As many others have mentioned before me, the soundtrack is great. There's a large number of tunes for each biome, enemy encounters, and structures in the world. The number of potential classes to play as and the different ways to win also gives it a nice boost to replayability. A large variety of variables can be changed to make the game easier or harder, depending on your preference.

---GRIPES
There's only a few personal gripes I've had so far (and they are small). First, while there is a large number of biomes for the world, I would have liked more types of natural and constructed obstacles. Water is one such element present in the game, but it tends to be little more than a mild variation in the terrain. Occasionally, lakes will spawn with chests in the middle of them, but otherwise they're fairly generic and feel a little short of their potential in the game's unique setup.

Another minor issue is that some classes are noticeably harder to play with. I'd like to play more as an Adventurer, for example, but the class's physical weakness and emphasis on running away makes it difficult to level up and increase their equipment load (something this thief-like class desperately needs in order to maximize their chest-looting!).

---OVERALL
Overall, it's a fun game that I'm still enjoying at the point of this review. I should warn that--like every other game--it's not necessarily for everyone. If you're not a fan of roguelikes or RPGs, you might have some difficulty getting into the live-grind-die-repeat cycle you'll quickly recognize in the game. There's also a noticeable manga/anime influence in the art and storytelling style,  which might clash with some players (personally I enjoyed it, particularly the game's humor).

I should also mention that the game seems to have an expansion that adds content such as more companions, classes, and gameplay elements. I unfortunately haven't had the chance yet to try it--it's currently unavailable on Steam--but the presence of its Achievements here hints at its eventual release.

Personally, I've enjoyed this little hidden gem, and feel that my less-than-a-dollar was well-spent.

16902885.review:
[h1]Un desafío curioso[/h1]

Según empiezas a jugar te plantan en mitad de un mundo que está siendo engullido por la oscuridad, sin poder ir marcha atrás deberás avanzar sin descanso para encontrar el origen de la misma y salvar a todos de la muerte (sin descanso, sin descanso.....no, que si no te mueves la oscuridad no avanza). En tus numerosos intentos por salvar al mundo te acompañará Iris, un hada muy cuca que te dará consejos de cómo mejorar después de acabar cada partida (bien sea porque has muerto o porque acabas el juego).


En lo que respecta a [u]jugabilidad[/u], hay varios modos de dificultad, diferentes clases desbloqueables, muchos beneficios iniciales entre los que elegir (un máximo de 5 cada partida, también se desbloquean según avanzas) y un mundo que se expande hasta el infinito que explorar (con puntos de guardado repartidos aleatoriamente). Los [u]controles[/u] son simples y los explican al principio, pero no conozco la compatibilidad con mandos. Los gráficos son bonitos, con efectos especiales escasos pero llamativos, los monstruos están bien logrados, se ve el esfuerzo. La [u]música[/u] me mola, ayuda a sumergirse en el juego y va cambiando según avanzas en el mapa y cambias de bioma, no es muy variada pero está chula. La [u]duración[/u] del juego varía dependiendo del punto desde donde se mire: matar al jefe final en modo fácil lleva menos de una hora, pero pasarse el juego en los demás modos, desbloquear los oficios, encontrar los personajes secretos, etc. (que es la miga real del juego) lleva muchas horas. Yo he jugado unas 15 y tengo poco más de la mitad acabado, y aunque no vayas a desbloquear nada, es guay ir por el mapa matando bichos y subiendo de nivel sin parar.

[b]En general me ha gustado mucho, es divertido y tiene un formato que no había visto hasta ahora. Vale mucho la pena pagar los 3 eurillos que cuesta.[/b]

-------------------------------------------------------

One Way Heroics is a side-scrolling rouge-like turn-based RPG in which the Player attempts to claim victory by defeating their evil adversary. However, even in defeat, one can carry over items and gain hero points, which can be used to unlock new perks and classes. The game even gives you advice based on how well you did on your run.

As for playtime, the game varies on a case-by-case basis. Although there's a wide range of things to do- find companions, unlock epilogues, beat the game without using x, maniac mode, and other achievements, one may find themselves interested in some things more than others. 

For the people who run out of these things, the game offers daily campaigns, all with unique aspects, whether that includes no level ups, a companion off the start, or all NPCs being merchants.

All things considered, there's a lot of value here for a game that's only $3.49, and One Way Heroics Plus, a DLC expansion, is coming soon. How soon? As of this review, the acheivements are up for the expansion.

I highly recommend the game. The amount of content and humor in this game is definitely worth the money, especially when it goes on sale.

A rouge-like/rpg hwhere you must keep moving to avoid the darkness (AKA the dark void of death).
You first begin the game with the hero (you) selecting a class and a variety of perks to aid you on your quest. You can enter a randomly generated world or scenarios that change in real time. Depending on what mode you choose, the dark lord will appear at a certain time during your playthrough. You must defeat him to beat the game but this is no easy feat without proper equipment or items. Of course, there are dungeons and towns but you have to plan how to get in and out safely throughly without being eaten alive by the void. If you die on a playthrough, you can store items you had in the dimensional vault and use them on the next playthrough. You also accumulate hero points after each playthrough in which you can spend these points on extra vault space or hidden perks or classes for your next run. The amont of points you get depends on how well you did on your last playthrough.
A nice, time-killing game overall with buckets full of replayability but try not to swim in lava. Can you reach the end of the world?

There are 3 available resolutions.  None are wide screen.  One is so small that my phone actually has a larger screen.  Terrible.

The resolution in general is very poor.  Again, paying homage does not mean turning the negative aspects of something up to 11.  

There are numerous interface issues.  EG, why doesn't moving into an enemy attack them?  

Overall, I cannot recommend this.  It's an interesting idea done poorly.
