Short answer: Reccomended for completionists, peopel who love NG+, and achievement hunters. If you like to complete a game and put it away, your experience may be lacking.



This review is somewhat late, as I beat it several months ago. It only took me about 4-6 playthroughs if I remember right. I think I only unlocked 2 additional classes and barely any of the other content, as I was able to "win" through the luck of the RNG. I am someone who does not mind restarting games over and over due to dying and learning, but I can't say I like replaying a game once I've beat it.

One Way Heroics has fairly standard roguelike combat which I got the hang of fairly easily having played other games. The darkness adds an additional layer to this, almost making it like chess - you have to be able to plan your moves several steps ahead, taking into account each enemy's movement speed, movement patterns, item locations, and whether you might get trapped by the terrain. This can all be done fairly rapidly in most areas outside towns and dungeons. The game, being a rogelike, has a decent amount of teaching through experience and playthroughs.

The big big big gripe I have with the game, and is the primary reason I wish I could give a "mixed" rating? I managed to kill the dark lord before I think I should have been able to. I discovered one of the special artifact items and managed to fight him inside a town. Just a single artifact, my level wasn't that high. I truly expected him to be harder. Then I expected that to not be all and for the devs to pull a "Disc 1 final boss" on me. But no, the Big Bad of the game can be defeated by simply holeing up in an inn with a single artifact weapon and blowing all your items and special abilities.  I had no longer felt a real desire to play it afterwards.

However, this is my personal taste. While I find the idea of NG+ and completing a game many many times fairly dull (in most cases) for those people who DO like that sort of gameplay, this is a decent offering. I didn't encounter many, if any bugs in my playing, and the visuals are uniformly presented with nothing that seemed out of place. Worth the money for that kind of player, and having gotten it on sale and with the addition of trading cards I can't say it wasn't worth the 69 cents I paid for it, if not more.

16477164.review:
This weird little game is an absolute delight.

You're a generic JRPG hero in a generic JRPG kingdom who has to keep moving east because a fog of darkness is coming in from the west and erasing everything it touches. The way this works in play is that every step you take causes the map to scroll to the right. It's a turn-based system like you see in most roguelikes, except instead of creeping around a dungeon at your leisure, you're trying to climb up the down escalator. Every now and then the evil wizard responsible for the death fog warps in and tries to kill you for a few dozen turns, but if you can get strong enough you can kill him and win the game.

Loot what you can as you go and just keep moving. You can duck into a dungeon in the hopes of finding a few treasure chests, but you run the risk of not being able to find an exit before the darkness swallows the building. It never stops being a challenge and you always have to think about what you're trying to do.

"Winning" by killing the bad guy is relatively easy. The REAL point of the game is to find secrets and alternate endings.

16476325.review:
=HEADS UP=
I had a review before this one about the game being good. This stays of course but i had to clarify some points and fix this old messy review that i made before.

=INFO ABOUT THE REVIEW=
1. My reviews tend to be a bit longer. If that is the case please be patient and read everything.
2. This review is about my point of view and opinion. [If you disagree on a certain point or want to correct me: Be reasonable or i will ignore your comment.]
3. If you want to try to change my opinion with arguments that make no sense in any way then please do not comment at all.

=REVIEW=
Now what can i say about this game? That it is worth the money. It is a small game with only one purpose for you. Go forth and kill stuff. But there is a twist to it. The World is ending and you are the legendary hero to venture out and try to get ahead of what is coming after you to kill you. And what is that right behind you? Pure Darkness.

This game leads in a certain direction and that one is Right. You go as far as you can get to meet at the end the Bad guy to stop the End of the World. But that is not an easy task. Even though this game is semi roguelike you wont have that much trouble with it like other roguelike games. Over the time of you playing you will die. But everytime you can transfer items into a little box that is between the dimensions. And as soon as you visit a new world you can decide if you want to take it with you or not. This makes the game a bit more enjoyable and easier for you. But in the end it depends on you how it ends.

The game brings you into a randomly generated world. Here will the Adventure begin and here you can do whatever you want. Go on and kill some bad guys. You are the Hero. Go into the Taverns and buy gear and let the people help you. Or just kill them and their guards. That is right. You are allowed to do everything you want. Kill, destroy and so on and so forth. But there is a nice twist to it. If you are the great Hero you are able to find people that want to help you defeating the bad guy. And since everyone trusts you they will not attack you when seeing you. If you do attack other people though the game will punish you. The word goes around very fast and in other inns or taverns the guards will recognize you for what you did and will try to kill you. But not only the guards will turn aggressive but also the other people.

So it is up to you what will happen in the game. At the very end it is the bad guy who you want to kill. But it depends on you how easy or hard this may be.

If you want simplicity while being punishing this is the game for you!

Story: Not much to say, you're trying to build yourself up to fight the Dark Lord so that you can stop the increasingly spreading darkness. You collect items, use abilities and level up as you go along and fight, find dungeons, dropped loot, etc.

Gameplay: Simple, but it's effective and quite honestly it's a good reason to pick it up. If you don't possess a controller for the more complicated games, this game would do you a service. I find that the diaganol facings to be difficult and often find myself getting beat up by multiple enemies by the time I should have killed a few but it's overall goodly.

Music: Simple, again, but definitely uplifting and sets the tone appropriately. Any good game should take note of this and be inspired, you don't need a weird soundtrack to get attention, just quality music.

Online: Uh... didn't see any option for it, it's single player and a few things can be done as a shoutout but it's not a multiplayer game by any means.

Overall: 8.5/10 Shows that you can still enjoy simple games and have fun with it. I docked the 1.5 off for the facing issue as it can end your game really quick.

Replayability: As endless as you are.

The best classical final fantasy game that had never been created by square enix.

Can get repetitive, but not bad if you are up for a challenge. Yes, it gets repetitive. The roguelike curtain the game hides itself behind is a huge illusion here, don't be fooled by it. 16008200.review:
An amazing indie RPG. It can be considered a roguelike, but permadeath is not really present. However, the game rewards those who make it to the end without dying or saving (yes, you can save). So basically, it's you who decide the kind of experience you want. And there's the variety you expect for this kind of game: 8 classes, 8 difficulty levels, lots of customizable weapons and armor (which will break with frequent use) and accessories, enemies, maps, NPC's, endings, daily updated campaigns with special conditions, cool music, art and animation. Like the game says, the only constant is darkness. You will always need to go to the right of the map, as the left is constantly destroyed. And it all works well. Definitely worth it's price, because there's a lot of replayability, the game is addictive and you won't get bored soon.
I also strongly recommend it's "Plus" DLC, because it is a true expansion to an already great game, adding lots of content like 3 new classes, tons of new items, new area types, new enemies and NPC's, 2 new companions, and 12 new epilogues, including a new, hard final boss. The DLC may be expensive when compared to the "base" version, but since the "base" version is usually cheap, the DLC cost will feel balanced if you consider the total amount of content you're getting. The DLC also installs like a new game, separated from the "base" game with a launcher. This is cool because some aspects were balanced and tweaked, so you can go back to the "base" version at any time if you like. However, you can only import your save to the "Plus" version. If, like me, you done everything in the "base" game and want more, this is for you. There's plenty of new content here (around 50%) while the game still feels the same (which is great). For the same reason, if you didn't liked the "base" game, you won't like the "Plus" content. If you're a new player, i recommend jumping straight to the "Plus" version, because you'll get the best One Way Heroics experience to date, with all the content from the "base" version. Now this is DLC done right.

15972570.review: A very fun game for those who like to pick up and play games in short sessions, and for those who are fond of deep-rooted games that they can delve in for hours. OWH is a very interesting RPG that forces you to continually advance in your journey, as backtracking or lollygagging in the same area for too long will surely end in death. The game gives you fun classes to unlock and play, as well as neat and very useful perks to select for your character to help them along the way. The game does include permadeath to an extent, allowing you to save the game if need-be, but you are encouraged to start over upon death, as it allows you to level up characters and stats, unlock new classes, and transfer unique items through the dimensional chest. In this respect, this game isn't a hardcore Roguelike, but moreso a Roguelite, making death encouraging other than punishing. Add to this the great resource management system, the many stats and equipment you can find and upgrade on your quest, and you'll find a very fun game to kill a few minutes on, but at the same time, can easily cause you to sink countless hours into.

15924440.review:
When I first saw the game One Way Heroics it looked like something that could fill my spare time.
I decided to give it a shot for 3 bucks and this game blew me away.

This might sound like i am giving this game more credit than needed, but this has quickly turned into one of my favorite games to this date.
Of course the game has some flaws, but the good points of this game make it all. Let me give you a summary

This 2D Rogue-like RPG puts you in a world where the end is on it's way, and it is close! Every step that you make, every action that you do, will cause the end to draw closer and closer.
With dungeons, towns, npcs, monsters, holy items and companions spread all over the place, it quickly becomes a game where you have to think how much you can risk for opening that one chest that might give you a great item.

The first time you will complete the game will be in about your first hour of play ( getting to the end isn't that hard on the easiest difficulty) but with daily challenges, increased difficulty maps, secret endings (that i won't spoil) and a ton of classes to complete the game with. You will find yourself a new challenge almost every single day.

The game plays good, has controller support, has a good learning curve, and it makes you feel like a real hero when you accomplish something.

The cons?
Well if you don't like dying a lot, then this is not the game for you. One mistake or wrong decision can get you trapped and sometimes the game will be unfair to you.
Sometimes you will see the game paused with the message "loading map" which is a slight setback in pace.
Classes are a little bit unbalanced (in my opinion this only adds more challenge for those willing to take the risk)
Maybe if you are really looking for a complex story in a game this might be a let down. (You are the hero, save the day, thats about it)
But that is right about it for the Cons.

In short, while I only have 9 hours currently into the game, it feels like it has been minutes.
If you are looking for a cheap game that is worth the price, and that will consume your time like there is no tomorrow, you will not be disappointed with One Way Heroics.

15909655.review:
This game is a fun Roguelike dungeon crawler where the entire world is your "dungeon". In this game the world is being engulfed by darkness and you have to outrun it while killing enemies, collecting treasure, and recruiting teammates along the way. Whats more is that each teammate has their own story you gradually learn as they travel with you as well as several alternate endings involving them. The goal of the game is to stop the darkness from spreading which you do by defeating the Dark Lord who appears after 400km (Walk in the park mode) or randomly set distances in every other mode. With Walk in the park (easy) mode the Dark Lord only spawns once but chases you indefinitely until either of you dies while with other modes the Dark Lord will despawn if he doesn't kill you within 3 hours game time (aprox 27 actions) and it's spawn timer will reset.

After each attempt win or loose, the dungeon crawler portion of the game kicks in. Your performance will be rated and you will get an amount of hero points based on how well you did. These hero points are used to purchase bonuses to make your future attempts easier such as new perks, more dimensional vault room, and new classes. After your performance is rated if you already have the vault unlocked you are free to move your most important items to the vault which can be withdrawn at the start of your next attempt. I'd also like to point out that this game is very informal both through your fairy companion who answers your questions and through the tips you get if you die which actually analyzes how you died

Overall it's a really fun game I like it

It's really fun. You'll stumble around for hours until you start to figure out the little secrets to winning. By no means easy, but despite the simple nature of the game it completely hooks you and you lose about 20 hours in a week to it.

If you want to know what it plays like, imagine how Binding of Issac uses seeds to determine items and layout (only you're not punished for using them), then imagine you play bumper cars (ie ram them) with enemies to damage them and finally  add some "multiplayer" where you can see progress of other adventures in the same seed. If they die, you can find their ghosts and get free stuff. Then imagine all this on a auto scroller.

Talking about it really isn't the same as playing it. It's really robust, despite the simplicity. There's like 8 classes, and you can fully customize your starting stats and abilities, which really changes everything. Great game, and it's dirt cheap. An absolutely amazing little game combining aspects of roguelikes, classic JRPGs, and even a little bit of action, all mixed into a nicely paced, well humoured game. 

As with many games that it takes its roguelike elements from, the game has the capacity to simply drop you on your head and kill you off at the start, but the same randomness almost always results in a fun experience - if a little frustrating at times. On top of the charming little world that has been set up for you to heroically... walk... oneway... is an array of secrets and unlockables to make life a little bit easier, or prepare you for the next difficulty up - and make no mistake, you WILL need the help!

The ability to take items from your completed runs and keep them for your next budding adventurer is extremely helpful - playing without this function is extremely difficult, but rewarding!

A game with random elements cant help but occasionally turn evil on you as a player, but all things considered, this is an excellent little game that, unlike other RPGs, doesnt need a huge time investment - though you might find yourself spending that time anyway! Incredible value for money gives this a real thumbs up!

15632782.review:
One Way Heroics might look like a cheap and generic jrpg made in rpg-maker but it's definitely not the case.

The game is a procedurally generated turn-based roguelike with many interesting features. One of the most noticable ones is that the game takes place on a world map, each move will take you one turn and the darkness on the left side of the screen will draw closer. Basically as you move and battle across the world, darkness will consume everything behind you. Be it an enemy, friendly npc, objects or the entire terrain. You have to avoid it at all costs. During your journey you can find various loot and treasures. From simple weapons and armors up to supplies and precious magic scrolls. The rpg mechanics are fairly generic, you defeat enemies and gain level points which can be spent later on cetain spots on the map. Although you still increase your stats normally by gaining experience. Various weapons and armors have different attributes. Scrolls and magic items might have special abilities, pretty much the usual roguelike stuff.

Combat is extremely simple and only requires you to attack the enemy by pressing one key, then a series of dice rolls will determine everything. It's not that engaging but yet very enjoyable mainly due to the smooth controls and fast pace of the game. Your character has certain special abilities though that require stamina points which are automatically generated as long as your energy is high enough. Energy is another ressource and acts mostly as a starvation meter. You lose energy with each term and depending on the terrain, you might lose even more. You refill your energy by consuming various food items.

Now let me explain the goal of the game and perhaps one of it's more compelling features. As soon as you start a new run, your goal is to defeat the Demon Lord which appears in 400km in the world map. During those 400km, you want to level up and get the most loot in order to prepare for the final encounter. But due to the darkness, time  management is vital and you have to carefully plan ahead your moves. Even if the combat is simple, there are many things to take into factor. For instance various terrain types can give you additional bonues/mali, some enemies are more resistant than others to various weapons. Furthermore with the spreading darkness, you really want to make the combat the most efficent as possible. Turning it into somewhat of a puzzle game. During your journey, you can also meet tons of charactets that have their own quests, some may join you on your journey. Others provide services or act as merchants. Finally there is a lot of variety and content in this game, there are tons of classes and things to unlock. Each generated map feels really unique and offers different challenges.

Also the game let's you save items that your next character can chose right at the start of a new run. So there is some progression in this game, furthermore you can spent a rare currency to save at certain points of the maps.

To conclude, there is a lot to talk about but this game is definitely a blast to play and offers something refreshing to the roguelike formula. It really conveys a sense of adventure.

15601748.review:
OWH is a roguelike RPG in the shape of one of the old classics. Pick your hero and hack your way through one of the many worlds as you try to save it. You can influence your strengths and weaknesses by selecting different perks that'll allow you to increase your attack/health or other stats. A dimensional vault will allow you to carry on the items of your dead hero unto the next unlucky chap in line. 
It also bears to mention that OWH has one of the most interesting takes on turn-based combat that I've seen for quite some time. While the game is technically "turn-based", everything happens in real time. Enemies will move as you move, attack as you attack and so forth. If you don't plan ahead, you'll likely find yourself stuck between 5 killer hounds.

Due to the random nature of the game, differences in the gameplay between the classes as well as the ability to have maps randomly generated for you, the replay value of this gem is off the charts. Oh, and the difficulty options will allow you to choose between having a quick 20 minute adventure, or an epic struggle for survival that might stretch on for hours.  

With the risk of overselling a bit, One Way Heroics has gorgeous aesthetics, fun gameplay and a great soundtrack. I'd recommend this for anyone who enjoys roguelike games, or RPGs with a bit of a twist.

15590547.review:
A cute JRPG with a roguelike twist. Plays quickly and satisfyingly and gives a new random dimension every day to challenge a leaderboard for, as well as other challenge modes and random modes to do for fun. Combat is simple but there's a decent amount of classes, perks, gear, and items to find, as well a sparty members to recruit that come with mini storylines to complete. You can also save items from previous runs to hand them forward down the line.


The game forces you to continually press ahead or die to "the Darkness", so exploring and fighting is balanced with continuing onward, ever onward. Everything you do takes up a turn, so exploring a dungeon and hacking down chests takes time, and you need to make sure you've got time to get out of the dungeon you went into! Or break a hole in the wall.

At under 5 bucks, the game is a steal if you're looking for a small, simple game to play bits at a time. You can get in a game before work, or at lunchtime, or etc. You can play for a lot, lot longer at a time if you want to! But the game's strength is its ability to deliver a full package run in about a half hour.

15583232.review: One of the more overlooked games on Steam (probably because it was made in Wolf RPG Editor), this game was actually made by the creator of Wolf RPG Editor. In this game, you have to battle against the screen scrolling basically. If you get scrolled off the screen, you die. There are lots of interesting RPG elements at play here, such as different classes, leveling, skills, weapons, partners, and more. You can also save some items from your failed runs to use for the next run. The game is procedurally generated, and you can play worlds other people played by entering their world's seed. The game will also show you who was/is online on the same map you are. There are daily maps to explore and this game has a ton of depth you might not expect just looking at it. The expanded version is out on Playism and coming to Steam in the near future, but this version is well worth playing on its own.

One Way Heroics is a typical roguelike, that (thankfully) lets you gain in power on restart based partially on what you've done in  previous games.
However, it's always-move-right-or-you-die nature doesn't let you really enjoy an area; it makes encounters overly tough; and, worst of all, it actively discourages exploration in a a genre, and most importanntly, IN A GAME, that rewards exploration.

15273565.review:
Gameplay: This plays a lot like Mystery Dungeon games, only instead of a dungeon, you get a rather linear strip of land. Luckily, the game spices things up by throwing in an instant-kill wave of darkness, which means you have to constantly move to the right while gaining enough exp and resources to survive. After you win or die, you get a chance to carry over Hero Points and a certain number of items to the next playthrough.

Each playthrough utilizes a seed (string of characters) that determines all the random NPCs, towns, obstacles, and everything else in the world map. Additionally, the game will also generate daily campaign dimensions with special conditions and challenges. This seed system gives you the choice of discovering new dimensions to keep the gameplay fresh or revisiting old dimensions that have favorable conditions for the various Steam achievements.

Story: At first, the plot seems fairly generic, since your mission is basically to find and kill an evil overlord to stop the darkness. However, once you play on higher difficulties, you get a chance to recruit NPCs, who all have interesting backstories and world building lore to tell you as you raise their affection. If you manage to set off all their flags, you will also get their endings along with an achievement.

15238536.review:
Ultimamente me encontraba en un momento en el que los juegos que tengo me aburrian, no jugaba mucho, más que Dota 2 con mis amigos y otros juegos más.. Y fue así que encontré este juego el cual es  una joya rara en la industria, que he estado disfrutando mucho en los pasados días y no he querido detenerme.

En primer lugar, lo tengo como un regalo, así que no tuve que gastar nada en él, simplemente fue un regalo expectacular, maldición. En cuanto al juego en sí, lo primero que pensé es que sería una cosa muy repetitiva en el que siempre haces lo mismo sin ninguna diversión (matar, correr, matar, morir)... y por el contrario, es un impresionante juego con mucha diversión.

La primera cosa que me di cuenta es que siempre voy a querer jugar más. Yo no soy un fan de los juegos donde se tiene una cantidad limitada de tiempo para hacer algo, pero la oscuridad me empujo a ir más allá en el juego, y le da un impulso de adrenalina increíble.

La segunda cosa es que yo soy un gran fan de RPG's y tal, y este juego es de los que pongo mi alma en mi personaje. Hay tantas posibilidades, no se puede evitar este juego si te encanta algo diferente cada vez que le pones "Juego Nuevo".

Así que supongo que voy a hacer una especie de resumen:

Pros:
+ Juego muy divertido, nunca se vuelve aburrido
+ Gráficos bastante decente
+ "Sólo una más vez" o "5 Minutors más" -tipo de juego
+ Uno de apuesta no es tan largo hasta que encuentre un punto de guardado / morir, por lo que puede jugar a este cuando estás aburrido y tienen poco tiempo para jugar.
+ Mi fetish de RPG's... o sea el alma se complace
+ Es muy divertido a veces "Corre Forest, Corre"
+ Tu hada personal dira que te bañes ya que llevas tiempo sin levantarte.
+ Gran durabilidad 

Contras:
- No hay mucho en cuanto a la Creación de un Personaje, dos apariencias y con un 3ero que es desbloqueado... sin embargo usar las clases es lo divertido y dificil. 
- Los mundos creados al azar pueden ir desde "Que ch$%&%# es esto!?" a "LOL no tengo oportunidad..". Nunca habia gritado tanto a trav´s de un terreno de nieve, luego desierto, para pasar por una área volcánica y luego nieve de nuevo para entonces morir por la Oscuridad.. "Demonios.."
- Realmente muy frustrante cuando mueres en el juego y sabias que te faltaba solo un poquito más para romper tu record.. "Por que!?!? Por que a mi!?!?" 

Como Conclusión:

¿Te aconsejo comprar este juego? Depende. Si no quieres un juego en el que en "teoría" se tiene que hacer casí lo mismo, pero en diferentes situaciones, o si quieres un juego fácil, no lo compres. Entonces, sería que si amas los juegos de RPG y más con un estilo oldie, que te gusten los retos y pasar grandes frustraciones, este es el juego para ti.

15006888.review:
*tl;dr:
This game is basically walking to the right side, while avoiding the darkness that keeps eating everything from the left side, with RPG elements and randomized world.*


-The game has different classes.
-Each world is different (randomized).
-The game has good difficulty modes (They are not too easy and not inhumanly hard)
-You level up your character, by gaining exp from creatures that spawn around the world or in dungeons.
-The game has multiple classes that you need to unlock. Each class has different strenghts and weaknesses.
-Each class levels different stats up faster. For example the sorcerer levels inteligents faster than the knight class.
-Story is scattered. You need to beat the game multiple times on different difficulties and with different characters, to find out more about the story.
-Great replay value if you like walking east every time.

Overall I'd say this is a good game for the completionists, who dont mind doing the same thing in a randomized world over and over again.

I wouldn't recommend buying this if you're not planning on spending hours unlocking the characters and the different endings or difficulties.

DLC EDIT:

-Monster spawn more and items spawn randomly, so no more waiting or sitting around
-More items have been added and the spawn rate has been reworked so powerfull items are more rare
-More story has been added and the main story has been completed.
-Mini bosses have been added
-Random events have been added
-More terrain has been added
-More NPC's and shops/dungeons have been added

The DLC is a great addition to the game, the events, mini bosses and random loot will keep you busy during your runs, while the extra quests and companions will keep you coming back for more.

(I apologise for my bad english)

14945737.review:
[quote]"A unique and comedic take on the JRPG/RPGMaker Genre that is so satisfying that even if you die for the first few runs in the game, you'll be sure to come back for more"[/quote]

[h1][u][b]Game Details[/b][/u][/h1]

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The game is pretty much immersive to the point that it could even lead to addiction. With a total of 8 classes (3 initial classes if my memory serves me right), it adds variety and replay value. Though some might see themselves inclined to a certain class since it is kind of OP. There are dirty humors within the dialogues too, though it's mild enough (unless you understand the references or the language).
The maps are limited, in which you will notice after a few hours. Though their sequences and contents may change depending on the dimension/campaign you will play through. 

[b]Graphics:[/b] You'll mostly see pixel graphics in this game except when character dialogues pop up. Nothing more, nothing less.

[b]Audio:[/b] The game showcases good, quality music. The tracks change depending on the area you are currently at which creates the mood of the setting.Even though I already have played the game repeatedly, the charm of it still lingers fresh to my ears. Sometimes, I find myself opening up the game and idling on the menu screen while listening to the opening/menu soundtrack.

[h1][u][b]The Verdict[/b][/u][/h1]

For a game that packs a lot of replay value, comedic references, good RPG transition and a unique side-scrolling mechanic, it is already a great deal by itself even without discount. A must-buy for JRPG fans.

If you are asking if this game is worth its value, my answer is [b]"Yes, it is worth it"[/b].

[quote]If you would like to see more recommended games that is worth the value you are paying, please visit my other [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/rankmenotplz/recommended/]reviews[/url], or follow our curator group at [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/GoodGamesGR#curation]Good Games Giveaways & Reviews[/url].[/quote]

14941636.review: Sort of like Passage, but fun and a JRPG. Takes all the best parts of random item drops, grinding, and stat boosts and cuts off all the excess, leaving you with a fast-paced, enjoyable gem of a game. It's probably the lightest rogue-lite I've ever played, complete with - fairly plentiful - opportunities to save at no penalty (if there's an unlockable difficulty with no saves, play that, though it really [i]should[/i] have been unlocked from the start if it does exist, and included if it doesn't) - but it's still challenging enough, and the procedurally generated worlds are surprisingly satisfying to carve your way through. Definitely worth getting, even at twice the asking price.

14929363.review:
To be quite honest I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought this game. It isn't exactly my normal style but it was also on sale for less than a buck so I figured it couldn't hurt to try it. It was a great decision. 

The game isn't intricate, instead it's a short fun game with excellent replay value. Think of a game that was ridiculously simple, but that simplistic approach made it all the better and you basically end up with One Way Heroics. The game is easy to pick up and it encourages multiple replays since you are allowed to store items after you die so you can use them in the next round.

Overall it was totally worth it, especially if you can catch it on sale.

14928736.review:
For such a small price even outside of sales, One Way Heroics is a prime example of good game design and amongs the best rouge-like games on the market today having the honor to share that place with titles such as This War of Mine and FTL.
Some highlights of the game's features:
Pros:
-Great Soundtrack
-Easy to learn the mechanics after about an hour or two
-Hectic as hell (especially after the 500km mark)
-Great combat which really makes you think what you want to use in that one crucial turn.
-Innovative unlock system which really sets it apart from most rouge-likes.
Cons:
-No native graphics support (have fun playing at 480p)
-A bit cheap at times (really, rarely any save zones after the 500km mark?)

I had set this game aside on my wishlist to pick it up at a time when it was less than it's already paltry cost, so I picked it up for $0.87 and I truly and wholeheartedly believe it was one of the best purchases I've made on Steam. 

On the surface level I thought this game was going to be a casual game that I could kill some time with and that's a true statement, but there is also an even more intense side to this game. This game is like an anime version of Pokemon Mystery Dungeon I've always wanted. The mechanics remind me a lot of PMD, the attack mechanics are similar the fact that you have to eat is similar, the random creation of worlds to travel, the recruiting of teamates. It's all amazing. 

I don't think I can even list off the Pros and Cons because I just love this game. I would suggest playing this game with a controller, just because it's very comfortable and enhances the casual-ness. 

If you are contemplating buying this game and asking yourself whether it's worth it, I'd say buy it. Buy it and play it hard. I would have bought this game for the full price had I known how absolutely amazing it is. 

Also, there is actually an elaborate plot with characters and it's funny. 

Buy it right now.

14859027.review:
Let's say you wanted to bring back the old, simple RPGs of the early 90s, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy I. Plenty of people have done that, aped their style and failed. So you know you need to create a simple RPG, but you need to use all the gathered knowledge and experience of the past 20 years of RPGs to shake out what works, what doesn't, what's fun, what's not, what worked then that doesn't work now and what works now that wouldn't have worked then.

Congratulations, you've just created One Way Heroics: An early 90's style RPG informed by the knowledge of the past 20 years of RPGs!

The storyline is simple: Save the world. Classic, right?
Well, thing is, you're on a timeline. That's new.
It also makes it very difficult to explore everywhere and talk to everyone--two things you MUST DO in an RPG!
Ah, but the game is randomly generated, and you can re-visit a world by re-entering the seed (think something similar to old save codes). That's both new and old!
But there are save slots too, if you reach the classic save point. That's old.
When you die, you can transfer some of your experience and gear to your next playthrough. That's new!
So too is using some of that to unlock new classes and perks!
This revisiting, this ability to replay worlds and continue on after failure with an overarching metagame leads to another thing that works now which wouldn't have worked so well in an older RPG: The game can be run through and beaten in a couple of hours or less.

This game brings in some of the best aspects of casual games and hardcore games, of old RPGs and new RPGs, to make a great RPG you can put down and pick right back up on later. I honestly feel a little bad only paying 87 cents for it due to a sale, but the game is under 5 bucks normally... still a steal, considering it doesn't play like a $5 game!

If you like RPGs but no longer have time for them, this is the game for you.

14841758.review:
One Way Heroics is a turn-based roguelike game. After the character creation and a bit of customisation you are dropped into a randomly generated world with death coming for you from the left side of the screen and adventure, loot and almost certain death waiting for you on the right. Every time you move, fight, use an object or talk, the world moves on: enemies act and the darkness comes a little bit closer, forcing you to plan your next moves well. Do you want to try going for that treasure chest? Kill that enemy? Explore that building? Maybe talk to a merchant somewhere else on the screen? You are very unlikely to be able to do everything. Luckily, you can generally move a bit faster than the darkness, so even if you let it come close, you will be able to outrun it for a bit again, provided you don't waste too much time for a bit. If you make it far enough, a boss will show up and you can win the game... or die trying. 

Due to the random map generation, the difficulty of the game will vary greatly from cakewalk to trying to break a wall with your head. However, after each round you are allowed to buy new perks, unlock other classes or upgrade your dimensional vault, a storage that allows you to transfer things into your next round - great for storing that overpowered weapon you found right before darkness caught up to you. 

Not a game you will end up sacrificing your social life to, but a great deal of fun to have in little bursts. It's quick to pick up, the rounds are short and refreshing, and afterwards you will still have a fair amount of the day left to spend on studying, working or even socialising if that's what floats your boat.

One Way Heroics is a AMAZING RPG!
While theres not much o a story, One Way Heroics still is great in another aspects, from the fact that each level is randomly generated which gives you hard deciscions you have to make  in a way of a Telltale game. You start off talking to the Queen after creating your character, now first off playing it, there are instructions on how to control, but theres still no sense of starting & learning to make your way, it just drops you in without much to know, which is quite a minus for starting out. But prior to my last sentence, once you learn, it gets better, a lot better. After you learning the controls, first thing i did was die, why was that? i pondered for the few seconds til i made another game, then i understood, the game keeps scrolling to the right, everytime you do something, & it only stops when you use an ability which makes it stop for 3 turns, which unless you are fighting, or as it suggest when to use it, breaking through walls for which i will cover later, its not always that useful, less a emergency. (it also increases damage during this period)
As i said before, it scrolls constantly every turn, & thus this is were the hard choices come in. Your inventory weight is limited, meaning you can only carry so much, & at the start its not that big of an inventory, its allright, but you need to increase it early on by giving up your Levels at a goddess statue in a dungeon, there are several statues, but not in all dungeons, this idea right here is also very interesting, also at the statue you can increase specific skills (Strength, Intelligence, Agility Etc.), which once again, is very interesting & cool. But then theres "Where to go", as you roam there are towns you can pass by which of course you can buy equipment at, & at the same time, in towns (where scrolling does not stop, still gotta keep moving) & outside of towns, there a items you can find, there are a lotta good items you can get, but the problem where in lies with inventory space, if you don't have enough, then ya can't carry, or ya gotta trade it for something else. With limited amount of moves it can be hard to get through, or get to towns & dungeons, which can have major items, but depending on your previous moves, you may not be able to get through, but alas, there is hope. Breaking walls, literally you can beak through while hopped on coolade & 'splore dem dungeons or to get through the towns. (sorry you can't actually be hopped up on coolade) the last thing to mention, past all the things i said, this game can be long, & i mean long, do not expect a short game, the goal is to get to a certain distance & fight a appearing boss, but the distance to get to the boss, can be long, because it is randomized, & even if its at like, 250 distance, getting through 200 is long enough, & it doesn't end there, everytime you start a new quest is randomized, making it different everytime, thus far longer! You either have the decision to play a random generated world, on normal, or hard (Normals hard & long enough) or there are also different modes to playthrough, which i haven't even covered cause of the main game, damn its long!

One Way Heroics, is a constantly moving, tough decision making, level sacraficing, long tough RPG, & if you like those kind of games, its the right kind for you.
But alas here are the plus & minuses of it.

PLUSES
+Long, with several different modes & the normal game is randomly generated.
+Challenging, its really tough with the screen scrolling, & random hard enemys can pop up to kill ya instantly if your not prepared.
+Its an RPG, cmon, whoz dusn' like rpgs.
+Classes & traits, several different classes & traits to choose from & unlock as you slowly play through.
+Randomly Generated Worlds
+Several other different modes besides the story to play through
+Records Your Run, after making a run, it records the entire thing, which you can save & show others.
+A Universal Inventory, basically if yur current character dies, but you found such a cool item & ya wanna keep it, you can unlock universal inventory spaces, which can hold items for your next character.

MINUS
-Really doesn't teach you how to play, or whats happening so much at the beggining
-Customization, while its not a big deal, there would be a bit more if you could customize your character besides there being just a gender & class choice.

14813460.review:
This is the sort of game that feels really well realized.

The gimmick of One Way Heroics is the constant movement of the screen to the right. This may seem like a simple mechanic, or maybe something that would limit the fun you could have, but it's honestly what makes this game so addicting.

You have to plan ahead. If you blindly rush into any dungeon you see you'll likely find yourself stuck behind a wall, frantically trying to break it down as the darkness creeps up from behind. You have to consider whether you can clear it before the darkness catches up, whether you have the HP and gear required to take on the monsters inside, and whether to advance into a room or wait and let the mobs come at you one by one.

It encourages you to pack all those items that you'd discard without a second thought in other games. Scroll of Confusion? Use it on the Demon Lord so you can run away while he flails randomly. Teleportation Pill? Use it when caught behind a mountain range and pray it drops you on the other side. (Seriously, watch the map. Mountains are just as dangerous as monsters.) Nayuta Fruit? Use it when in a snow area to replenish your energy. Big stone? . . . Leave it, this one is actually useless.

The character classes are reasonably varied. Each class starts with different stats and abilities depending on what their purpose is. For instance, the Knight has the Great Wall ability, which lets him regen health every turn. While the Bard has the Song of Heroism, which increases party members damage and defence. There's also an adventurer class, with stats that make him perfect for stashing as much loot as possible.

The world generation is simple, but effective. You'll be seeing the same tiles over and over again, with few real differences between the biomes. Thing is, it's the layout that matters, not the scenery. It's the generation of Alters of the Goddess, towns, Dark Brotherhood hidouts, and Golems (Be very prepared before you try to take these things on) that make each new world interesting.

After each run you'll be awarded Hero Points which you can spend to unlock new perks, classes, and expand your Vault. (In which you can store items from your previous run, in order to use them in the next.)

The last feature, and judging from the other reviews here also the most unappreciated, are the story missions. These change every day, one day you'll be accompanied by the healer Dosey, the next you'll be tasked with rescuing the Queen. Each of these NPCs have different stories which you'll learn more about as you fight with them. These really make adventuring more interesting, and are a nice addition to the game. They didn't have to be there, but it's nice that they are.

One Way Heroics is, in my opinion, criminally underpriced. I fully recommend picking this up.

One Way Heroics is a fantastic example that games dont have to provide 60-80 hours in the core content and story to keep you hooked for two or three times as many hours.  The core gameplay feature used in OWH is one that I had almost forgotten existed and I was impressed with how well OWH executes it.  Breath of Fire Dragon Quater was the last time I played a game that expected you to fail early and immediately provide the spark to do it all over again by keeping some of the items/skills you acquired and knowledge of what to expect.  I dont want to ruin the game's story surprises that took me completely off guard to the point I felt it was better than what most mainsteam titles have presented in the past few years.
I thought i had a firm grasp my 4th run through but I did not feel satisfied that I had completed its story until my 8th or 10th.   I still get the feeling there is more for me to find given I learned something new each time and I'll keep playing it even if there weren't.  PROs - Provides addictive gameplay that you can experience in less than an hour or several if you amp up the difficulty, Wonderful Soundtrack, and daily campaign dimensions that add more challenges and interesting modes of play.  The tone of this game had feelings of nostalgia running through me every playthrough and i finally realized it was because of how much it reminded me of the Fire Emblem series.  I think if you cut this game it would bleed pure heroism.  CONS- None buy this game ASAP only the unimaginative could find faults in a game as enjoyable as this and the reason would be that it doesnt have awesome graphics. 14674705.review:
One way heroics is a great rogue-like turn-based quasi-tactical rpg. 
It's hard to label this game as any one specific catagory, but it's ideal is apparent.

This game is all about strategy, and uses a grid-based platform.
If you are a fan of fire emblem style gameplay, you may like this game.

The second element is more of a rough and tumble type of turn-based rogue-like battle system.
First you choose your action, then all other actions occur after your action, then time moves foreward and stops when it comes back to your turn. It's a very simple, yet complex system as there are a multitude of effects to change the style that you play. (examples: combos, criticals, ranged, meditation, throwables, etc etc)



Another huge aspect, which I believe carries this game to a better aspect, is it's music.
While the volume isn't always properly adjusted for some of the areas, the music is still great for every single area/theme in the game.
also I swear I heard guile's theme...


In addition to to having great music, the effort they put into the smaller details in the game, such as character interaction and ending sequences, goes to show how much they actually cared for the game. This is something more developers need to do.


I would give this game a solid 9/10.
-1 point for including hippy tree huggers.

14642646.review:
One Way Heroics is a great single-sitting roguelike. (4/5)

Pros:
[list]
[*]The game isn't inundated by heavy story. Recruitable NPC's each have a short story, which you discover when certain conditions are met.
[*]It has several ways to win, and hence has several endings.
[*]There are many classes and skills to encourage replayability and experimentation.
[*]Every play-through is different. (Maps, monsters, items are all randomly generated).
[*]You can customize gear over several play-throughs.
[*]The music is great.
[*]The controls are easy to use.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Not all keyboard controls are customizable. (You can fully customize a controller though.)
[*] RNG can be frustrating. Sometimes you're just plain unlucky, but I wish there were some guarantees in the game (ie. If you find a locked door, you have a chance to get a key).
[*] Replayability drops off a bit after you've finished all achievements and seen every ending.
[/list]

One Way Heroics is a fun game where you can sit down for a couple of hours and try your luck. There are a lot of ways to play, each are equally rewarding. The stories are short, yet empathetic. My only regret is that there isn’t much more for me to do.

After about 50 hours of play, I’ve exhausted all endings and achievements. All that’s left for me to do is craft the ultimate weapons/armor and beat my previous scores. I still play occasionally for a quick bit of fun, but I’ve moved on.

One Way Heroics is totally worth the asking price of $3.49. I’d easily pay $10. I got it on sale, and was pleasantly surprised.

14365574.review:
One Way Heroics emulates the aesthetic of old school JRPGs without feeling like it’s trying too hard to recapture nostalgia. With each procedurally generated world, each combination of Perks and Classes, and each difficulty level, there are infinite gameplay experiences possible. 

If you’re a fan of sprite-based JRPGs and want a break from traditional turn-based combat and random battles, I would highly suggest you check out One Way Heroics. The simplicity of the game makes it easy to get into and hard to put down, creating an experience that borders on addiction.

One way heroics is a rogue like indie turn based rpg.
You choose a class,sex and up to 3 traits and venture in a quest to save the world from darkness.
There's a inminent darkness approaching, everytime you move it gets closer to you, if it touches you you're a goner.
Each time you finish a game by either reaching the demon lord or dying you will be ranked in several categories and tips about how to increase your game efficiency.
You will also get heroic points to buy special traits, classes and advantages like being able to storage items for the next playthrough.
Game has is challenging and the random generated npcs,monsters and paths can screw you over your be your best friend.
The game costs less than 4 dollars and i'd say that's the ideal price for a game like this, good to know some indie developers know how to price their products.

14257147.review:
Have you ever gotten a game for sale price and after playing it, you feel like you'd have been satisfied with the value even if you paid full price? For me, One Way Heroics is that, except I'd feel happy paying more than sale price.

One Way Heroics is a rouge-like game kinda like a Mystery Dungeon game, except you're not stuck in a dungeon and have a randomly generated world to explore. Except with one twist: There's Darkness to the left. And it endlessly creeps up on you. And if you fall in it, you're dead! So you're stuck going to the right. And there's monsters out there, too, so remain on guard! Of course, there's helpful stuff out there, too!

One Way Heroics is kinda tough at first, but it gets easier as you go along, unlock classes, and generally get an idea of what to do. And it's alright if you mess up after you got some cool item, because after you die or clear you game, you're allowed to put items into the Dimensional Vault, to use them on another run. You've got limited space, though, so until you're heroic enough to expand it, watch how you use it!

I had a lot of fun with this game, and I only spent 87 cents on it! So it's a definite recommendation from me.

Best game.

14230183.review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a RPG Rogue-like game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

There are some settings before the launch. at Config. 
You can choose if you want to play on a high pc/medium pc or a low end pc. (you can change during the game by pressing F5).
There is 3D mode and software mode. Software mode is better for low end pc.


There is a Sound volume slidebar and it is marked with bars.
There is a music volume slidebar and it is marked with bars.
Pressing F10 will make it fullscreen. Pressing it again will make it windowed.
You can play with a controller.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You are playing a hero that has to defeat the evil. You can choose between a class and a perk. Each with their own effect and attritbutes. Each step that you take will bring you closer to the evil. But the game is side-scrolling and everything on the left is "destroyed" and you are forced to keep walking to the right. Whenever the screen has catched up, you will die. Every step, Every move, Every action that you will do, will bring the left side of the screen closer to you. You have to kill enemies to get experience to level up and finding loot to make your character stronger. Once you have finished a run, you will get points at the end of the level which will help you on the next run. (once you have spend it ofcourse).

Game has very good music.
Gameplay is fun but a bit repetitive.
Graphics is decent.
The game is fun but at some parts tricky too.
There are different save slots.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

None.

-------------------

I Give this game a 8/10

14196172.review: Enjoyable enough, and has some replay ability. Given the price this game is a good buy.

14184669.review:
Takong "Gotta Go Fast" to the ultimate level, OWH challenges you to be able to manage your time, as every turn removes one row of the map. Everything save talking to an ally takes up a turn. Despite the intimidating apperance, the game is actually rather simple once one gets a idea on how to play. The easy mode really helps new players, but harder difficulties give signifigantly better rewards, like partners. Special mention to the partners, they really can steal the show. Especially Panty, who challenges you to take time out of your adventure to gather money, which can take lots of time, and Freida, for her ending.

Pros:
Psudo-Online: Ghost of other players can give you items.
Companions: Good time.
Titles: Titles can boost/weaken an enemy or ally, conversations also change to match NPC's title.
Gamplay: Simple but fun.
Seed system: Self explanitory. However, every seed has a Hall of Fame list, showing everyone who ever beat the seed in order, and every seed you beat gets added to a list, allowing you to check the Hall of Fame to see changes.

Neutral:
Artstyle: VERY Simple. I personally like it. You may not.

Cons:
Padding: One ending involves going about 2000 miles/tiles/km. This gets EXETREMELY tiring, and prepare to resort to save-scumming your way to victory here.
Saving: Not every world has everything. When starting, I often used the seed "Shinryu" and never got save points. (Moral, don't use Shinryu).
Terrain: Minor complaint, but after a while, the biomes start to repeat over and over, with no randomly generated structures to set apart (I once got three empty plains in a row).

Overall: 9.5/10 Would auto-scroll again

One Way Heroics

     This is one of the most simple games that I have played on the PC to date. The game combines some of my favourite machanics for some oldies that I enjoy and combines them in a way that makes each new map playthrough a fun and interesting experience. Although each playthrough is not considerably long the ability to transfer items from one playthrough to the next is quite an interesting game machanic that you can use to do strategic playtroughs in an attempt to aquire high level items for early use on a new map or simply attempt to finish the game in a single run through without useing any items from a previous playthrough.

     Taking into consideration that the story is supposed to be simple and short I would give an average rating for story and a high rating for gameplay. Leaving this as a highly recommended game for times when you are not sure what to play or when you are looking for somthing simple to pass the time.

13884285.review:
9/10 Gameplay
11/10 Value

An amazing game, aquired from a friend while it was on sale for 87 cents. 87. Cents.

I was reluctant at first. "What could this game be? Looks like Final Fantasy Tactics, which I love, but is quite dated." I was delightfully WRONG. It plays more like Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, with the twist of death always pushing you from the left, forcing you to always move forward to the right. An amazing game with infinite replayability. After beating the short campaign with one class with one set of perks, you challenge yourself to play it again with a different class a different way, or even challenge a harder campaign. Honestly, I've seen games go for quite literally 4x the price and offer nothing but crap, with less gameplay and much less effort placed into it. This might be the only time I'll ever say the price tag is too low for such a game.

13748512.review:
This is a gem of a game that I picked up for $.87, would've paid full price in hindsight. The simple concept, the execution in a rougelike randomly* generated rpg world-- and it all comes together wonderfully in whatever way you want it to. A quick, leisurely stroll into a final boss confrontation that might end with a little cheeky grin? Aye, not too hard to play your cards that way on easymode after you test the game dynamics in a few runs. Something a little more intensive and nervewracking for that character you've grown fond of as they developed? You can have that too. Layer on top the rotating special worlds you can select and the game has fantastic replayability that more than outweighs the meagre price.

9/10. Gave me everything I wanted out of the title and more.

13672917.review:
A turn-based fantasy Roguelike RPG with a twist: in place of a dungeon with hallways, you are constantly on the run from a wall of death.

Suggested for:
-Those who do not mind losing more than winning.
-Completionists who like working to find 'the true ending'.
-Those who excel in turn-based tactical RPGs.
-Lucky people.
-Those who like JRPGs, but do not want to bother with a super complex story this time.

My Favorite Pros:
-Limited classes, but high amount of initial customization.
-Rewarded from good runs by being able to pass items to the next run.
-There are actual in-game hints to finding story secrets.  Hard to realize, but they're there.

My Annoyed-At Cons:
-That fairy needs more poses.
-Equipment durability.  I know it's required, but graaaah, it sucks to have my weapon break in the middle of combat.
-Some worlds does not allow stocking of food before long stretches of foodless zones.  Requires choosing a different world after you die... which you will.
-A Roguelike with a save system... seems kind of against what a Roguelike is... but oh well.

13660988.review:
This game is far-worth the less-than-1$ I've spent on it, to get as much time as I've had out of it all in one sitting...

The entire urgency feeling that "the darkness" puts upon you is one of (if not -the-) game's defining factor(s).
You end up weighing in how much loot you can drag with you, what loot to drag with you, what items to keep on you, what stats to raise at an altar (because you want to carry more items right? RIGHTT??!?), how far you can even get through a dungeon before it becomes too risky, what monsters you should engage (is that lizard behind that chest a noob? or will he kill me in 2 hits right after i open this treasure chest...), how you should play your class (focus characters are a total pain in the ass...even though I killed the final boss in only 3 hits, as opposed to 100...total pain-in-the-ass!), what class to play after you've tried them all (heck, I've JUST tried them all...they're all unique enough to want a bit of each of them, even though the first two are quite similar).

Its just a total clusterfuck of choices put upon you, all because of the timed factor...I'm ashamed to say I don't even know what some of the stats even DO I've been so sucked into playing the game and not worrying about it...

If that sounds too stressful for you, don't worry, it isnt, the game doesn't take itself too seriously, with cutesy anime graphics everywhere, and your hilarious little fairy companion that you might get a dialogue prompt asking to 'equip' (lol!). The first difficulty is cakewalk anyways...you could practically travel all the way to the demon lord (the final boss) without picking up a single item, or leveling up at all, and still beat him if you were careful enough. That doesn't mean it isn't fun as heck to play, since the further you go the harder the game gets, but you get to choose if you go just as far as you need to to finish, or if you push on to get better gear for the final battle...CHOICES! :p

Havn't played anything like this before, probably won't find another chance to...
That, and, with the time I've had right now (7hrs) I've only scratched the surface, beating the game once with each character on only the easiest difficulty!

13515128.review: I've beaten the end boss twice now and really like the pacing of this game. It's a classic roguelike in that enemies move only when you move / perform some action and the forced scrolling mechanic adds an interesting element to navigation. The average playtime for a successful run is 20-30 minutes, although I've only done the walk in the park mode. The dimensional chest also adds a nice way to store gear for a different class that may drop during your run. Overall I'm very happy and you can't beat the price - 87 cents during the Winter Sale. I'm even considering buying this for a few of my friends to share this gem and help support the dev since they did a stellar job with this.

13513090.review:
By this point, we all know what a roguelike is, even if the exact distinctions have become muddled. Perhaps many of you play roguelikes fanatically. I am not talking games like Binding of Isaac or FTL. I am talking ADOM, Nethack, Dungeon Crawl, those sorts.

Those of you who do play those games may feel at times that their greatest strengths, their vast complexity and length, can often become overbearing and intimidating. By the end of any roguelike, the game becomes exhaustive. You've been at that game for days just for that one playthrough. And how many times did you have to die just to learn every special situation, and figure out every monster along the way to victory? These games require a lot of cognitive overhead and rote memorization.



Doesn't it seem counterintuitive that I write a gripe about roguelikes in a recommendation for a roguelike? Yes, sure, but this is exactly what One Way Heroics tries to shy away from. It is a true roguelike, but it shies away from the issues I stated before. It plays fast and simple. You could expect to complete a full game within a few hours, and it provides enough of a challenge that it isn't a pushover for it. The wall of death to your left also rids you of the tedium of stashes and grinding.

Your perspective of the game may be different from mine, but this is the most important aspect to me. This is how I sum up the game and why I play it.

I play roguelikes for their nuanced and complex gameplay.
I play One Way Heroics for its simplicity and short length per playthrough.

13285379.review:
One Way Heroics is a very addictive rogue like game, but instead of lasting for hours or days rounds are 5-20 min runs in which you'll be trying to out run the ever present Darkness consuming the left of your screen while gaining enough gear and lv's to defeat the Demon Lord. This makes for an intreasting dynamic as you try to balence exploration, monster slaying, cheast looting, and even buying and saving. For every action you take the darkness creeps a little closer. Luckily after each run you'll earn points towards buying classes (you start with two of the 8 available), Perks (you start with 3 slots and only stat perks available, you can buy skill perks and will aquire 2 more slots as you buy perks), and most importently Dimensional Vault spaces (Which allows you to carry over your best/favorite gear and items). 

OWH is a little light on the story but compared to a lot of rogue-likes it's on par or above. Features a party system you can take advantage of (As long as you have charisma and don't abandon the appropriate npcs to the darkness). A fair amount of gear which can hold up to 10 enchantments meaning a huge variation of what can be found/made. A MASSIVE random map generator (seriously this things HUGE you can create a world by typing in nearly anything). An online mode where you can compare your success to others and even find player ghosts which will grant you half a lv's worth of exp and a random item said character possesed. There's also multiple difficulties ranging from the very very short Walk in the Park  to the slightly more demanding Massive Odeisy, online scoring and 44 acheivements to collect. 
 Now I paid full price and I'm an old school gamer so I can honestly say I've blown a lot more then the measily cost for this wonderful game in an arcade and I'm getting a ton of fun out of it, it's worth the buy!

13278834.review: We don't often see console-style roguelikes - ones that handle well with a controller and are generally accessible - especially on the PC. One Way Heroics is one such roguelike.

13275578.review:
To be perfectly honest, I didn't expect that much for the $3.50 full price of the game.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The number of hours of gameplay to price has proven to be a solid purchase.

I do not wish to oversell.  This is a solid game.  It has both pros and cons.  However, at this price point, it's a very high return on price.

The Pros are that it's a 2d sidescrolling, roguelike, fantasy style game that contains elements of progression post rogue-like death.  The unique aspect of the game is that the world is constantly scrolling to the right, and that if the hero is trapped on the far left of the screen, it's game over.  The game offers a few classes, with more unlocked as you continue to play through, and the ability to carry forward items (how many items can be expanded as well).  It's a typical 2d fantasy style throwback game.

The Cons of this game is the seemingly random difficulty at times.  Experiencing impossible creatures right outside the starting castle, and random event demons that you can't avoid.  This can be painful if you're trying to clear with a particular class and have dedicated some game clearing items towards your hero!  As mentioned in other reviews, there's also random map loading, which can hurt continuity of the game, but is overall relatively minor.

With all of this in mind, I believe buyers will experience a good playtime/cost ratio with this game.

13176486.review:
Got this on sale a while back for less than a dollar. Still trying to beat it. Worth even more than its original price. 

Graphics: Old-school graphics, which can be a boon or curse depending on your tastes. Art style for the characters is anime-style, and I kinda like the sketch style for the PC portrait.

Sound and Music: the music is pretty good( especially in snow terrain), though one track seems to cut out a little when it loops. The Music does fit the mood really well every time, though. Sound effects are nothing special. 

Story: Being a rogue-lite, the story isn't all deep and engrossing as the heavier hitters, but has some interesting twists.

Characters: Pretty likable, actually. The way they develop as you go on your journey is great and while they're not totally original, they're awesome nonetheless. ( and the endings can get pretty touching.)

Gameplay: If you're dipping your feet in the rogue genre, this would be a great place to start. The Ransom aspect is there( provided you don't make perfect world by abusing the world naming system) and death is permanent, but you can reload from saves, provided you have the crystals or luck, the awakening skill helps save your ass if things don't go as planned, and the Vault helps with later playthroughs. The idea of using levels as potential stat boosters is great. There's a variety of classes, each with their own playstyle(defense, long-range, offense, charisma, etc.), though you'll have to earn a few before you get them. I love the simple idea of the side-scrolling aspect; it leads to some very tense moments( especially when in dungeons or near mountains.)And the little touches, like the NPC dialog, the varying levels for enemies, the differeing difficulties, the replays,  and even the multiplayer aspects( no co-op, but there is a way they can help... and you can show how awesome you are when you clear a world.)

All in all, if you can live with the old-school graphics, the relative lack of multiplayer and the rogue-liteness, you'll find a game that is well worth or even more than the price. ( and also, keep an eye on a sequel, which is in developement at the time of this writing.)

Let's start with the pros:

In another word, this game will provide you the opportunity to get a good learning curve, and the elements to make your future gameplay easier or more challenging, totally by your choice (such as using pre-saved items from last playthrough/death or not doing that and just hop right into a new world)
- Maps aren't just 'different', they have different characteristics, coming with different perks and extra challenge. Pick according to your own liking/style (some of them are pre-sets with description, no worry of getting confused!)

In another word, a great deal of variety for gameplay experience and control on difficulties, pick as you desired or just go random!.

Gameplay;

All the npcs have more personality than you do :0)

There is so much heart in this game that this sales is totally not doing it justice!


Ok, as for the cons:

No other complaints really, you'll find the game quite fair once you actually start playing it.

13132428.review:
Like FTL, but as a medieval RPG.

This game has a deceptive level of depth to it, especially for such a cheap game. What makes this roguelike different from most other roguelikes and yet similiar to FTL, is that there is an advancing wave of darkness that forces the screen to scroll to the right. If you fall into the darkness? You die, and thus you need to keep moving to the right to survive, hence the name of the game. You would think that something like that would leave very little room for story, and in a way you are correct. But there is actually a bit more plot than it appears on first glance and you will need multiple playthroughs to fully understand what is going on. 

The gameplay is mostly based around exploring, killing enemies and finding items while staying ahead of the scrolling wave. You need to find items to recover your energy, health and stamina, while also looking for weapons, armor, and enchantments. During this time the Demon Lord will occasionally pop in to try to kill you, and you either have to run from him, using whatever status effect items you have to slow him down, or finish him then and there. This sounds very simple on paper, but in practice it's actually a quite expansive resource and time management game, and you often need to plan your movements carefully to avoid getting killed by the scrolling darkness.

There are also a number of interesting NPCs, but sadly they very rarely appear. Each one has their own backstory, personaliy quirks, and even an associated ending. To mix things up even more, there is a random prefix system that can sometimes spawn either an enemy or an NPC with a stat changing prefix such as "stiff-necked", with some of them even changing the character's dialog, often in hilarious ways.

Like most roguelikes this game has a lot of replay value, but here it's even more enforced by the fact that you can "vault" items at the end of a playthrough so you can get them at the start of another playthrough. Combined with the various classes, starting perks, and random world generation, you will likely end up with quite a bit of variety right at the start of your various runs through the game.

There is even a limited online play component, in that you can start on a world where other players have played and see their ghosts where they have died. At the end of a run you will also see leaderboards listed all the other players who have played on that world.

Unfortunately this game isn't perfect, which is to be expected with it's nearly non-existant price. The stats aren't very balanced, with some like intelligence being less useful than the others, and charm in particular is almost useless given that it's mainly used for recruiting companions, who, as said before are extremely rare. I also noticed that bows seem a bit underpowered since they can't combo like melee weapons and often you can just throw things for similiar damage. Hopefully the upcoming expansion polishes the game up a bit, but even with the few issues this game has, it's worth far more than it's listed price at the moment.

13084174.review:
Roguelikes are my favorite type of game. Since the old days of Rogue and Hack, indie developers from all over have taken the basic ideas of roguelike games (procedurally developed worlds, blistering difficulty and permadeath, for example) and ran with it. 

One Way Heroics literally "runs with it" by providing a game that forces you to keep running forward until you reach your destination: your final battle with the Demon Lord threatening the world. The parts of the world you leave behind are gradually consumed by a darkness that will devour you, too, if you wait too long or try to backtrack. So, in order to survive your encounter with the Demon Lord, you have to prepare yourself by gathering items and equipment and gaining levels on the way.

Replayability is high due to the fact you can use Hero Points gained from a previous playthrough to help your next incarnation succeed better or faster than before. There's the Dimensional Vault, where you can leave your best items behind for the next play-through. You can also unlock new advantages or even new classes, for greater variety and strategy. You may also choose to run through the same world next time, rather than generating a new one, meaning that you can remember where towns, dungeons, merchants and particularly dangerous enemies are on the map, and approach or flee from them accordingly.

The game itself is a short one, which is good for those of us busy folks who want gaming in small bites. You can sit and finish a play-through in less than an hour. But there are multiple worlds (including multiplayer ones hosted online) and modes if you get bored of the standard game. I suspect there is more depth and content in this game than I have begun to scratch the surface of, because it requires many playthroughs to get to.

Would definitely play again (and again)!

13064184.review: Fun and unique interpretation of the Japanese RPG game type. On paper, the concept sounds forced and confusing, but the game plays intuitively after only a few lives. Most importantly, there is a great design sense that unifies the game as a whole. Each class encourages its own gameplay style, and character customization, through an unlock system, is flexible without being overwhelming. An inter-game treasure chest, like that in Shiren / Mystery Dungeon, allows players not used to roguelikes accumulate treasure without being able to horde it. Well worth the price: a game that is rewarding whether you invest hours into it or simply play it as a coffee-break roguelike.

13025224.review:
One Way Heroics is like potato chips: you eat one, and you can't help but go for another.

For those moments where a player wants to pop open an RPG, but doesn't quite want to start a 40 hour time investment, OWH is perfect; simple combat, roguelike gameplay, and varied challenge levels depending on one's mood. Whether for a 20 minute stroll or an epic 2-hour odyssey with perma-death waiting around every corner, this game aims to suit itself to multiple tastes.

Finishing a game, whether winning or losing, awards points used to boost one's future playthroughs (with wins awarding more). Whether it be unlocking new perks or opening new slots in the Dimensional Vault to transfer items from one playthrough to the next, every run feels like it progresses the player. That being said, while there are technically save areas, losing concludes the run and records the player's performance right there - no going back to try and get more points, but it will allow you to conclude a run 'just for funsies'. Maniac Mode, the game's 'hardcore' setting also prevents players from importing items from previous games, though depositing new items is still possible. Save points and dimensional vaults make the game friendly for casual runs, but the true hero wins on Maniac Mode with no takesies backsies (the greatest scores are only counted upon no deaths).

More than that, the game is also surprisingly colorful. Dialogue and narrative is sparse, but sweet and entertaining. Furthermore, there are hidden secrets everywhere: the various characters you meet may have hidden dialogue, items may have unexpected purposes, and the non-restrictive nature of weapons gives a lot of freedom in designing 'builds'. There are even secret ways to win - it is recommended you do not go in with a guide, and simple explore yourself, as reading the wiki ruins a lot of the surprises this game has to offer (don't even look up those secret ways to win).

This reviewer's only criticism is that, after clocking a couple dozen hours, I'm ready for more! The weapons do resemble each other a bit too much, there's a hard limit on the available spells/abilities, dungeons resemble each other, and the charming character dialogues do eventually run dry.

For $3.50, this game was absolutely and totally worth it. It's creative, it's original, it's got high replayability, it suits people looking for various challenge levels, and it deserves to be recognized for what it is: a small but great roguelike RPG.

A minor edit to this review, a newer 'edition' has come out called Mystery Chronicles: One Way Heroics; however, despite slightly higher quality sprites, it manages to be inferior to One Way Heroics and One Way Heroics+. If you want the proper experience, it's here.
