12966537.review:
Part roguelike, part JRPG, One Way Heroics is an hybrid game that should please many people.

The game tasks you to keep moving forward (from left to right) in a world that is randomly generated, to become stronger and stronger, until you're finally able to save the world by defeating the Evil Lord responsible for the Darkness invading from the left.

But contrary to pure roguelikes, a failure doesn't mean you lose everything : when you finish a game (regardless of whether it was a success or not), you can save some items from your inventory into a "Dimensional Vault". The vault allow your next heroes to grab the items from them, and thus start a new game with powerful equipments right from the start. With this system, you can soon have starting heroes that are extremely powerful.

Moreover, since this is an hybrid JRPG, there is a lot more story in this game than there is in a typical roguelike. During each of your travels, you may find some new locations or characters, and this will help you better understand what is exactly happening to the world, as well as unlocking new places, storylines and endings. This helps alleviates one of the problems of roguelikes which is that they sometimes feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again.

The gameplay itself is nice, with many items, skills, and classes that allow for different approaches to combat. It's turn-based, with positioning being an important part of the combat system. If you're lucky, you might later be able to expand your party, and have companions help you on your quests, which add more tactical options. Once again, this is a nice difference to classic roguelikes where you're usually all alone all the time.

Another good point for the game is that it should please a large number of RPG or roguelike fans. It has 4 different difficulty levels and you also have the option to turn off the Dimensional Vault as you wish. This mean that casual players will enjoy being able to finish the game on Easy and Normal, while Roguelike veterans will get the challenge they are looking for by playing harder difficulties, without the help of the vault.

On the whole, I really enjoy One Way Heroics. It offers me some interesting challenges, but somehow, it also feel like a relaxing game, because you're all alone in the vast open country (contrary to many roguelikes who prefer claustrophobic dungeons). It's a very nice game to both unwind, and also get my brain working hard, depending on which difficulty i play on. And i keep coming back to it, because there is a lot of secrets that i have yet to find and classes i have yet to finish the game with.

12930823.review:
A fast-paced, unique and quirky "rogue-lite." One Way Heroics does away with the traditional floor-by-floor navigation of the genre in favor of a love it or hate it gimmick where the screen continiously scrolls to the right with certain death awaiting you if you fail to outrun the approaching darkness! The result is a frantic scramble for survival with the clock ticking down to your inevitable clash with the Demon King.

Far less lengthy than your average roguelike, OWH is designed to be played (and cleared) many times with a plethora of unlockables, performance evaluations and limited online capabilities providing incentive to keep coming back for more even after you've trounced the Demon King.

What OWH lacks in complexity, it makes up for with a host of novel features atypical of the roguelike genre as well as being surprisingly easy to pick up. Presentation is great too with pleasant music and charming SNES-era graphics as well as a responsive and smooth (but also cluttered) UI.

Concerning flaws: There aren't many as long as you're not expecting a traditional roguelike! As mentioned before, the UI can come off a bit cluttered. Luck/RNG plays a tremendous role in your success as usual for the genre and it can be difficult to impossible to mitigate a bad hand that you've been dealt. The forced march style of gameplay definitely will not appeal to everyone and the cutesy-weird anime style might be a deal breaker to some.

Short, sweet, and some replayability, but once you hit a certain level of meta knowledge and beat it a few times it gets stale.

12691044.review:
It is hard to sum up One Way Heroics into just a few words, so let me give you a couple paragraphs. (If you're the sort that likes to go "tl;dr" then just scroll to the bottom, but I mean, then why are you even reading reviews to begin with?)

I picked this game up for <$0.60 when it was sale during the summer. I have to say, those were the best $0.60 I have ever spent. One Way Heroics doesn't appeal to you with stunning graphics, rich storytelling, or intricate gameplay. Instead, it is more retro gaming, silly short tales, and an easy to pick-up set of controls. Now you might be wondering, why would I want something like that? Arguably everything but simplicity of the controls could be considered negative or at least niche.  One Way Heroics doesn't offer high spec gaming while emptying your wallet - what you're buying is meaningless fun and entertainment.

When I first opened this game and started an adventure, I found myself with my silly little 2D character talking to a "Naughty King Victor" about the darkness at the left of my screen that would attempt to eat me until I killed the Demon Lord. Yes, clearly the storyline could use some work, but as I struggled to kill weak mobs and then stronger demons I found myself falling for this game. Everything was fairly straightforward and the desire to complete achievements, "save the world," and become a true hero compels you to play over and over again. It doesn't take several hours to do a run through like a quest in some RPG, just 30 minutes or so if you're short on time. Yet, you can play longer sessions that go for tens of hours depending completely on what you want to do and how much time you have - and those hours? They were some fun hours.

I won't try to tell you that you'll be so entranced with One Way Heroics that you'll spend thousands of hours playing it - you probably won't. But it's easy to lose 10, 20, maybe even 100 hours of your life having fun by sending your hero towards the right of your screen. Was that worth my 60 cents while it was on sale? Definitely. Is it worth the full $3.49? Absolutely. Most of us play games to have fun - and One Way Heroics delivers.

tl;dr?

If you're a hardcore gamer looking for a game with brilliant graphics and intricate/competitive gameplay to drop thousands of hours on, I think you're better off somewhere else.
If you're someone looking to spend 10-100 hours having fun in your spare time? Buy One Way Heroics.

12668501.review:
I got this game on a sale, long time ago, for a dumb and extremely low price, something like half an euro, or even less. To tell you the truth, for such a price, I was expecting something horrible, dreadful, like an 8-bit Ride to Hell. Did I got surprised? Yeah! Buuuuuuut as usual, let me explain the BAD things the game has first, so we can take them out of the way:

The game is kind of short. Of course, for such a price, you can understand it, so it's not that big of a deal. Besides, this is a Rogue-like game, and rogue-like games are usually short, but change in every playthrough, this is no different from the standard on that regard.

The other thing that I did not like at all, is the lack of multiplayer. This game had such extreme potential for a Coop experience, but instead you can play the same randomly generated world at the same time as one of your friends, to see who goes further...INSTEAD OF PLAYING TOGETHER, AND HAVING FUN! I was indeed dissapointed by that, by looking at the captures of some friends that got the game, and by looking at the pictures and videos of the Steam-Store, I was expecting to play at least with one friend in a journey to save the world by punching demons on their d#cks.  You know, the usual. 

Now, let's talk about the GOOD stuff, pretty much everything else. As I said, it's a Rogue-Like. At the start of the playthrough you select the kind of character you desire to control, and special skills for you: You want to be fast? You want to be strong? You want to use magic? You want to start with a companion? You want to start with insane amoutns of gold? It's your choice, and it's indeed well made. I really did enjoy starting in different ways, and testing different strategies.

The game pretty much goes like this: The world is being taken out by some sort of "Dark Sonic Boom" (Damn Obama, he stole that from Guille!), and ANYTHING NEAR THE LEFT SIDE OF THE SCREEN IS F#CKED. Your goal is to travel to the right, getting stronger, surviving the wilds, getting better gear, meeting other people, saving lives, and if you get far enough, saving the world. It might sound simple enough, but the game mechanics make this journey, a journey to remember: First of all, you have to eat, or your character will get tired. Sounds easy enough? Well, there's not that many free food out there, so you have to make sure to visit any Inn or Town and get supplies before they got suck up into Oblivion (I bet that portal leads to Obama's #sshole, NOW THAT'S ONE SICK WAY TO END UP DEAD). Not only that, but your equipment won't last forever. Your stuff has limited use, for example, 100 uses on a sword. Once you swing it for the 100th time, the thing breaks, and it's lost forever. There are ways to repair it and make it last longer, but you should make sure to AT LEAST CARRY 1 BACKUP WEAPON. Infact, I always try to carry at least 3 weapons on myself. And armor? HAH, THOSE THINGS BREAK TOO, SHIELDS INCLUDED! You're far pass f#cked on these lands, specially later on when enemies start to get dangerous!

For a cheap game, there's a lot of fun to be had in this game, and I do recommend it. The game is worth 3€ WITHOUT sales, and that's already cheap enough, on sales it usually lowers to 1€ or so. It's up to you to buy it or not, but I do recommend that you give it a try.

12631900.review:
One Way Heroics is a very nice gem, especially due to its low price. 

GAMEPLAY:
The game's gameplay is relatively simple, making it quite easy to learn, a great positive for a more casual game like One Way Heroics. Fortunately, despite its initial simplicity, the gameplay becomes addicting due to its blend of a slow turn-based aspect together with a sense of urgency created by the ever-scrolling screen. The gameplay becomes especially enjoyable inside of the dungeons, where the player must plan out all of the character's moves to kill all the monsters before the darkess reaches you (and maybe take some loot).

SOUND:
Although it didn't strike me as particularly mesmerising, the sound track does a good job at involving the player, and is enjoyable enough to listen to for a long amount of time. 

ART:
One Way Heroics seems to be following a recent trend of indie games having pixelated graphics, but despite this I really enjoyed the art, and in this case, it matches the old-school RPG feeling of the game.

In conclusion, this game is a good recommendation for those people who only have a couple minutes available to play games and also to those who have multiple hours to play. The game is very enjoyable,and although the game may seem short at first, it has incredible replay value.

Thumbs up for One Way Heroics

12356923.review:
This game is brutal no matter what difficulty you pick, in best possible way as a rogue-like. It has a VERY surprising amount of depth for a game that is by default played on a resolution of about a smart phone (what you see in the screenshots is what you get, and full-screening it does not help its prettiness!). Graphics-wise, it's incredibly indie -- see the character "portraits" in the bottom left corner that seem to be sketches made a bored developer, especially Swordmaster Class C for a laugh.

If you get this game, it's for its gameplay, which does one thing, but does it really, really well. The turn-based gameplay with a constant timer and emphasis on movement will make it incredibly addicting for old-time Rogue-like players, as experience points (read: monsters to farm) and treasure may be within arm's reach but inaccessible due to the choices you have to make. The item appraisal system makes every item a mystery and makes even a new starting sword drop a desired reward, as durability constantly counts down with few ways to repair items and replenish supplies. Even when you're on top of the world, you'll feel pressured and challenged by item weights and inventory limits, decreasing energy and stamina, and other factors to encourage you to weigh risk and reward ("how long should I wear this Training Bracelet, which cripples my stats for more experience?") to get ready for the next area.

The "hidden" parts of the game are by far the most enticing. You simply have to go out and find out for yourself how to get access to things like Party Members, Force powers (spells), the Dark Brotherhood, Hidden Elf Villages, Goddess Statues, and Key of Seals and their associated doors. After each death or victory, the progression system encourages trial and error, mixing and matching unlockable classes and perks with rotating featured Dimensions and allowing players to access the Dimensional Vault to carry over a limited number of items. The game is well-supported outside of a playthrough with a replay system, a hall of fame for each dimension and for your overall profile, and, of course, the different daily Dimensions featured. It does not hold your hand after kicking you out of the castle with a fairy of questionable use, explaining only the most basic and necessary mechanics until you recruit party members: you have to go out and discover it for yourself, since at a base level the game is so simple! Even the limited story and simple humor is fun to discover, especially as more party-member-specific endings are unlocked.

One of the best games on Steam under $5, and amongst my favorite Rogue-likes; highly, highly recommend.

12301434.review:
[b]A game that thrives purely on its innovative gameplay.[/b]

Games like this are part of the reason why I love what indie games bring to the industry. While AAA developers stick to doing what they know will make money (sequel after sequel, FPSs, etc.), indie developers are more often willing to take risks on new ideas. Sure, you still get plenty of repetition out of the indie scene (side scrolling platformers, RPG Maker RPGs, roguelike elements, retro visuals, zombies, etc.) but I think that their overall percentage of innovative games brought to market is higher. Oddly enough, One Way Heroics features all the examples I listed in parentheses for repetition except for platforming, yet it still goes down as an innovative game in my book.

In order for you to be successful in One Way Heroics, every action you take requires that you be mindful of the ever encroaching darkness on the left side of the screen. It's such a simple concept and yet it has such a profound effect on the entirety of the game. I particularly appreciated how it forced a fast pace to the game (an extremely uncommon trait in RPGs) and demanded strategic thinking. Both of these play into a relatively harsh learning curve. My first attempt ended very early on yet I was quickly able to restart and learn from my mistakes. This isn't an exceedingly deep game so the learning curve relaxes after the first few hours. That said, between the 8 classes, a variety of perks you can choose from, and 4 difficulty levels, there are enough new things to try to keep your interest.

It's when you look outside of the gameplay that One Way Heroics comes up short. Its visuals, while not offensively bad, are very generic and bland. The music is a little better but equally generic. I'm still not entirely sure what to make of the story. It's odd because so much of it is worked into the game like an optional sidequest or rare, chance encounter. There were several moments that I enjoyed but the terrible English translation, silly anime character tropes, and high degree of difficulty in even accessing the story put a major damper on this aspect of the game. Despite 33 hours played I only ever encountered one of five NPC characters that you can have join your party and hear their story. The only reasons I can think of to have that level of rarity are a misguided attempt to elongate replayability or an MMO inspired reward for dedicated players. This is an excellent point to lead into my summary: One Way Heroics has a solid gameplay concept at its foundation but is surrounded by otherwise amateurish game design.

12123388.review:
The UI is terrible and requires you to navigate vast quantities of terrible menus using the keyboard or a controller since there's no mouse support.

The game only runs in windowed mode in one of 3 sizes (too small to see, too small to be useful and big and blurry) or full screen in some resolution that's nowhere close to the monitor's native resolution and is thus really blurry and has black bars on the side.

I can't say anything about the game itself. The terrible UI and eye strain inducing resolutions were too much for me to get past. My whole "played" time was sat at the menu with the monitor turned off in order to get trading cards.

0/10. Stay away.

12108060.review:
This game is amazing. It has a combat system similar to what you would find on one of the Pokemon Dungeon games, which is one of my favorites.
You don't have a whole lot of classes to choose from, but you wouldn't expect to at the price. You still have enough to keep you busy for hours on end.
Each run scores you based off your treasure looted compared to treasure possible to loot, monsters killed without being hit, distance traveled, and your overall level. There are some other minor point contributors, but with those four main ones, it means getting to a high score means you have to be focused and make good use of everything you see.

I would recomend this game to anyone who has free time, because it will eat up a whole lot of yours.

12107841.review:
Saw a friend of mine got this game, and I noticed it was on sale for $1...  So, I thought I'd grab myself a copy; I was very much satisfied. :owforce:

One Way Heroics, being a rogue-like on the run, is quite a fun experience.  I was afraid it would be extremely time limit based, which I despise, but I was thankfully proven wrong.  While you do always have to be on the run from the shadowy darkness from the left, you can play a pretty much infinite game...  Just, be aware things will get stronger, and that the Demon Lord will continuously hunt your butt down.

While I extremely enjoy this game, the friend I saw buy this, did not.  This game is not for everyone, but to give you an idea of the games I like, you could say this game is similar, but on a certain degree, to...  FTL: Faster Than Light and Dungeons of Dredmor.

If you're still not quite sure, and if $3.49 is still a bit much for you, I highly suggest picking up a copy when it goes on sale, even one as low as 25% off. :3

12084999.review: This light-hearted turn-based roguelike requires careful planning. Lots of replay as each playthrough gives you the opportunity to unlock additional abilities / classes, and you can stash loot into a shared vault even when you die. Similar to Cargo Commander, worlds are named by their seeds, so you can rank against friends by manually typing in the world name on a start (or similar.) It's, what, five dollars? Pick it up.

12047855.review: This game is like crack. Seriously. Not even joking. One Way Heroics is a perpetualy generated RPG, what is that you may ask? Well everytime you start the game, you load up a different deminsion, and who knows how many there are, there are also special deminsions that will challenge you, say by making enemies stronger, turning ALL NPCs into merchants, or by having you gain an ally, you can pick from a multitude of classes, after you unlock them of course, classes like the Knight, who's got the best starting equipment, The Hunter, your basic archer class, The Adventurer, They're only in it for the Loot, The Force user, with force powers, plus more that would take me to long to list, when you enter your deminsion, you'll be greeted by the king, who proceeds to tell you that there is a demon lord, he has summoned a darkness, darkness is envolping the world, you are the only one who can stop him generic RPG Plot, which is fine, the plot really doesn't count, the gameplay does, and boy is there gameplay, for starters, you're constantly battling enemies, and not being sucked up into the darkness, so you have to plan your moves carefully, do you dare enter the dungeon and risk being trapped, or should you continue on your merry little way. However you decide to play I promise you will die, a lot, luckily there's this thing called the Deminsional Vault, where you can stash your goodies, and then pick them back up at the begining of the game, which if you have a lot of OP loot (like me) it makes the game a cake walk, that is if you decide to open the vault. There is a lot of charm with this game, and it's a really great deal on steam, hours of re-playability, plus secert endings, alternete versions of charcters, not to mention the special deminsions which get changed out daily. I highly reccomend this game, especially if you like rouge-like games.

12042341.review:
I was expecting this to be a traditional, rather good-looking rogue-like. At first, I was dissapointed when i realized that it was the kind of games that would be played in a short-session match/game/run where you start over again everytime. I had hoped for a storyline in which my character and the world around him evolved more and more, bit by bit.

But then, as I played more, as I got further every time, as I recruited different companions, as the story unfolded, as the mysteries came to light, as I got different endings, I realized that this was exactly what I got.

I can only recommend this game, to any RPG and rogue-like fans, to any casual player as well.

Don't be decieved by the apparent simplicity as I was at first glance, this game has a lot to give.

12041400.review: Rudimentary retro graphics paired with a flat / 8-bit soundtrack does not prevent One Way Heroics from succeeding as  a ridiulously addicting rogue-like game. Strongly recommended for those who enjoy rogue-like experiences and/or people who need to add another addiction to their current catalog.

12017581.review:
+ Interesting and challenging concept; felt like a fresh breath in the RPG genre\
+ Every move and item selection has to be calculated, as you're always on the clock
+ Random world generation, unlockable classes, game-modes, and various ways to beat the game add a good deal of replayability
+ Simple, aesthetically pleasing UI
+ Excellent controller support
+ Controls and battle/item systems are all very simple and easy to pick up, especially for an RPG
+ Charming, enjoyable retro sountrack

- Inordinately difficult for new players
- No tutorial

12011360.review:
Curioso [i]rogue-like[/i] muy adictivo en el que controlas un heroe en su misión para derrotar al malvado Señor Oscuro que ha lanzado un hechizo de destrucción sobre el mundo. El juego consiste en ir avanzando hacia la derecha por un mundo generado aleatoriamente, huyendo del ya mencionado hechizo de oscuridad que avanza por la izquierda destruyendolo todo a su paso, con el objetivo de derrotar a un boss final (que en función de la dificultad aparecerá en un momento u otro). Por el camino encontrarás enemigos, aliados, ciudades y tesoros, e irás subiendo niveles y mejorando tu equipo. Cuando termina una partida (tanto si vences al boss como si no), se te adjudican ciertos puntos en función de tu desempeño, que puedes utilizar para desbloquear nuevas profesiones y habilidades para la próxima partida.

Cuando lo ves la primera vez piensas que es un juego cutre hecho con el RPG Maker, pero tras jugar 2 o 3 partidas y empiezas a entender la mecánica, te pica el gusanillo y resulta MUY entretenido para echar una partida de vez en cuando. Como todos los juegos de este estilo en los que el contenido es generado aleatoriamente, hay a veces que las partidas son muy difíciles e injustas, mientras que otras se hacen muy asequibles.

El juego tiene un componente online en el que juegas tu solo, pero en un mapa digamos "común" a varios jugadores, y en la esquina superior izquierda irás viendo mensajes informándote  por donde van el resto de heroes en su propia aventura. También es posible que encuentres el fantasma de alguno de los jugadores que perecieron por el camino, que te proporcionarán experiencia e items para ayudarte. Me da un poco de rabia que no haya también un multijugador clásico de varias personas jugando a la vez, ya que creo que sería muy divertido.

Yo pagué como 2€ por él en un Humble Bundle y me he quedado con la sensación de haber pagado poco para la diversión que se le puede llegar a sacar; si le tienes echado el ojo, por 3€ ni me lo pensaba. Una muy grata sorpresa.

12009370.review: While ugly and unforgiving, One Way Heroics is nonetheless an enjoyable, addictive and innovative take on the crowded roguelike genre.

11989981.review:
My review for this game is very simple, its fantastic. The game is very clever in both its execution of gameplay and art style and here he is what i love about the game:

- Many demensions (worlds) as they are randomly generated
- Tried and tested RPG methods that work, sometimes better than other games
- Easy to pick up, hard to master
- Soundtrack is off the scale (and is free with the game!)

However this game wont certainly be for everyone. If you hate turn based RPGs then you wont like this one bit, as it does rely heavily on this feature. Here are a few nags i have about the game:

- Can become to easy once your gear is insane 
- No enough end game for me (except setting my own personal goals)
- Classes dont feel different enough (however there is a very wide choice)

Also please note, while this game has no direct multiplayer, it does have community demensions in which heroes can compare how they have faired against eachother e.g how far they go in KM.

MY RATING: 8/10 - Worth everyone penny!
